I love Crusader Kings 2.  Perhaps its not for everyone, but the nerdy-ness, the curious and "paradoxical" mix of both deep gameplay options and severe limitations in your control over events, and the humorous randomness of the world of Crusader Kings is a perfect fit for me as a gamer.  I appreciate that this game is both "easy" (all you do is click play and look for genius brides), and "hard" (how many times I have finally created that strong, fair, genius heir, only to have them die in battle a year into their reign... countless).  If you are: 1) into history, 2) into map style grand strategy games, 3) into hilarious events like "because you joined a stanist cult your back has bent and you now eternally face the ground, and your lord, SATAN - you have gained hump-back trait", then this game will be for you!

Crusader Kings II Review: A Grand and Intricate Tapestry of Medieval Power Politics

Pros:

Deep and Complex Gameplay: Crusader Kings II is renowned for its intricate and deep gameplay mechanics, offering players the opportunity to manage a dynasty across centuries. The focus on dynasty building, politics, and diplomacy sets it apart in the grand strategy genre.

Dynastic Management: The game excels in allowing players to shape the destiny of their dynasty. From arranging marriages for strategic alliances to managing succession and dealing with internal conflicts, the dynastic element adds a layer of complexity and immersion.

Historical Authenticity: Crusader Kings II provides an immersive historical experience set in the medieval era. The game's attention to historical detail, including events, characters, and cultural intricacies, enhances the authenticity of the gameplay.

Expansive Map and Variety of Playable Characters: The vast map spans across Europe, Asia, and Africa, offering an extensive playground for players. With a multitude of playable characters, each with unique traits and ambitions, the game encourages diverse playstyles and replayability.

Continuous Development and Modding Community: Paradox Interactive has supported the game with extensive post-launch content, including expansions that add new features and depth. Additionally, a vibrant modding community has created a plethora of user-generated content, expanding the game's possibilities even further.

Cons:

Steep Learning Curve: Crusader Kings II has a notoriously steep learning curve, and newcomers may find themselves overwhelmed by the sheer depth of the gameplay mechanics. The complexity of managing characters, relationships, and realms requires a significant investment of time to fully grasp.

Graphics and UI: While the game's depth compensates for its graphical limitations, the visuals and user interface are not as polished as some other contemporary titles. The user interface, in particular, can be overwhelming, especially for those new to grand strategy games.

Occasional AI Inconsistencies: The game's AI can sometimes exhibit inconsistencies or make seemingly irrational decisions, impacting the overall realism of the medieval political landscape. This can lead to moments of frustration for players seeking a more predictable and strategic experience.

Performance Issues in Late-Game: As campaigns progress into the later centuries, the game may experience performance issues and slowdowns, particularly on less powerful hardware. This can detract from the otherwise immersive experience, especially in lengthy playthroughs.

Conclusion:

Crusader Kings II stands as a grand and ambitious title in the grand strategy genre, offering a deep and engaging experience for players who appreciate complexity and historical authenticity. While its steep learning curve and occasional technical issues may pose challenges, the game's rich tapestry of medieval power politics, dynastic management, and continuous development support make it a captivating choice for those willing to invest time and effort into mastering its intricacies.

A great simulation engine and story generator regarding a noble dynasty and the individual rulers that you get to play as from that bloodline - and at the same time, a poor strategy video game. Crusader Kings never delivers that "just one more turn" satisfaction and drive of top-tier strategy games like Civilization, Master of Magic or even Heroes of Might and Magic. It's slow, dull, overly complicated and repetitive.

Both fans and non-fans are quick to mention this game's complexity and depth and, although there sure are many options and buttons to click, it's more complicated than really complex. The complexity comes from constant micro-management of dozens of things happening together at the same time and struggling with the terrible UI, be it on the several game screens or trying to maneuver your military on the world map.

I'm sure many people with hundreds of hours in-game would disagree and say that the interface is very intuitive and everything is very easy to manage - but hey if I had 400 hours of experience doing open-heart surgery, I would probably tell everyone it's a cakewalk too!

Is this game deep? I think there's an argument to be made that it is but I think a majority of people praising its depth are confusing "complicated" for a quality. If anything, a game that needs to keep constantly pushing "story events" to you every five minutes is an admission that its amazingly ambitious simulation engine fails to generate interesting gameplay by itself.

[b]PS: Font rant[/b]

There are dozens of results you can find through a web-search for "Crusader Kings 2 text is hard to read" and i think the problem boils down to: poor support for non-intended resolutions; awful font choice; and transparent backgrounds for text panels.

For a game with minimal graphics and almost entirely menu- and data-driven, this is completely unacceptable. Stellaris by the same studio, using the same engine, on the same device, with the same resolution has perfect readability and was released while CK2 was still being actively developed, for a decade, all the way up to 2021. 

This is beyond mind-boggling to me... but this is the studio that manages to have 90% of their dozens of DLC (per game) be poorly-reviewed and that managed to have half of their players negatively review their latest two major releases, including their most anticipated sequel bar-none in Victoria 3.

So I can see how being able to read text in a game with so much of it is somehow not a priority after an entire decade of complaints. Who has the time to make a panel fully opaque when they have more over-priced, poorly-received DLC packs to put out?

Don't even get me started with the launcher that has broke multiple games, that has just made its latest victim with Across the Obelisk, an otherwise 87% positive game currently rated at 38% because Paradox is just too greedy to ever learn their lesson.

After 1800+ hours playing Crusader Kings II, the most recent DLC and free content expansion, Conclave, has forced me to withdraw my formerly enthusiastic approval.  CKII used to be one of the premiere Grand Strategy titles available.  Sadly, over the course of several expansion/DLC releases the game has lost its way, becoming increasingly tedious and straying far from the original wonderful gameplay.

  The Conclave DLC and the accompanying free content patch was released completely unbalanced and apparently largely untested.  It caused a widespread negative reaction which forced Paradox to immediately begin work on a fix patch.  That patch, now in open beta testing, goes a long way toward fixing the worst of the problems.  Unfortunately, it doesn't go far enough.

  The root of the problem is that the entire concept of Conclave makes councils far too powerful.  The intent of Paradox seems to be to make the game more difficult and thus hinder the ability of players to "paint" the map all in the color of their empire.  The intended result was achieved.  And now the game is a mess of micromanaging council votes and council favor which detracts from the initial design concept of a fun game focused on dynasties and war in the medieval period.  Paradox might as well change the name of the game to Crusader Kings II: The Council -Hindered, Blocked and Trolled.  The game is no longer focused on dynasty and conquest and religious fervor in the medieval milieu.  Now it is just a grumpy, greedy pseudo-democracy council simulator set in a medieval era with the player forced into spending inordinate amounts of time dealing with fractious, constant council problems almost to the exclusion of everything that once made this a great game. 

  Congratulations, Paradox.  The greed pushing a need to continually release more DLC to line corporate pockets has finally sent the core game into oblivion. You succeeded in satisfying a vocal minority who wanted the game to be more difficult (with no proof that many of those who complained had even played the game beyond the Easy setting).  In return, you've so drastically altered the basic gameplay that Crusader Kings II is no longer really about Crusader Kings.  You've turned a fine Grand Strategy game set in the medieval period into something entirely different. Short of removing the Conclave DLC and the free content expansion entirely, there is no fix for this.  The game has moved too far from its original design concept, which attracted many of us to the game in the first place.  There are other better democracy simulators available.  They aren't Grand Strategy games; but neither is Crusader Kings II since the changes of the last expansion.

Update: 2023 and CK3 failed where CK2 succeeded

For those who are new to the Grand Strategy genre, the game is hopelessly complex at first glance. However, the high learning curve can be mitigated by understanding the following concepts:

1.) Family is the most important resource; more so than any single Genius/Strong/Attractive character.
2.) My character is but a tool with which to expand the power and the glory of the Family.
3.) Dying can sometimes be the best thing you can do for the Family, especially if you can take unpopular but necessary actions before kicking it.

and, most importantly;

4.) Without strict guidance (i.e. proper 'pruning' of the family tree), the other members of the family will do its utmost to screw me over, and in the process, bring our Family into ruin.

Now, extrapolate this across other Families sharing your Culture and your Religion, and you'll have an idea of how to 'win' the tutorial part of the game, and get into the actual meat of CK2, where you murder children, cuckold your allies and marry your half-sister-mother.

1,100 hours in, and a I still haven't completed a single play through. I keep getting distracted by shiny things and starting a new game! CK3 is out, but I can't see myself moving on from CK2 for another 5 years at least.

UPDATE 2: The DLC seems to be working right now. The review's score has been flipped to "recommended".

UPDATE: DO NOT BUY THIS GAME, at least its Mac version, for there is something that prevents you from using any DLC or mod you get. I repeat, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME unless you want to have non-DLC-non-mod vanilla version.

 Long story short: This is a really good game that everybody should try at least once. Welcome to the ultimate feudal simulator.

 While in many grand strategy games you control a country, raise troops and build an empire through conquest, Crusader Kings II brings on a more complex and interesting experience of country management where you will not actually control a country as a whole, but just a male or a female ruler who will have a limited authority upon the land he or she has through his/her nobility titles.

 These titles vary from being a count (a minor ruler who usually has one or two provinces) to being an emperor (who can even control kings), but each of them has it's advantages and challenges. Although there are other titles (such as Emir for moslems or Jarl for norse pagans), most of them follow the classic feudal system of Baron/Bishop/Mayor<Count<Duke<King<Emperor. There are many ways to get new titles, but the most common ones are through conquest and through inheritance.

 Laws can be changed in your domain, but your vassals have to approve them, so try to keep them happy. There're also inheritance laws, that include the way the titles will be given or if a woman can hold them or not. 

 Speaking about women, marriage plays a pretty important role, being the key to your blood line's survival. Following traditional feudal diplomacy, many alliances and agreements can be reached by marrying another character.

 Wars, crusades, rebellions and infight are not as important as in other games such as Europa Universalis IV, but every ruler will eventually have to live by the sword. Since you don't have an army of your own, you will have to ask your vassals for their leavies, that will remain loyal to you for as long as you don't overuse them. In this game, you cannot declare a war without a casus belli, so you may need to fabricate one. Crusades and Jihads are called by the Pope / Caliph, and you can choose to join them or not.

 Of course, religion has an important role in this game, so there are many religious options you can follow in order to make your religion stronger. Christians, moslems, norse, jews, suomi, zoroastrians, buddhists and many others have different religious options you can use in your benefit.

 As a whole, this game is really fun to play, and you can play it just for doing stupid things with your realm or try to go on and build a new empire. There are many choices, and there's always a new surprise waiting for you.

 The only flaw this game has, and it's a big one indeed, is that you cannot do many things (like playing moslem or pagan countries) if you don't buy the DLCs. So get your wallet ready to spend a lot of money here.

Under no circumstances should you buy this game. I have over 100+ hours on this game outside of steam, and regret even buying a copy to support the developers.

Pros
+Game is great with all the DLC

Cons
-Game is dogshit without any DLC, and incrementally gets better the more DLC you buy. There's about $100-$200 of "expansions" that add up to be worth one or two actual expansions. (Sword of Islam, Holy Fury, etc) and MANY which should be in the base game (Ruler designer, way of life, conclave, EU4 converter, all the cultural cosmetics for different factions, etc)
-In game advertisements, the game actually takes longer to start up than a pirated copy because it tries to load THREE ads on the main menu for CK3 and their monthly DLC subscription.

You should find this game by other, "free" means, it's a good game worth playing but Paradox really is greedy as hell, which fine so long as it's not a detriment to the game. The amount of content-scraping they've done with the DLC ranks just below EA/Ubisoft with how badly it negatively impacts the game for people who decide to spend money on it. Realistically, t will be almost a decade before CK3 catches up (If it ever does) so find this with all the content somewhere while you can!

This game is entirely worth the time it takes to learn it.

This game has a ton of depth and strategy to it, but the time required to learn it may be off putting. It gives you as much as you are willing to put into it. Gameplay is mostly numbers, choosing decisions, and watching the map be carved up into all different funny nations. Not the most engaging for the average person. But if this is your thing, the sheer RP potential is staggering and there are a ton of mods to enhance it. 

Now for the negative: The DLC policy. I’m no fan of the amount of DLC this game has or its pricing. Or really any paradox game, as it’s not just a CK2 issue. But I cannot deny they (usually) enhance the game to a decent degree. Plus, if you don’t want to give them a dime, vanilla is always an acceptable option as well. It’s just a pick your poison type situation. 
Still recommend this as it’s a one-of-a-kind game and the sheer insanity you or the AI can cause is simply fantastic.

[h1]Short review[/h1]

Paradox Interactive continues to quietly unfold its wargames. It has been quite a few years since the Swedish studio acquired a certain expertise in the genre. But all of that was just practice. Hearts of Iron? A draft! Europa Universalis? A sketch! Victoria? Unfinished! Back then, the learning process finally acquired something almost perfect! With Crusader Kings II, Paradox delivers its magnum opus, its grand work, the culmination of its quest for the perfect wargame.

Alright, Paradox developers can retire! In fact, if one of them was to leave today, he could do so with a sense of accomplishment. The duty that the studio has imposed on itself for a long time was to deliver the ultimate wargame to players, and that's precisely what Crusader Kings II is. There's no need to reiterate what will be said in the review; I might risk excessive use of superlatives. Just know that if you even have a slight liking for the genre, you can't afford to miss this masterpiece. All things considered, let's hope Paradox developers wait a while longer before considering retirement. I want them to continue releasing games of this caliber for a long time!

[h1]Long review[/h1]

From a historical chronology perspective, Crusader Kings II is the first among Paradox Interactive's wargames, spanning from 1066 to 1453 (from 867 with DLC). It is set just before Europa Universalis III (1453-1820 with the Napoleon's Ambition expansion), followed by Victoria II (1835-1936) and ultimately Hearts of Iron III (1936-1948). In four titles, the studio covers nearly nine centuries of European history. Such dedication is truly commendable, especially considering the established quality of the mentioned titles. However, some questions linger concerning Crusader Kings II. The game had seen only one iteration, which dates back to 2004. Moreover, its older setting, synonymous with less advanced technology, doesn't lead to a shallower gameplay, does it? Rest assured, it's not the case. There's no need for assault tanks to create a complex wargame; political and religious intrigues suffice. In fact, CKII was arguably the most ambitious game ever produced by the Swedish developer.

Ambition, you'll need it as a player as well. By having you embody a noble from Europe (or other regions with DLCs), Crusader Kings II entrusts you with the weighty task of developing your realm and, perhaps, building an empire through warfare, diplomacy, and intrigue across generations. It's worth noting that you can also start right at the top by playing as an established monarch; the task won't be any easier for that. In fact, it's often easier to begin as a small entity, gradually acquiring counties or duchies as opportunities arise. Managing an empire, on the other hand, can prove perilous, with numerous external borders to defend, peasant rebellions to suppress, and most importantly, internal divisions. It's important to remember that the grand political entities of the era exhibit only a facade of unity; in reality, they are disparate aggregates, fragmented into a multitude of provinces controlled by ambitious vassals, sometimes as powerful as their ruler. Consequently, you must contend with noble quarrels and internal power struggles, machinations, and even backstabbing. This is what gives the game its flavor.

You can access the profiles of all the game's characters to interact with them. The possibilities are numerous: you can imprison an unscrupulous conspirator exposed by your spy, bribe a neighbor to improve their opinion of you, or grant a land title to reward a deserving vassal. Let's not forget family relations: it's up to you to decide where to send a child for their education and with whom to arrange a marriage. There's nothing like a good union to secure a valuable ally; in times of conflict, your father-in-law will likely come to your aid. Each character has their own skills (stewardship, diplomacy, etc.), personality traits (humble, courageous, etc.), and, most importantly, their relationships within their lineage and alliances. Dealing with all these parameters is no small feat, but it's captivating. Playing Crusader Kings II is like donning the role of a puppeteer; you take great pleasure in pulling the strings. You sow discord between a vassal and their liege, send a fifteen-year-old cousin to marry an elderly count whose favor you seek, or even assassinate your own spouse if necessary! Machiavelli wasn't born yet, but he already had disciples.

Beside these political intrigues, war seems almost straightforward. There's certainly vigorous fighting, but it happens with rules. Yes, war had its very specific codes at the time. You couldn't just invade your neighbor because you liked their little piece of woodland! A valid casus belli, or in other words, a justifiable pretext for an attack was required. This is the role of your chancellor, who can fabricate claims by working in the shadows. Alternatively, you can target the enemies of God; no one will object if you pick a fight with a pagan Nordic kingdom or a Muslim caliphate! Religion plays a significant role in the game; you must ensure good relations with the Pope to earn piety points and perhaps request the excommunication of a nuisance... But let's get back to war. Once the casus belli is duly established or manufactured, you can raise your troops and those of your vassals, hire mercenaries if the treasury allows it, or call upon orders of warrior monks. All that's left is to march toward the enemy. Combat resolution is quite simple; apart from a few factors related to the terrain (rivers, terrain, etc.), the stronger army prevails. Nevertheless, you will need to occupy the enemy province for a certain period to eliminate all resistance. Afterward, your weakened opponent will likely offer you favorable peace terms. Now you have control of a new province and a healthy stock of prestige points, the accumulation of which is the ultimate goal.

Besides its military aspect, Crusader Kings II, like most wargames, has a management component. Laws, the economy, technological research... In this area, some players will probably lament the limited control over many factors. However, this is a deliberate choice by the developers to adhere closely to history. As mentioned before, even the mightiest emperor must negotiate with his vassals, or risk seeing his grand empire disintegrate. Thus, it is not possible to change laws or taxation without their consent, which can sometimes be challenging to obtain. The lack of direct control over these parameters, while realistic, can be frustrating initially; however, one learns to adapt. The same applies to the game's interface: it's not perfect, but you eventually get used to its minor flaws, which are not insurmountable. It's fair to say that the game is so outstanding that one is inclined to forgive all. The software is stable and smooth, which wasn't always the case with the studio's previous releases. In short, Paradox has truly outdone itself with Crusader Kings II. Every wargame enthusiast should give it a try!
Very rich game with extreme amounts of replay value. Can be difficult to learn, but highly recommend.

Pros:
Challenging Gameplay: The game remains consistently challenging, promoting strategic interactions and decisions.
Storytelling and Strategic Relationships: The gameplay mechanics encourage players to create their own stories and nurture strategic interpersonal relationships.
Detailed Medieval Simulation: The game provides a detailed simulation of medieval life, with a focus on historical accuracy and depth.
Creative Freedom: There are no crude victory conditions, and players have the freedom to set and pursue their own goals.
Unique Focus on Dynasties and Family: The gameplay heavily focuses on dynastic relationships, offering an original and entertaining experience.
Cons:
Complexity: The game can be daunting for new players due to its complexity and steep learning curve.
User Interface: The interface has been described as clumsy, which could hinder the player experience.
Underwhelming Campaign Ending: The campaign ending has been termed as disappointing, which could be unsatisfying for some players.
"Crusader Kings 2" offers a deep, strategic gameplay experience highlighted by its attention to detail and focus on dynastic and political maneuvers. Players can experience the historical challenges of medieval noble leadership and the exciting stories that unfold through their decisions. However, the learning curve and user interface could be improved to make the game more accessible, and the campaign ending could be disappointing for some players.

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

Crusader Kings II, the renowned grand strategy game from Paradox Interactive, is a tour de force in the world of historical simulations. As a long-time fan of both strategy and history, this game is nothing short of a masterpiece.

Gameplay (5/5): Crusader Kings II's gameplay revolves around the intricate management of your medieval dynasty. You play as a ruler and must ensure the survival and prosperity of your family line through generations. The depth of gameplay is astounding, from arranging marriages and alliances to plotting assassinations and waging wars. The game's clever use of character-driven mechanics, which focus on the people rather than abstract entities, sets it apart from other strategy titles. The result is a rich, dynamic, and endlessly engaging experience that unfolds differently with each playthrough.

Graphics and Sound (4/5): While Crusader Kings II might not boast cutting-edge graphics, it's worth noting that it was released in 2012, and its visuals still hold up admirably. The medieval map and character portraits are intricately detailed, and the user interface is clean and functional. The game's music and sound effects add a medieval ambience that enhances the immersive experience, even though they may not be groundbreaking.

Realism (5/5): Crusader Kings II excels in historical authenticity. It successfully captures the essence of the medieval world, replete with political intrigue, religious strife, and dynastic challenges. The simulation of medieval society, complete with the complex web of feudal relationships, is nothing short of exceptional. The game manages to make historical events, no matter how minor, feel significant in the grand tapestry of history.

Replayability (5/5): One of the game's greatest strengths is its tremendous replay value. The sheer variety of starting characters and historical bookmarks, coupled with the open-ended nature of the gameplay, means you can replay Crusader Kings II countless times and still uncover new narratives and challenges. The addition of expansions and mods further extends the game's lifespan, making it a constant favorite among the strategy gaming community.

Overall (5/5): Crusader Kings II is a classic that has stood the test of time for good reason. Its deep, character-driven gameplay, historical authenticity, and immense replayability make it an enduring gem in the strategy gaming world. While it might not boast the flashiest graphics, its substance more than compensates. If you have a penchant for history and enjoy weaving complex stories in a dynamic, ever-evolving medieval world, this game is an absolute must-play. Crusader Kings II is a grand medieval epic that deserves a place in the library of any strategy enthusiast.

Crusader Kings 2 is the first game that ever captured for me the vibe of the medieval period from a rulers role playing perspective. Backroom plots, dynastic drama and politics, alliances and crusades. Its all here, perfect for any fan of Medieval Europe's most colorful period as you lead your familial dynasty through the various periods of medieval history. The only onion in this sweet package is the amount, and cost of the DLC which for many people will be too steep. Ordinarily i wouldn't imagine dlc mattering but in this game, id argue many of the dlc are necessary to having a fulfilling experience, but this can be offset by a much cheaper (in the short term) subscription plan that will allow you to access all of the dlc. Well worth your time and effort, and although its tutorial positively sucks, the game isn't too hard to get into mechanically like some of Paradox's other games such as Europa Universallis 4.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
As a subscriber, I strongly recommend.

Crusader Kings II is a phenomenal grand strategy game developed by Paradox Interactive, which brilliantly immerses players in the complex and intriguing world of medieval politics, warfare, and dynastic struggles. With its rich historical context, deep gameplay mechanics, and engaging storytelling, this game stands as a testament to the brilliance of the genre.The level of detail and historical accuracy in Crusader Kings II is simply astounding. As you navigate through the game, you'll find yourself managing an empire filled with well-researched characters, each with their own unique personalities, desires, and ambitions. The game spans from 1066 to 1453, allowing you to experience the full range of medieval history and witness the rise and fall of great dynasties.The game's depth is truly impressive. You must carefully manage your realm's economy, engage in diplomacy, and make critical decisions about marriages, alliances, and successions. The game is far from a simple war simulation, as you'll spend much of your time carefully plotting your way to power by forging alliances, managing vassals, and navigating the treacherous landscape of medieval politics.One of the standout features of Crusader Kings II is the dynamic event system that constantly keeps you on your toes. These events add a unique flavor to the gameplay, presenting you with various dilemmas, plots, and narrative-driven choices that further immerse you in the world. This dynamic storytelling allows for an almost infinite number of unique playthroughs, ensuring that no two games are ever the same.The game also boasts a passionate and creative modding community, which has developed a wealth of additional content and enhancements that further enrich the experience. From total conversions to small quality-of-life improvements, you'll find a mod to suit your tastes and enhance your gameplay.Crusader Kings II does have a steep learning curve, which might be daunting for newcomers to the genre. However, with patience and perseverance, the game's intricacies become a rewarding experience that few other games can match.In summary, Crusader Kings II is a grand strategy masterpiece that offers a deep, immersive, and engaging experience for those willing to invest the time to master its complexities. With its rich historical context, intricate gameplay mechanics, and dynamic storytelling, it is an essential title for any strategy game enthusiast.

So you want to play Crusader Kings II in 2023? I’d say good luck my friend. The game is solid, intricate, and has a learning curve more curvy than a scimitar. 

It’s a complicated game where the game play is based on actual characters (kings, dukes, emperors, warlords etc) as opposed to collectively controlling nation states, Like in total war, EU4, Victoria II/III etc. 

This allows for a lot of unique gameplay mechanics and accomplishments that most other strategy map games lack. For example….. you can fuck the wife of any lord you dislike through enough planing and interactions. 

The game play is less “how do I conquer Europe” and more “how do I make my families lineage the most epic? How do I kill this disloyal duke without pissing everyone off? how do I get the pope to like me personally. How do I send an expedition into China to put my dynasty on their throne?” 

Now all of this is solid and super cool. The game also does have a wide array of “map painting” of you want to go the “lets create a single political European entity that just gets bigger” route. 

Now all of this can easily lead to an individual sinking hundreds, even thousands of hours into this game. Slowly getting better, unlocking more intricate strategies, and seeing the full extent of AI random event generation. But there’s a catch. You might have noticed this game is free. It’s a trick, the base game is free. 

To do 4/5th of the epic “I’m a medieval lord now bow before me!!!” Stuff you’d want to do…….. you’d have to spend $100s on DLC. Now you could wait for sales, heavily research the dlcs you want to buy, figure out what you deem the most essential…… but Paradox knows you probably won’t. 

For $5 a month you can “subscribe” to all the dlcs that make this game playable. I’d say it’s worth it as a trial run or place holder as you slowly buy the dlcs to exert full ownership of the game. 

I haven’t played the base game. (I bought it and all the dlc in 2014. But to play as Muslims (half the game rulers and a large part of the literal crusades) you need to fork over $10 for a dlc. Now not all the dlc are winners and some are more essential than others so that $5 a month might seem pretty good. 

The game (as defined as owning all dlcs or the $5 monthly subscription) is amazing. A solid 81/100

Only down sides are buggy multiplayer and occasional crashes.

Oh, Crusader Kings 2, how you stir the passions of my soul! As I delved into the intricate webs of politics and power, I couldn't help but see the divine hand at work. For what is the game's depiction of medieval Europe, if not a mirror of our own spiritual journey?

As I navigated the complex relationships between rulers and vassals, between faiths and cultures, I felt a strange sense of connection with the divine. For is not our own struggle to maintain our faith and virtue amidst the temptations of the world a reflection of the struggles of those medieval lords and ladies?

And yet, as I played on, I also couldn't help but wonder at the fickle hand of fate, which can cast down the mighty and exalt the lowly in the blink of an eye. Is this not a reminder of the ever-present hand of God, who guides and directs our lives in mysterious ways?

In the end, Crusader Kings 2 is not just a game of strategy and conquest, but a meditation on the human condition and our relationship with the divine. Play it, and you may find yourself drawn into a world of spiritual exploration and introspection that will leave you forever changed.

Crusader Kings II is a grand strategy video game developed and published by Paradox Interactive. It was released in 2012, and has since gained a dedicated following of fans. The game combines elements of empire building, warfare, and diplomacy to create a complex and engaging experience. Players take control of one of the great medieval dynasties, and attempt to expand their power, influence, and wealth over the centuries.

I have to admit, I'm not a big fan of Crusader Kings II. While I appreciate the complexity and depth of the game, I find it to be too slow and tedious. The game has a steep learning curve, and the interface can be confusing and unintuitive. Additionally, the game has a tendency to drag on for far too long, with some campaigns taking upwards of 20 hours to complete.

That said, I can appreciate the game for what it is. It provides a unique and engaging experience, and its deep and complex systems can provide hours of entertainment. If you're willing to put in the time and effort to learn the game, you'll find a rewarding and enjoyable experience.

For those looking to jump into the game, here are a few tips to help you get started. First, familiarize yourself with the game's interface and controls. Second, read up on the game's systems and mechanics to get a better understanding of how it works. Third, start off small and work your way up. Don't take on too many tasks at once, as it will be overwhelming. Finally, save your game often, so you can undo any mistakes you make.

Overall, I didn't quite enjoy Crusader Kings II as much as I thought I would. It's a complex and deep grand strategy game, but it can be slow and tedious. If you're willing to put in the time and effort to learn the game, you'll find a rewarding and enjoyable experience.

I have to admit, I've spent most of my hours on this game playing the many total conversion mods, since the Steam Workshop Community for this game (and other Paradox properties I should add) are insanely well done and full of a very supportive and hard-working creators. With that being said, my experience of the main game itself, and it's colossal library of DLC (that yes, I bought) was superb. With DLC attached, it allows you to begin anywhere on the map, any era, and you can even create your own Ruler. The game is very RNG reliant however there are many tricks of the trade you can use to really take the fun to the next level. The game's many achievements act as superb objectives for the player and contain a significant amount of challenge dependent on which you pick to go for. Overall, CK2 has brought over a thousand hours of fun and frustration that really tested my attention span. And, now that CK3 is out and CK2 has gone free to play, I don't see why anyone shouldn't give this instalment a try while Paradox spend the next few years fixing CK3 through DLC.

About two years ago, the developer Paradox decided that, after five years of being released, they were going to hike the price back up to just a bit below the price of a brand new Triple-A game. They attempted to do this not just with CKII, but for all of their other games and DLC as well. The "reason" given was "to match the purchasing power of different currencies..." or some BS. Basically, they wanted more money for an old game.

As you can imagine, this didn't go over well with the community and resulted in a slew of protest reviews which sent the trend from Very Positive to Mostly Negative. Indeed, as of 26/06/2017 the recent reviews were Mostly Negative. The community rightly drew a line in the sand. They weren't having any of it.

After this massive community revolt, the CEO of Paradox issued a statement that they would be reversing the new price changes. I felt that this statement satisfied me at the time, and my review went back to being very positive. Crusader Kings II is a great game and worthy of all the praise it gets as a game, but it was a shame that Paradox seemed so eager to burn through all the good will they'd built up over the years.

You'd think that this outcome was a good thing, but fast forward another two years and they have succeeded in pulling a bait and switch. No longer does the game and its DLC go on sale for 75% off. Now, 50% is the lowest you'll ever see it go. Basically, since they couldn't hike the base price, they decided to nerf the sales instead which achieves the same result.

To the average potential customer thinking about buying the game's DLC, the 50% off sale price should be viewed as the sticker price. Do NOT pay full price for the game and its DLC when it's not on sale.

CKII is still a great game worthy of being played but it's getting harder and harder to recommend it as the years go by. Still recommend it, but only when it's on sale. We'll see if that changes in another two years.
What CK2 lacks in stability and performance (as well as some QoL features) it makes up for in depth that CK3 is sorely lacking.

You know when you are young, full of dreams and hopes, living a simpler life, and you had a game that you always played to, relax, have fun, get mad, overcome a challenge yourself made, and you will always have a fondess towards that game?

If you like CYOA games, like Role Playng and are full of imagination. You should try this game.

If you are a sadist that want torture, imprison, commit murders, and some war crimes. You should try this game.

If you want be a noble person, had a life full of joy, friends, spouse, childs, grandchilds. You should try this game.

You know, when I initially downloaded the game, I searched up the classic Ireland noob starting guides, quickly becoming proficient enough to conquer the British isles with a mixture of classic seduction, warmongering and keen diplomacy. And for the longest time, this was how I played the game, 4 speed, waiting for my next claim to fabricate or peace treaty to expire. However, it is only after ~1000 hours of gameplay that I have come to realise the true beauty contribution of this masterpiece - that being a facilitator for the imagination. Crusader Kings 2 is one of the few games that is fleshed out enough [with DLC mostly, if you're short on cash there are numerous ways to 'acquire' these ;)] I finally find myself in a position to challenge my creative imagination in response to the many events that transpire over the course of the game. These can come in as ouvert forms such as finally completing that elusive quest for immortality, or even stealing your former rival's skull in a final act of gloating and humiliation, to the more complex narratives that construct themselves over the course of one's playtime - such as avenging the murderer of your father and eradicating his whole bloodline over the course of a few decades or centuries, or even recruiting a promising rebel leader and elevating him to rulership and seeing how he deals with the administrative challanges many rebel leaders would never think to oversee. And for that, I must wholeheartedly thank both Paradox and it's community for encouraging me to think like a child again, and create scenarios after all else has been provided for me. Additional to riveting event chains and qualilty of life decisions, the extensive modding community has only furthered my enjoyment of the game, and despite most efforts being completed in stead of the release of Crusader Kings 3, CK2 will always have a special place in my heart for its propensity to create stories, and most importantly, be an engaging map painting simulator. I've learned it's nice to slow down life every once in a while, let the game 'idle' on 2-3 speed and pay attention to the minutae that is laid out before you. This game has fomented both an interest in imaginative exercises as well as history. What more could you ask for? Definitely would recommend.

One of my favorite games of all time. Just enough complexity to keep keep things interesting on a strategic level. Where the game really shines however is in its generation of alt-historical story telling and human conflict. Your dynasty will be full of unpredictable(or in some cases, very predictable) characters who all have their own motivations and decision making abilities. The chaos that ensues as characters engage in ruthless behavior towards one another makes for a different game every time. 

On top of that, the modding community is fantastic and you can easily set up your game to be playing in a variety of universes like warhammer, lord of the rings, game of thrones etc. Performance is demanding despite the game's age due to its old engine so you will need a strong processor to play some of the more in depth mods. Mods also exist to tweak the vanilla experience by adding more historical content/accuracy, removing/adding/expanding/minimizing certain game mechanics, enhancers for performance and the list goes on. Truly one of the most replayable titles every made.

Despite Crusader Kings III now being an established release I still vastly prefer the old game. While I play primarily with the ASIOF mod, I particularly enjoy the mechanics and political thinking of the game- so will be sticking with the older version for some time yet!

I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started playing and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Youtube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my son for help, and together we spent hours playing . I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Steam has ever since brought me and my son closer again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both my son and I many happy memories.

Best Grand Strategy ever made. Has replay ability like no other. Great game if you love history and want to play as a medieval lord in the middle ages with all its harsh and cruel aspects across multiple cultures and religions all which have a unique playthrough. CO OP is a great feature that is in the game, me and my friend managed to get a playthrough with every religion that was in the game, we reformed all of them and our favorite was to always go after the Catholics and spread our pagan religion across Europe. Vikings, the Christians, and Muslims have the most features in my opinion, though there are plenty of mods that you can download for the game to add even more content to some of the dry areas which is what me and my friend did, there's even a Game of Thrones mod we took at stab at that covers all the timelines of the known George R.R Martin world and enjoyed it very much, it was like a whole new game all together. 

  Overall, no strategy game beats CK2 in my opinion, its the best game paradox ever made and I can't wait for CK3 to come to its potential. Only downside is the DLC for this game will cost you a fortune, there is an expansion subscription for $5 a month to get all DLC if you don't want to pay the hefty price, you can also wait for sales which paradox frequently has, this game has also been offered at Humble Bundle .com for $12 with all DLC.

I will start off by saying what I believe makes this game good and this is only my opinion this in no way accounts for the game as your opinion might differ. 

Please do take into account that this game is bland unless you buy the important DLCs that paradox have created for this game like the ones that change the start date and ones that add more immersive role play experience for the game that being for example the "way of life" DLC, this is because without these critical DLCs the game has little to no events that pop up and the game will feel like a drag.

Alright, now onto what I like, the review I will put out is what is good and bad about the game when you have the important DLCs that the game has available to buy, this being because the game is free so there is no need to do one without the DLC's as you can experience the game yourself and make an opinion as to whether it is worth buying the DLCs but I do recommend that if you like the game that you do go ahead and buy them. 

The good parts are that the game has flavour, you can do a lot when you have the DLC's for example you can seduce your brothers wife and have a child which you can then legitimise making him eligible to inherit your titles, this will obviously annoy your legitimate children who find it offensive that a Bastard of your dynasty has gained legitimacy over their titles but impress your mistress who is happy that you have made her child legitimate but also annoy your wife if she finds out as your will be known as an womaniser by your court and realm.

Now onto the bad side, when you do have most of the DLCs this game can get repetitive as the same events pop up over and over and you get used to these events and already know what it says and how you are going to respond without thinking too much into it, do not get me wrong this by no way makes the game boring but it does dull down the fun a bit as even when the same events pop up you still have the ability to manipulate history to your liking if you know what you are doing.  

Overall I do recommend this game as there are not many things bad about the game a part from it getting repetitive which is not really a problem as you can just come back to the game later when you are in the mood to continue playing.

Crusader Kings II is a grand strategy game.  You basically simulate running a kingdom (marrying a spouse, arranging marriages, making decisions about laws, fighting off revolts and invaders or revolting against/invading someone else, managing vassals, managing religious matters, etc...) and when you die you can continue playing as a family member/heir.

I never played Crusader Kings (the first one) so I cannot compare to the previous game.  The reason I was interested in playing this game is because you can actually play as a Muslim ruler.  As a Muslim myself I find that interesting and appealing.  From what I've seen in the game so far I like that it takes a fairly unbiased stance on Muslims.  CKII doesn't focus only on Christian lands or push them as the right or good side of anything.  However, the game mechanics are still largely skewed (even with Islamic expansions) towards a Western Christian Kingdom and Ideology.  Being that the Muslim portion is largely an expansion I understand  that and it would be a bit much to expect that the games mechanics would be altered that much to better fit an Islamic kingdom.

The game itself looks like it could be really fun to play but does require a lot of strategy to play well so it's definitely not for a casual gamer.  My biggest qualms with this game are that:

1. It is not an easy game to get into.  It has a very steep learning curve and the in-game tutorial kind of sucks.  I tried following it twice and got lost both times.  There's very little help available and there doesn't appear to be any really good, simple, getting started guides.  In fact the only real help seems to come from Youtube tutorials.  The most recommended would take several hours to fully watch.  I don't really have that much time to invest in learning a single game and since I struggle to get into it due to the difficult interface and steep learning curve it makes this very difficult to like.

2. The entire interface is difficult to see and navigate.  Maybe I'm just too old but I can barely read anything on the screen of my laptop.  I already make sure to purchase large laptops because small screens are difficult for me to see and strain my eyes but CKII even on my large screen laptop is difficult to see.  I have to really strain my eyes to read the small print and look at the tiny icons.  It seems like a poor use of space and the interface is spread out all over the place on the screen all along the top and parts of the bottom.  Yet nothing is overly obvious as to what menu/options it will pop open.  I find myself wishing there was a single pop open menu that you could navigate in smaller portions (maybe tabs?) so that the information could be presented in a larger font.

So all in all... It has some good points and looks like it could be pretty fun plus has tons of achievements (if you play in the right mode).  However, I have to give it an overall negative review because after about 5.5 hours of playing I still don't understand how to play even at a basic level.  To be blunt the learning curve is too steep for me especially since I'm not getting much enjoyment out of it as is.  Couple that with the price of the game which is pretty prohibitive (plus any expansions you may want to get) [**please note the game was not free-to-play at the time this review was written**] and the  overall result is a game I just can't recommend.

Crusader Kings 2 is the dynasty simulator. Not the best one, the dynasty simulator. There is nothing quite like it. At any specifically chosen starting date, there are over a thousand provinces, and at least five hundred playable characters. In total each starting date has ten thousand characters.

Let's do some math, if there are five hundred playable characters in each of the five main starting dates (And that's a lowball estimate) then that means that there are 2500 unique playable characters in those five combined. That's not including the fact that you can move the clock to any single date between 1066 and 1337.

In terms of map scale, CK2 is dwarfed by its sister titles Europa Universalis, Victoria, and Hearts of Iron, as the map is restricted to Europe, The Near East and North Africa, Central Asia, and India, but in terms of playable entities, Crusader Kings 2 is utterly massive and dwarfs the lot of them.

Crusader Kings 2 is so huge and gives the player so many options that in my mind it is the ultimate sand box. If you want an easy game then you can play as Charlemagne in the earliest start date, who gets his hand held by events specifically designed for him. Or you could play as a Nenets count on the tiny island of Kolguyev in modern Russia, where in order to invade anyone you need boats, but you're a technological backwater where nobody knows how to use boats. Or you could play as Genghis Khan and perform perhaps the easiest world conquest in any Paradox game by simply taking your massive unending hordes and stomping Europe into the dust.

Scale and choice are why I love Crusader Kings 2 so much. Whenever I get bored with a campaign I simply go somewhere else and have just as much fun. Mods only deepen the quicksand. It's not for everyone, no Paradox game is and that's okay, because for those who enjoy this kind of game, it's the best around.

Make money, expand coffers, weigh taxes vs expansion of the economy (likely flaw; if it were realistic it'd be the economy every time).

Battles and commanders and family mean something. A bunch of family members, that's a bunch of commanders. Also, it's rivals once your die. AI that will vie for the crown that you have, people who might end up with pieces of your kingdom as you are the eldest.

Marriage makes alliances. Betroth your under 10 year old girl (and women today think their life is SOOOO tough), plot to kill your dullard, oldest son so you don't have to play as a rube once you die, or play as a saint and realize your wife is having an affair and wants you dead.

Alright, let me spit some real game at you here. I play Crusader Kings 2 currently, I have a blast while doing so, and I have all 68 downloadable content packs for this game, acquired over the handful of years since I bought it. At the time I wrote this, I have 2,005 hours in this game, if that adds an iota of legitimacy to what I have to say here. This review isn't negative because of CK2, and I'm not bitter about the CK2 subscription model from a "I should have waited because then I would have saved money" point of view. This review is negative because of the disturbing pattern that I've noticed and thought about regarding all of Paradox Development Studio's current "grand strategy" titles (CK3, EU4, Stellaris, HOI, Imperator). This is just my perspective, and I know I will find many enemies amongst those who drank PDX's kool-aid, but I believe that what I have to say here is right and true, and all I ask is that you consider this before buying, if for nothing more than for hearing a well-informed critical perspective from the inside.

You, potential player, will find that Crusader Kings 2 seems to have a high financial barrier to entry. At the time I write this, the core, gameplay-affecting expansions cost [b]~$183 minus a 10% bundle discount[/b]. The full, [b][i]*developer-intended*[/i][/b] experience, including everything made for the game (including 2 e-books and the completely self-contained Sunset Invasion DLC), is [b]~$317 minus a 17% discount[/b]. Those price points are somewhat ludicrous, but this game is the kind I’ll still be playing 10-20 years from now. As one of those grand strategy games whose gameplay partially exists in your mind, it has the potential for that sort of soft longevity if that’s your thing.

Now, let me tell you my real beef, which is with PDX’s remarkable history of releasing DLCs that can range from competent, significant additions to unpolished or unfinished to just straight broken. Make no mistake: PDX is capable of releasing DLCs that at least seemed like it’s quality was assured by playtesters, and [b]not all DLCs come out in a bad state[/b], but any fellow CK2-heads will recall [u]Way of Life[/u]’s release (every AI took the seduction focus, so the whole world had herpes and syphilis) and [u]Conclave[/u]’s release (The threat system was unbalanced to the point where an Irish duke taking a single county would result in the Pope and the Caliph banding together to take you down a peg. The council was so overpowered that one funny review said something like [i]“tl;dr: paradox thinks there were constitutional elective monarchies in the 8th century”[/i]). Let’s not forget EU4’s [u]Common Sense[/u] and its patch (gave the AI the ability to develop provinces, but not the player unless you bought the DLC; only recently rectified), and what appears to be the case with Stellaris’s [u]Overlord[/u] (haven’t bought it, but the reviews detail a similar experience on launch of a clearly untested DLC that introduces bugs and design issues). All that is to say that there is definitely a lack of QA testing done by PDX for their DLCs. On the one hand, this makes sense. The people who made this game are in their 30s and 40s and 50s with families, kids, and mortgages. They don’t have time to play a video game for long enough to provide adequate QA suggestions, and PDX (or any company that controls a game as a service) will not pay for the QA testing required to ensure a good product because (1) their games get too big, ergo (2) to properly QA test everything to ensure a well-made product would require a robust QA department and an amount of money and time on their end that they are unwilling to spend. That would eat into the bottom line for no other purpose than to make a better game, which isn’t [i]necessarily[/i] profitable. I think you’ll find that PDX grand strategy DLCs and their accompanying patches mirror strongly the patches of League of Legends in both execution and outcome: Changes will be introduced to a game by people who don’t play said game, resulting in changes that don’t accurately reflect what the game needs to be healthy or complete, leading to the frustration of players on the ground and a loss of goodwill from cynics like me. This is the natural sacrifice of a game as a service, and you need to realize this before buying into CK2, whether monthly or wholesale: CK2 and all extant PDX grand strategy games are services whose cost for full ownership of the [b][i]*developer-intended*[/i][/b] experience is obscenely high.

I was there for Stellaris on launch day. I even pre-ordered it for the little bug guy portrait in-game. For those who can recall, 1.0 Stellaris, from a design perspective, is unrecognizable from what we have today. There are so many added and removed systems in current Stellaris that weren’t even considered before its release. This makes me question “Why?” Why would they release a game only to so radically change it down the line? Wouldn’t they have been better off taking a few years and just making one finished game? This can be a matter of perspective, though. Where some people see that and say “Well, PDX needs money to continue the development of the game,” I see that and say “I paid for a game, not a service, so I expect a complete product for my $40-$60, not a perfectly breakable platform to sell me further products.” My problem with all the PDX Dev Studio DLCs isn’t that I don’t like extra stuff being made for a game I like. It’s that there are certain features baked into the CK2 DLCs (excluding Sunset Invasion) that are arguably essential, even if some consider them to just be nice-to-haves. For instance, the Old Gods DLC is fantastic, thematic, and absolutely essential. The component I think is most essential to the DLC and ought to have been baked into the game to begin with was the pushing back of the start date from 1066 (this was way before the free Iron Century update) to 867. To me, the pushing back of the start date is literally more game that is added by just adjusting a couple of values and looking at some real life maps for reference. The analogy I came up with is that this part of Old Gods DLC and those like it (i.e., those DLCs containing non-relevant features that affect the core gameplay) are like the back door to a house you buy. Sure, the back door isn’t strictly necessary for the house to be a house, but having to specifically pay extra for it on top of the house itself is kinda sus. Why wasn’t a back door specified in the original design for the house?

In the end, I can’t recommend CK2. I can’t recommend it in good faith without informing you of the DLC practices of the company that made it. If you in the future choose to buy a PDX Development Studio grand strategy game, you should be prepared for that game to meet one of three fates: either it becomes bloated beyond belief (EU4), it becomes a complete product after almost a decade (CK2), or it will be shelved indefinitely in a somewhat polished yet undercooked and barren state (Imperator: Rome). 

TL;DR: The PDX Grand Strategy model enables the release of sub-standard games and DLCs, and you paying $5 a month (or God forbid $317) for the [b][i]*developer-intended*[/i][/b] CK2 experience after the highs and lows it has been through is an endorsement of that release practice, which I don’t think you should do. If you buy any other PDX Dev Studio title on launch day, just know you are buying into a service, not a complete game.

This game is over 10 years old and it still costs $200 ON SALE for all the DLC that make it a complete game.

214 hours for an entire dynasty play through.  It took about the first 200 years of dynasty to learn how to play the game. Very heavy learning curve that, once diligently researched, ultimately points out the "formula" for how to play this game.  I did not give up or restart my dynasty while learning because it was obvious that I could come back from bad decisions over time - unless I did something that would kill off the dynasty early on.  That's a little hard to do but it's possible if you just "poke and hope" without doing some research.

I have most DLCs - all that have decent or very good reviews.  

About half way through the life of the dynasty, things started getting pretty repetitive.  There are some intriguing aspects of this game and then there are some that become a bit boring or tedious over time.

There is more to experience, things to try differently, and different political manipulations to perfect.  

The "end game" screen gives you a bit of information about your dynasty but I wish it had much more as some of the joy of playing the game is living through each ruler's tenure.  

It's an interesting game and, as I've played over 200 hours, it's only fair to give it a thumbs up. My opinion is that it actually deserves a 3 out of 5.

Also: The inability to quit and reload WITHIN the game is absolutely moronic....

This is a good game if you have all the "expansions", however, I cannot recommend anyone who is not wealthy to buy this game because of the price tag if you want to experience the proper game: US$164.55.

To elaborate, the game is "split" into several DLCs, some of which are essential, that is, the "expansions" which unlock game content that should not be locked; and some which are not and can be ignored, such as coats of arms, models, portraits and soundtracks. So if you want to own the game with all the "expansions", that is, the game without locked content, then you have to pay US$164.55, which is too much, let alone speak of the price of owning the game with every single DLC, which is US$263.29.

The price of playing this game may not seem harsh to those who purchased the DLC over time since launch because they paid for this game over time, but to those who are new to the game and want to experience it without being locked out of important features, the game is simply unreasonably expensive, thus not a game that can be recommended in most cases as most people are not wealthy.

I really enjoy this game. I am mostly playing with mods, but the base game is solid enough that you can get a lot of enjoyment out of it.

Something “less good” is the amount of DLC that Crusader Kings 2 have. The DLC policy of Paradox is able to make their games have a long life with a lot of updates, but it also means that for newer players the amount of DLC makes it look very expensive and hard to get into. This barrier is a lot lower now that Crusader Kings 2 base game have been made free, but that hurdle is still there. However, that hurdle have been lowered even more with the release of a subscription, that I personally think is a great thing for newer players and those who have not got most of the DLC yet. It allows you to test out different DLC to see what you maybe want to get permanently.

Since Crusader Kings 2 is quite old it has gotten a lot of DLC, and some are more important than others. Conclave and Way of Life are two examples of DLC that you should get as soon as possible, while Sword of Islam and Rajas of India are examples of more niche DLC and cater more towards those that really want to play as a Muslim or as an Indian ruler. Still there are more DLC to get, there is the divisive Sunset Invasion, where some like it and other hate it, The Republic, which introduces a lot more complicated government to play, and a lot of different customization and graphical DLC that are not needed, but gives better variation between characters.

I have found a lot of entertainment in this game, and since it is free, I would recommend at least trying it to see what you think for yourself.

This game is amazing. It's fun, interesting, educational (to a degree), and it's so much fun. I love it. Otherwise, I wouldn't have spent over 500 hours playing it. Why do I not recommend it then? Because of Paradox. Possibly the most avaricious game studio ever. I bought every single major DLC (I refuse to buy unit packs or music packs, simply unnecessary). I didn't like every DLC I bought, sometimes they added features or content that I didn't like (or sometimes didn't add enough), but I wanted to support and encourage Paradox to continue to develop the game. I knowingly contributed to their greedy attitude. $15-$20 DLCs are outrageous, especially after you make your game free to play. That itself is a betrayal. Is any other Paradox game free to play now? The first Crusader Kings is still $10 on Steam. Why did you make this one free? Why did you make Crusader Kings 3 anyway? There was no reason to make another game. Paradox still pops out major DLCs for EU4, and it runs on the same engine, and it is similar in age to CK2. Then, around a year later, when they realized a money-making machine suddenly stopped making them money, and they alienated part of their fanbase by making a new game, they somehow thought that adding a SUBSCRIPTION SERVICE to a DEAD, SINGLE-PLAYER GAME was a good idea? It's rubbing salt in the wound. Hopefully some other company starts making quality grand-strategy games and will dethrone Paradox. I will never give Paradox another cent.

I recently played Crusader Kings II with two friends for the first time, and it really reminded me of why this game is fantastic. I've owned it for years, I paid for the base game before it was F2P, but I had played it the least out of all Paradox games. Moreso than other Paradox games it really writes a story for you. The best review I could write is one of those stories.

During an important battle with all three of us involved. As the Saxon, Swabian, and Bohemian armies were clashing with the Hungarian army, the Swabian duke died of cancer at 16. The marriage alliance between Bohemia and Swabia was dashed, and the Swabian army marched home, resulting in an allied defeat. Once the battered Bohemian army reached Prague, the duke of Bohemia hired mercenaries to turn the tide before the victorious Hungarians marched on the capital. However, after a mere few days the treasury was dry, and the mercenaries turned on the Bohemians, slaughtering the remnant of their army. This resulted in the Bohemians surrendering part of their treasury, causing them to go further into debt, and the heir to the duchy, to the Hungarians.

I thought its a mildly interesting story at least, and that doesn't get into any other elements of the campaign like the next Swabian duke, or the one after that (I can't quite remember) becoming the head of a Satanic cult and using unholy power to live until he was eighty, or that Swabian duke and Bohemian king becoming lovers. There's also the tale of Giselbert and his bloodline, a dwarf made Count by the king of Bohemia. There was the duke of Thuringia becoming the Kaiser of the HRE because a blessed king of Bohemia dying in a duel, the king of Saxony becoming the Kaiser and funneling the Empires funds into building a giant statue of himself in Saxony, and many others: from one campaign that hasn't yet finished.

In one game I used it to reform every pagan religion early in the game, choosing the traits I thought seemed accurate (was that added in Holy Fury? Dear friends, I am not one to write reviews, however, after 1000 hours spent playing it, i will give my honest opinion on it.

First, the good: the game has some interesting mechanics, in special the dynasty system. Managing a family was something unique to this game and got me hooked up. There are other features like assassination plots, scheming, managing the nobility so that the government goes your way etc. For all that, my thumbs up. However, I have to say, it is just not enough.

Now, the bad: combat and warfare are a disaster. You will plan, hire mercenaries, highly skilled commanders, move your troops to perfection, reach 100% score and all of a sudden see it all crumble. And that's that: You lost your war. You will loose most of your wars out of the blue. Very, very much frustrating.
                        The disease and death system of characters is a mess. Your 21 y.o. ruler will suddenly develop diarrhea or wrap himself on some lady and that's that. You are dead. Some child will take it's place and you will do it all over again. Unpredictable, unfair, and is a part of the game engineered to piss you off.
                        Do I need to mention the DLC system? Well, take a look: it is so disgustingly expensive that the producers are now charging monthly access...

Finally, with a broken heart and great sadness, I give my thumb down to Crusader Kings 2 as it is. 

If you would all allow me one final advice? Get the free version and download mods. There are plenty of it on the workshop and you might get some joy out of it. My family knows how hard I tried.

Thank you all for reading this far! Cheers!

Can't support this company anymore.I went to buy the DLC for this game off the store and noticed that on-sale their the same price as they once was before the sale.  I was expecting the price to be lower... It clicked that they raised the price in that instance before the sale to make it look like you got a bargain. 

Basically, at this pont the game is a mess with its DLC.  

Even trying to play it, if you own too much content the game just gets overcomplex, there is no simple way to play it and you dive into the deep end and hit a brick wall.  This is not the first game to do that, but this is one of the worst thus far I've come across for it.  So there is this too to deal with.  To which, the base game is pretty much all you need to work with, and you have to introduce some of the DLC slowly as you get used to it. This is different to (for example) the Sims, which even when you have the entire collection for still is relatively easy to get into.

Some of this DLC stuff is stuff that at this point should be a standard for the game, or in a C.Kings 3.  Their constantupdating makes me believe they don't want to make a CK3 and just continue to update this one, resulting in anger at their practices and the belief they are milking the game for all its worth... Which lets face it they are. But regardless, rather then upsetting customers and all that, they need to stop fiddling with this game and move on.  The continued toying with it isnt helping their reputation as a company.

Edit;
So this game isn't the only issue, theres members of the fann following who defend it, try and argue over the devs bad decisions, etc. And otherwise can be annoying.

This review is now not going to change at all, the game was not only let down by its devs, but its fans too.
