[b] [u]EDIT: [/u] I can no longer recommend this game in good faith.  [/b] I'll leave my original review, but in a recent update, they patched in a Threat mechanic, which is designed to keep extremely large, aggressive nations in check. But the implementation makes no sense, as all nations of different religions will band together to fight you if you get large enough. So Norse Finland and Hindu India can and will ally against you. It only serves to make the player's job harder.

Then in the next update, Monks and Mystics, they introduce a new "statecraft" mechanic only available to owners of that DLC that makes Threat much more managable. 

So in other words, they just made the game much harder in a way that makes no sense, then expect the players to pay to make that mechanic less of a pain. This is straight from the "how to make a predatory mobile game" handbook. Introduce pain points, then offer a paid way out of that pain point. Even if the developers didn't intend it like that, that's how it comes off. "Wait 30 years in between declaring war, or pay 14.99 to lower that wait time!" 

Nope. Can't endorse that.

Original Review: 
This is the most begrudging recommendation ever. 

The game is riddled with DLC content so you never feel like you're getting the full game. 

It's so complex that you have to spend hours on the wiki and going through tutorials just to begin playing, otherwise you're completely overwhelmed. 

The UI is a mess, they've only just recently patched it to a point it isn't hot garbage and is somewhat useable to a novice player. 

But there is something magical about having being an Irish duke trying to unite all of Ireland, marrying your son off to the 4th in succession Byzantine princess, plotting to have that princess promoted to empress, then having your successor inherit both the Irish Kingdom and the Byzantine Empire. It's a type of fun you can't have with any other game. I speak from experience.

So I recommend it for a very specific kind of video game player. One that is willing to put up with a truckload of BS just so they can pretend to rule all of Europe. And have incestuous moron babies. 

Also, they SPECIFICALLY PATCHED IN that lunatic characters will sometimes plot to kill themselves.

Possibly the best game I've ever played in my life.  Where do I start?

[url=https://kotaku.com/crusader-kings-ii-the-kotaku-re-review-1783955128]Here's pretty  eloquent review I found online.[/url]

To echo the author above:  This game is about people.  It crafts compelling and complex stories completely through emergent storytelling.  

This is a game I'd been waiting for for years without knowing it.  I like medieval stuff, roguelikes and other procedurally-generated games, strategy, RPGs, and simulations.  It's more than that, though.

This game captures so many of the defining elements of humanity completely absent from other games.  What are your goals and aspirations?  Who do you marry?  What is your family like?  What kind of legacy do you leave for your children?  The stuff (that has consumed the minds of billions of people since the dawn of history) actually matters in this game.  

Have you ever played a game and been truly and sincerely disappointed in your son?  Betrayed by your wife?  Crushed by circumstances beyond your control?  We pretend like these things aren't part of the human experience, when they are more core to human existence than any amount of power-grabbing, baddie-shooting, mushroom-eating fantasy struggles we create for ourselves in games.  

Your brother hating you can easily be the worst thing in your life in this game.  Doing something stupid or mean and offending everyone around you is a real threat, especially while you are still learning the game.  It sucks, but it happens.  That's a recurring thing in this game.  Sucky stuff happens.  Deal with it the best you can and try to live your life.  

This game still has empire-building and military strategy and all that if you want to dive into it.  You don't have to, though.  You can derp your way through life not really knowing how things work, and still have a fun time.  In fact, I miss the games where I didn't know all the tricks to secure stable holdings and manipulate the succession rules.  It is a great sandbox.  Set a goal and try to reach it.  Quit when you feel like it. 

The stories.  So many stories.  You know that thing where someone really wants to tell you about their D&D character?  I have that experience constantly with this game.   I want to talk about Martin Gabas Gabas who built an empire with nothing but a spear, outlived 6 of his 7 sons then died of old age on the battlefield.  I want tell my friends about Prusas Klakis, the faceless lunatic who passed numerous laws concerning pants and turnips, became the greatest crusader in history, and was canonized as a saint posthumously.  Those are just a two and they each have decades of successes and failures that felt compelling at the time.  Every character you play has a story that matters to you in the moment.   For me, this is another reason why CK2 beats other paradox games (Stellaris, EU4, etc.).  

Forget about any 'Deus Vult' controversy stuff.  The game is not racist nor does it promote a particular religion, but it does put you in the shoes of someone who has a distinct religion and cultural group.  It's up to you to choose how to play it.  The core game is based in medieval Europe, but you can play as a ton of religions and cultural groups.  Some might be harder than others, but they are represented with an eye towards historical accuracy more than balance.

This is a RPG disguised as a grand-strategy game. You pick a noble and work your way up from count to Emperor. I like the art which is on point compared to previous Crusader Kings 1 (that was too basic). The dialogs are interesting and the choice you make matters more than you think
It's a very unique game that makes me think about the long term consequences of any given decision.

I nearly never review games so when I do it's either really good or really bad. In this case, CK2 was really good. The complexity and historical content is like no other game. It feels like you're engraving your own mark on history and it is quite a refreshing approach to strategy games. it is extremely intimidating to new players and it takes a while to get into this game so be careful. Paradox is very money hungry with all the dlcs. I would recommend you play it while its free and then buy the dlcs when you feel ready. The dlcs add a whole new layer of content to the game and makes interactions a lot more intriguing. I do wish they would've given older players a dlc or something because they bought the game with money and now it's free just an idea to help keep the player base. The game does lack incentive to go out and take risks and challenges but I think this is just a part of CK2's charm. The game is not constantly badgering you to complete an objective. If you wanna chill and drink tea and watch Constantinople burn as a Viking King, you can or be small english count that will stop at nothing to get to England's throne. The possibilities are endless but be careful the learning curve is pretty challenging.

Yes I do.

There are very few games I've played that I am unable to complain about, but this is one of them.

Paradox has created a game that is incredibly complex, and becomes even more complex with every DLC they release. Speaking of DLCs, there are a lot, and the developers make it quite clear what it is you get with each DLC, allowing you to spend your money in a way that satisfies you rather than simply filling the pockets of developers.

Recommended DLCs: The content packs that add music and new portraits/models really add to the feel of the game. Way of Life is one of my favorite DLCs as well, adding new options for every culture. Horse Lords makes life dangerous on the Eurasian steppe, but once you get the hang of the nomadic way of life you'll find your empire growing at an unprecedented rate.

If you're looking for a deep, challenging, complex game, this is the one you're looking for. If you're looking for a game that involves battlefield tactics, though, this is not that kind of game.

Crusader kings 2 is an amazing game, but that doesn't mean you'll like it.

The good: Crusader kings is as much a story teller as it is a strategy game and the possibilities are endless. Your ruler could be incredibly pious and kind to everyone, or he could be a master seducer who leaves dozens of bastards in his wake. You could be warmongering savages bent on burning civilization to the ground, or you could build incredible centers of learning and bring in the new era centuries ahead of time. As you play, you get to know your families dynamics. You might have an erratic cousin who causes trouble, or a daughter who gets pregnant, or a son who gets killed. And how you deal with all these situations actually matters. It really has a way of making you care about the characters which just makes it all the more dramatic when they die of the plague or accidentally inherit the throne of Italy. If you don't care about the interpersonal politics, then the state politics are just as good. Dealing with insubordinate vassals, declaring wars, building up troops and crushing enemies is all very well fleshed out and dang fun to do. With so much content to play with, its damn near impossible to run out of things to do.

The bad: This game is close to 10 years old now. For its entire life it has been receiving new content updates. That by itself is great! The problem is that the devs have constantly added new mechanics on top of old mechanics. Now this isn't so much a problem for those of us who have been playing the game for years and have had time to gradually learn these new bits as they've come out. Unfortunately, for a new player, having so many things going on at once can be quite intimidating to learn. Often when trying to introduce my friends to this game, they'll lose or be unable to do something and have no idea why, usually because the answer is complex and difficult to understand at first. There is a very steep learning curve to overcome before this game can be even close to fun.

The ugly: As much as I love this game, it has a fundamental problem. As time passes in game more characters spawn in. Familys get bigger. More kingdoms form. The game gets increasingly complex.  You'll notice that after a hundred years the game will noticeably slow down, even on very high end computers. A few hundred years in and even on the max speed setting time will pass at a crawl. Now, credit where credit is due, this used to be a far far bigger problem, bordering on unplayable. The devs put a lot of work into making it better, but its still and issue. The time investment for just one game can be dozens of hours if played to completion.

The verdict: If you can get over the learning curve and you're okay with playing a bit of a slow game, then Crusader Kings has some amazing gameplay to offer.

I only bought it a while ago, so as a complete noob I just decided to play Harold II, King of England. I was under attack by two nations, Norge and the Normans. Both had much larger armies than me and were already on the island. I couldn't get enough troops to attack them so I just frustratingly managed marriages and council positions thinking how hopeless the situation was. 

It was complete chaos. I was deep in dept, thief guilds were popping up in all my holds, factions seeking to dispose me and my line rose up. It seemed England was about to collapse. When suddenly. William the Conqueror has been captured. The main (much larger than mine) force of the Normans had attacked my army while my screen was covered in marriage proposals and had somehow lost, the leader of the army (and country) was captured. 

I executed him quickly, peace was declared. With only one invader left I moved to attack Norge's troops, and beat those too. But Harold IV refused to accept my demands of gold (which I desperately needed), so the war went on for a few months until I finally got that 100% warscore and could get out of debt. Yet it was too late, a total of 4 factions were created specifically focused on disposing me. 

Panicking, I simply imprisoned everyone who joined the factions (Including my own son). Apparently making me a tyrant. The response to this was civil war. (Also I got excommunicated after telling the pope to go fuck himself.) England split into two. Thankfully the rebel half had most of their leaders imprisoned. Executing them crumbled the rebellion, and all that was left were a few holds lead by children.

Unfortunately Harold II was hit on the head while leading the armies and became incapable. Only a few days later, a few servants tried drowning him in his bath, but the guards caught them. So they tried again, and again, and again, and again (They tried drowning him, every single time.) and again until finally they did manage it and my king died. It was too late however, as the civil war had ended the very same day, and England was reunited. Harold II's son is now king, and most people hate him. But he'll manage.

This might be my favorite game of all time, if not then its at least in the top 2.  I have nearly 1800 hours of time in the game, not including the many more played offline.

It is a generally well designed strategy game where you don't play as a nation, but as a member of dynasty.  Interactions are through personal relationships which is an appropriate twist on the genre.

The replay value is immense, as there is a nearly endless combination of cultures, religions, heresies, government types... character creator, map options, randomizers...and the ability to mod...

It does take a bit of learning to get started, but once you get the basic nuances, its great.  I am still learning new techniques that are driving me to start new play throughs.

It is now free, which I think is a great way to get exposed to the richness that well made paradox games provide.

Very long term game. You can pause and save any time so you can pick it up and play for just five or ten minutes... or just binge for 5-10 hours. Very detail oriented game. Lots of little details that affect each other in an intricate web. Very cool in my opinion that you play as a ruler and not a nation. This is reinforced as a theme by the way you declare war on the opposing RULER and not their nation! 

Takes some time to learn but is incredibly rewarding when you succeed in completing a challenging objective; Whether it is an ambition, a decision, or an arbitrary goal you have created for yourself. I would recommend this game to anyone who would not be discouraged by repeated failure, and would instead learn from their mistakes.

Crusader Kings II is a deep grand strategy game that will give you hours of enjoyment provided:

1) You are patient with the learning curve, as it is steep. I truly did not feel like I understood this game until I hit the 100 hour mark, and I am honestly still learning new strategies and mechanics.

And

2) You understand that this is more of a classic RPG and not a modern action-RPG. Much of the game takes care of itself, your role is at the higher end of govenment. You role is more to guide your county, duchy, kingdom, or empire, not to run it. 

The best part about this game is easily the replay value, there is never a play-through that repeats itself. You are forced to varry your strategies each time to adapt to the new political landscape of each playthrough. If you get stuck just google, there are numerous active communities online that share strategies and offer advice and tips.

This game was a surprise addiction for me. The hook is that you have to learn a bit of real history in order to understand how to play the game. This is different than many period-piece games that simply place a common game mechanic among a historical visual theme.

The one knock that I have is the sales model that Paradox uses (with all of their games in addition to this one). You basically do not really have the full game experience unless you have many (or all) of the zillions of DLC for it. As much as I love this game, I am tempted to down-vote it in protest because I find this sales strategy so dishonest. It's basically false advertising as they are not disclosing up front the true cost of the full game experience.

I think that current law may even support the requirement that they list the true price of a game up front that is the Core Game PLUS the total cost of all DLC.

[h1]Average Score: [b]7.7/10[/b]
Personal Score: [b]A+[/b]. 

[u][i]The Veredict:[/i][/u][/h1]

The game is a really amazing and [b]addictive[/b]. Crusader Kings 2 Is a master in it’s genre. If you're looking for dinasty based management game with INTRICATE diplomacy options, this is it.

[h1]I recommend buying it IF you...[/h1]
[list]
[*]You enjoy pausable strategy game
[*]You enjoy real life historical events and maps
[*]You're looking for that dinasty centered gameplay, rather than a single character or kingdom.
[*]Enjoyed Stellaris and/or TW series, [b] but thought that the diplomacy options there were really bad[/b]
[/list]
[h1]Dont buy it if you...[/h1]
[list]
[*]Can't handle overcomplicated games
[*]Can't handle Paradox DLC policy
[*]Dislike RNG based events and unfairness in start settings
[/list]
[h1]Characteristics:[/h1]
[list]
[*]History Based
[*]Really management driven
[*]Simplistic fights if compared to general RTS or 4X games.
[*]Basically, the core mechanics of Stellaris
[*]Strategy pausable "real time" game.
[*]Game really flourishes with DLCs. Most at fair price on sale, I'll list the good ones and why.
[*]Real intricate government systems and diplomatic options.
[/list]

[i]Summary:[/i] Have you ever wanted to be a duke of some feudal county, looking forward to rise into your own kingdom and even maybe empire? Doing that through backstabbing, diplomacy, or even through martial means? Hell, buy Crusader Kings 2!
But if you do, buy it with the Way Of Life DLC. It's a [u]must.[/u]


[h1][i][b]Detailed Rating:[/b][/i][/h1]
[h1]General: [/h1]

[list][*][b]Mechanics: 9/10.[/b] : [b]The game does it's job and it is above average, but hard to learn.[/b]
Amazingly good mechanic, hard to summarize. You'll have a hard time at first, specially if you've never played anything of the sort. I recommend buying it with only [b]Way Of Life DLC[/b], than learn these mechanics. Only they, try new things, as each DLC adds a little more to the game. I bought 3 at the same time and the ammount of content and events almost doubled. Had about only two crashes.
[*][b] Graphics/Interface: 7/10.[/b]: [b]The graphics are smooth and info is well displayed on screen. You'll have some difficulties tho[/b]
I loved the interface and graphics. A lot of different map views, which can give you detailed info on every region, along with soothing graphics. Game is only complete with DLCs, regarding cultural diversity.
[*][b]Content/Surprises: 9/10.[/b] : [b] When you have some important DLCs the game has tons of content[/b]
The game is heavily based on random pop up events, along with possible actions to take. Even with a simple interaction there's so much to do, so many possibilities to try, countless dinasties, challenges, base campaigns and also you can just choose any land owner in the world and play with it in the possible starting ages.
[*][b]Lore/Story: 9/10.[/b] : [b] Historical based events, along with a completely dinamic Europe/Asia/NorthAfrica setting. Amazing[/b]
Specially with [B]Charlemagne DLC[/b], where you get the chronicle feature, where you can check your dinasty's achievmentes and other notable events that occured during that playthrough.
[*][b]Music/Sound: 7/10.[/b] : [b] Music got old quicker than Stellaris. SFX are well put, some will bother sometimes [/b]
Not much to add here. Some environment sounds that may bother you sometimes, sounds based on what tabs are you looking at, which are really pleasing and add most of the flavor to the game. Battle sounds are also pleasing, so most feedback sound is GREAT. The rating goes down because even with the context music, it still gets old quickly and does not feel well paced for the game. I'd rather listen to some podcasts or play some music of my own.
[/list]

[h1]Plus and Cons:[/h1]
[list]
[*][b]- Game is heavily dependent on DLC: 5/10.[/b]  : The DLCs are good, and all I've bought till now feel worth [b]on sale[/b], but that I'll vary from buyer to buyer.
[*][b]+ A LOT of achievements: [/b] : It's always a plus for me, but could be a minus for some achievement hunters out there, as you'll need ALL dlcs.
[*][b]-+ Game constantly changes: [/b] : Meta changes, some mechanics will be nerfed, some will be buffed, new things may be introduced.
[*][b]-+The game relies a lot on your roleplaycal[/b] : I have a blast roleplaying my characters, trying new stuff, fitting new personalities, enjoying it's events and adventures in many different ways. That gave me an amazing experience in many playthroughs.
[*][b]+ A lot of historical craziness and events that go from funny to sick as hell 7.5/10[/b]: This is a plus, I can't help it. There's nothing cooler than the aftermath of all the mess you've made on historical events. You can set events to happen on wider random spams, rather than their historical accurate date.[/list]

[h1]DLCs I recommend buying first and why:[/h1]
[*]Way Of Life: Adds focus, which is a +2,+3 buff on primary stat with some other buffs; New diplomatic options
[*]CharleMagne: Earliest starting age; Creating Kingdoms and empires; Annual chronicle, the famous "annals of history"
[*]Monks and Mystics: Societies, New orders, Relics. Another must have.
[*]Holy Fury: I haven't bought it yet, but seems to be the best received DLC yet, so it may be worth checking out.

Crusader Kings 2 is apart from Hearts of Iron 3 the hardest Paradox game I have played and never mastered. HOI3 is too complex and hard while I just lost any motivation in getting into CK2. The medieval setting could have been interesting if it had been more like EU4 where you get claims more easily and the game isn't as obsessed with titles and "legitimate" claims. Hold onto your butts because there are a lot of them. If you have not been a staunch republican before playing the game, you will be after CK2. You have to appease the most privileged kings, princes, princesses, dukes and barons and handle them in all kinds of mechanics that you will be dreaming about the French Revolution, eating baguettes and speaking French. Ça Ira! 
If you like the thought of role-playing strategy, Crusader Kings 2 is one of the better ones out there. You can get many random events and many of them are wittily written.

On marketing and financial matters, Paradox has made the base game free, but many of the game's content is hidden behind the dlc paywall. Without a sale it costs several hundreds of squids to get the full game for a game that came out in 2012. So instead of making their old dlcs cheaper, they decided to offer a 5 squid per month subscription for a game that doesn't get new updates and has desync issues in multiplayer mode. I think subscriptions are a slippery slope and many companies will probably take advantage of at the cost of their customers. Paradox are also adding launchers to their modern games that are much worse than what they had before and I don't like seeing ads for dlcs or other Paradox games in-game when I bought the base game. I can't say I'm delighted of the direction Paradox is taking.

Overall I don't recommend CK2. The only thing special about it is the role-playing strategy aspect of the game. If you are into this sort of thing, you might as well check it out. Most people will probably prefer Victoria 2 or EU4 over this though.

Let me begin by stating the following, this is not a bad game, but I feel as I have come to feel about all of the games Paradox makes, good foundations, tarnished by overwhelming amounts of DLC, leaving gaping holes that only the purchase of said DLC can fill. While I am aware of their DLC subscription service, I would argue that the implementation of such a system speaks to the larger problem. That said, CK2 is a game in which you can create and manage a level of inter-dynastic incest that the Habsburgs would find revolting, and commit horrid crimes against God and Nature, and still be named saint by the church. Meanwhile your sister comes into possession of the Necronomicon, and as King Dievas of Finland, you must have the tome for yourself and you kill your sister. If you like stories, and don't mind paying a papal tithe for at least all the major expansions, I would say go for it. Alternatively, if you plan on playing with friends, convince one of them to acquire the DLC and have them host, since in multiplayer, everyone operates off the host's content.

For all the countless hours I enjoyed this game, I cannot recommend it.

Save your DLC money and use it for Crusader Kings 3 instead, a sequel that far outclasses this graphically and with more content on launch, while keeping the same fun core mechanics and the infamous RPG RNG situations.

This game has a notoriously steep learning curve, but if you can make it through a first campaign, this will be one of the most fun games you will ever play. At its core, the game is made up of very simple mechanics that interact in complex ways (think Minecraft, but with people instead of blocks). You can ignore most of those mechanics most of the time and focus on what you want to, or you can chain them together in interesting ways. No two playthroughs could ever be the same. 1,000 hours later, I'm not even close to being done with this game.

Rating: 7/10

CK2 is a great game. It's not perfect, but it has a wealth of content and much like most Paradox grand strategy games, great replayability.

It focuses more on building your own dynasty and fame for yourself, rather than simply bulding the biggest empire - although that is certainly a valid way to go about it. Unfortunately, it is a bit limited in the roleplaying aspect by a rather limited interactions system, and by over-reliance on randomized events. While it is a lot of fun, at times, you feel like playing a slot-machine - and you, of course, lose more often than win. Considering the rest of the game suffered from this focus on interaction and events and is therefore a bit more simplistic than the other Paradox GS type games, it can be a bit shallow and frustrating to deal with at times.

Still, it is a great window into the life of a medieval ruler, and if you like this type of games, you will easily sink hundreds of hours into it, and it is still one of the best games to roleplay in Multiplayer, where the game really shines, as you can get an actual conversation with your adversaries and allies instead of the limited interactions menu. However, even in singleplayer, the game can still be a lot of fun.

The graphics are passable, given the age of the game, and the genre. Music is pretty good, ambience is as well, but some of it will become annoying pretty quickly and the ability to manage sound types and volumes is a bit limited, the game could use expanded options for audio instead of the very simple ones it has.

Also, I would recommend getting at least the DLCs that expand the roleplaying aspects, such as Conclave, but I cannot recommend the game and DLCs at full price - if you are interested, definitely wait for a discount campaign, they happen often enough.

I just do not get this game.  Every single mechanic seems to be designed to stop me actually doing anything or having any influence at all.  I can spend the entire game getting enough support to change one law.  

Playing an Earl is a waste of time unless you want to put the game on fast forward and see world events play out.  You can't actually do anything apart from maybe attack your Duke at which point you get stomped.

Playing a King feels like being in a government who privatised and now is held to ransom by unions you can't get rid of.

The whole game is an annoyance of trying to meet criteria in order to do anything which either takes an age or once you do achieve it there is no pay off as it does not affect anything.

In one game England got invaded and the King did nothing, I could not partition him to act or make alliances with others to raise a defence.  I could not partition the attacker to stop or even join them.  Spent the whole game waiting to be taken over.

You can rarely every assassinate or plot to kill any enemies as either it takes far too long or you can rarely get enough support.  You cannot do anything to free capture relatives, I can't invade the county that has them or offer the liege money to set them free.

Money is hard to come by, building and tech are a waste of time.

If you like watching different scenarios of history play out then you might like this game.  If you want war, battles, building empires then it's not.  The aim of this game seems to be nothing more than try and marry into a monarchy (if not starting as king) and then keep vassals happy.

TLDR: This is game is absolutely amazing at helping you create stories; you should play just for the kicks and giggles!
In the year 2019 A.D. I undertook the task of creating The Empire of Britannia in the 700's(Basically, the UK but like 800 years early.) 
- Started as Duke of Mercia (or 'Mercia, as any true patriot will say it.)
- Started to create the Kingdom of England.
- Random nugget head gets the title first.
- I consider invading him.
- I reconsider invading him because of his 10k stack.
- Focus on other smaller counties and create the kingdom of Wales.
- I notice that Nugget head has been losing land to vikings.
- Begins conquest of Ireland.
- Suddenly, England changes color.
- Why?
- Because the vikings got Nugget head and now they have England.
- Keep focusing on Ireland while keeping an eye on the viking threat.
- Half way through Ireland when a bunch of my dukes attack the vikings on their own.
- I applaud their bravery and then jump in with my own men.
- We claim more of England.
- I have become a virtuous paragon by this point.
- People respect me.
- I go insane from reading a book.
- I fire my son twice so my horse can be chancellor...twice.
- I keep trying to conquer England.
- I try seducing a duchess so she'll be my vassel.
- She still doesn't want to be my vassel.
- I wage more war.
- My hair-lipped, lunatic king wants his bloodline to be remembered forever.
- He finishes the conquest of England and Ireland.
- Is named "The White Knight" for his virtue and skill in battle.
- Dies 3 days later to sickness.
- Now as his son, I claim the title of Emperor and spend the next 10ish years conquering Scotland to add it to my growing empire.
- After 200 years in game, I finally look over my now complete empire and feel satisfied!
- Then something catches my eye.
- Muslim France?
- I zoom out to look at all of Europe.
- Spain is Muslim
- France/Germany is Muslim.
- Kingdom of Italy is in Poland, not in Italy (and being ruled over by Africans)
- Byzantine Empire is big and has half of Italy.
- Norway, Finland, Sweden, and Denmark are also Muslim.
- Only christian states are the papacy and some random counties in Germany/Poland area that the Muslims haven't claimed for themselves yet.
- Look back at Britannia. 
- Feels small.

This is the greatest slice of pie ever. Remember when ck2 first came out and how much it evolved shows that paradox cares. This is an RPG game disguised as a strategy. The DLCs meanwhile overpriced really pull the game together the only one that you can do without is sunset invasion but I would reccomend it if you decide to export your game over to EU4. 

This has a steep learning curve, when I first got into paradox games I had to learn off EU4 before I could event understand playing this and it sat on my shelf for a long time. Well worth learning, well worth failing, over and over.

Unlike Eu4 the host will not rehost and will usually continue in spite of you.

Even with CK3 out, you may be able to snag this and the DLC on a deal. This is a massive Game of Thrones-esque Medieval lineage simulator where you follow not an individual character, but a family line through the ages. There are immediate concerns such as income, defense and realm stability, as well as generational interests such as improvements to the domain, massive construction projects and proper breeding.

As my time invested would show, I rather enjoy this game, and as a side note, its sequel is rather promising to me.
A niche genre for some, but if you enjoy the genre, you'll probably like the game.
I played the game for somewhere around 500-700 hours before seriously investing in the DLC, mostly in the AGOT (A Game Of Thrones) mod, so while the DLC provide a lot of content, mods can more than make up the difference if you don't want to shell out a rather hefty sum.
My advice is if you are on the fence about it, the base game and mods are completely free. If you enjoy the game in its free form, you can consider if you want to pay for the DLC features, of which there are quite a lot, and subsequently the price tag for the full game is rather high, around $200-300, depending on if you get package deals or sales; prices can vary. 
If you just want to get a taste of the DLC features, the subscription feature seems nice, if you just want a taste of it. If you pay for more than just a few months though, you start having to pay a lot more than if you just bought a few DLC outright. For example, if you pay for the subscription for just over 5 years, roughly 62 months, you will have paid as much in the subscription as if you paid for all DLCs, but once that month runs out, you once again have nothing.
That being said, if you want to play the full experience for just a couple of months, or only occasionally, or want to try the full features before investing $300, the DLC subscription is a great deal.
Full disclosure, I have paid for all major content DLC, and you can see my total hours played. You can really get a lot of enjoyment for the price tag, I personally think that the amount I paid is worth it, as of the time of writing it, the game has cost me roughly $0.14 per hour played, which is a better deal than a lot of other entertainment options, but once again, you have to really like the genre to invest that amount of time in a game, so it's not the best option for people who don't love the genre to invest heavily into the game.

One of my all time favourites. CK2 truly is a fenominal and timeless game. It has everything you could wish for in a grand strategy game. Like most Paradox games it has one hell of a learning curve, but for me that's fantastic. You can play this game for a thousand hours and still learn new things, how cool is that? It also has a dark sense of humor, which is quite befitting for the Middle Ages I guess. Want to get posessed by Lucifer himself, sacrifice dwarfs and marry a horse? Sure, why not. Would you rather go wife-swapping as a Viking, kill the pope and duel your own mother into submission? Just an average day am I right.

I do have to talk about the DLC's though. Paradox's DLC policy is probably the second worst in all of Steam (the worst being Train Simulator with over 625 DLC's) Yes, you will have to destroy your life savings account to buy all the DLC because Paradox likes to get their greasy fingers all over your money. Yes, some of these DLC's should be in the base game and Sunset Invasion is basically just a meme. Luckily you can get the Steam keys relatively cheap online for a total of like $50. 

All in all I can definitely recommend CK2, in my oppinion with all DLC's it's still way better and more challenging than CK3. In my oppinion they've dumbed a lot of things down in newer titles.

Absolutely excellent game! Today, the 26th of November, I can with certainty say this is my game of the year. It has completely captivated me, so much so that I've so far spent 1560 hours playing it. And just got my 161st 'Seven Centuries' and last achievement. 

The game itself is a real time grand strategy where the focus is placed on the actual people in your kingdom, and not just warring. It has a very "Game of Thrones" element to it where to succeed you have to combine plotting, diplomacy, wars, land management (church, city, county, duchy, kingdom & empire) and execute it perfectly.

When you start, you can select to be a normal lowborn all the way up to emperor. If you select to be the Earl of a single county, you will in most cases report to your liege. You liege reports to his Duke and that Duke reports to his King. Using Marriage and other tricks you can position your family members so that at some point in the game your family inherits more land and titles. Once you have enough power you can then use war to take future land.

Overall this game has endless depth to it and many unique ways to replay it.

The game is very hard to understand at first and you will spend a lot of time on google trying to find out what you are meant to be doing, but once you grasp the methods, it really does come alive.

My only gripe with the game is the DLC is expensive for what you get. Dont buy it up front until you have played through the game enough to understand what you are getting with the DLC.

You will like this game if you enjoyed the Strategy map gameplay in Total War (not the battles) and if you liked Civilisation V. Those games are very simple and casual compared to Crusader Kings 2, so if you found those games hard or boring, then don’t bother playing Crusader Kings 2. If you don’t like slow games with 90% reading, then don’t bother buying this. Otherwise it is excellent and I'd recommend it to anyone who enjoys grand strategy games.

Crusader Kings II might be my favourite video game of all time. It's such a creative mix of strategy gaming and role-playing. In my opinion, it's much more interesting to play as a personal ruler than as an impersonal government, and that arguably raises CK2 above any other strategy game. 
The game is quite well balanced between not being too hard or too easy. After you've got a few titles and a dynasty of a decent size, you're unlikely to face a game-over, but expansion is still challenging because of lack of good CBs and abundance of defensive coalitions. 
CK2's world is also really dynamic. Huge empires can suddenly split up when a ruler dies or there is a succesful rebellion. Old alliances and rivalries may change quickly when rulers come and go. Few strategy games have such changeable worlds.
The game also has tons of great historical and fantasy content, like crusades, epidemics, churches, and witches, though much of this content requires you to buy the rather expensive DLCs.
On the negative side, I think that CK2 is a pretty luck-based game. For example, inheritance of good congenital traits, dying of disease, and avoiding hostile plots are often more about luck than skill. You can do almost everything right and still see your amazing character die of a sudden smallpox infection, and you can do almost everything wrong and still suddenly inherit the Kingdom of France. 
It's also quite frustrating that in this game that is all about royal dynasties, you often get just a minor opinion bonus for being of the same dynasty as the ruler of the neighbouring realm. At least you should always be able to ally your kinsmen, even if they are only distant cousins.
Still, CK2 is a game you can easily play for hundreds of hours. Its immersive power, depth, feudalism-based game mechanics, humour, and historical accuracy are amazing. It's a must-try for anyone interested in strategy or role-playing games or medieval history.

I don't have the most hours thrown into this game compared to many players, but by my own standard I certainly have a lot. I wish I could tell many stories about this beauty of a game, but for the sake of time I'll tell one in the world of Elder Kings (a fantastic Elder Scrolls mod).

I was but an orc boy in a small county to the north west (High Rock for you nerds). My father had died the previous year, a great warrior finally bested in a duel by a rival he had tormented over the years, his enemies took no chances to keep the great man alive. This boy the warrior's son grew in his fathers name. The boy had a mentor, age 65, the same as the one who had once taught his father. He trained and practiced, till one day he grew strong enough to rule, his mentor stood down as regent and sent forth a new era. Once a boy and now a man, he slay the traitor who murdered his father, killed the past, and took his place in the sun. Bolstering his ranks he challenged the might of the Kingdom of Daggerfall in battle, with crushing blows to the enemies flanks he made many sacrifices to the cruel gods that day. Battle after battle and war after war he conquered his enemies, until one day he had achieved his goal, he had conquered all of High Rock and ushered in the Kingdom of Orisinium, a new homeland for all orc-kin. And thus continued his bloodline following his legacy and orsimer tradition each son would challenge his father to combat, the winner would rule and the loser would die. 

And then the crazy CK2 stuff happened. One son who was quite weak killed his father who was a near indomitable force. That son then ruled and all was well for some 20 years, until he was murdered in cold blood by an assassin. Thus his son took the throne, but that son was quite weak and had no chance either, he too was assassinated. Then the next son, only three years of age, he made it but 6 months before he was assassinated as well. That son's Great-Uncle then ruled Orisinium who was promptly killed in combat. At this point the Orisinium vassals were not very content with the state of affairs at which point they removed by bloodline from the throne and placed a more stable one upon the throne. And thus my great bloodline were but mere dukes and it took many hours of gameplay before I was able to reinstate myself as the true rulers of Ork-Kin.

They have a battalion of rabid [b]Right-Wing extremist fans, now showing themselves even here to insult and harass me for speaking out,[/b] and these people show you how backwards they are with their regular insults.

The truth is that outside of the European and Indo-Aryan cultures, this game is frankly white-centric supremacist propaganda.  Africa has NO detail (and they have had more than enough opportunity to "SELL" that detail).  Black characters are not treated with unique love and admiration as the white kings are, and one of the richest men in African and frankly, WORLD history - Mansa Musa - is barely depicted as a footnote in by this overwhelmingly Eurocentric extremist company.

If Genocide of races and racist game mods are tolerated in Stellaris, and if mass-murder and outright cultural discrimination and celebrated - even encouraged - colonization of "inferior" cultures are a staple of games like Europa Universalis (itself Universal Europe - the raw definition of white supremacy) then WHAT, dare say, does a game like CKII offer?

ZERO beauty from race mixing.  ZERO celebration of diversity.  Just carbon copy, after carbon copy, of predominantly white superiors 'owning' people in shades of brown; not historically accurate in the slightest.  Some might want to make the argument that Asian cultures are overpowered, but let's be real - they're tokens, just like the Aztec Invasion DLC is a cheap shot at false representation for Latin American peoples of mixed ancestry.

In short?  This game was designed by racists, for racists.  It is absolutely despicable the lack of effort put into making African nations a playable, fun atmosphere, and the lack of effort to make them anything more than a token feature to be colonized by the Europeans to the north.

And now, yet another feature by Paradox to discriminate against people of color and those stricken with poverty has arisen.

So, as with typical Paradox Interactive fashion, they do great things and then proceed to shoot their whole foot off afterwards to balance things out.  CK3 is a really good game.   It wasn't released in the same bare boned DLC hell fashion like all their prior releases (Stellaris, EU4, HOI4, and I:R).  However, instead of just riding on their success, they decided to engage in pure greed with their subscription policy for CK2.  Hence, they shot their own foot off.

First, CK2 is the definition of DLC Hell.  All the DLC's added together for an 8 year old game is insanely high.  So, instead of doing the smart thing and lowering the prices or creating a overall bundle that is cheaper than currently buying all the DLC's, they decided on a subscription model.  This does two things:

1) It alienates people who have already bought some of the DLC's but can't afford the rest, so they are getting far less value in this subscription than someone who has never bought a single DLC for this game.  That's terrible, but #2 is far worse...
2)  It shows potential customers that they shouldn't buy Paradox's games & DLC because Paradox could just do a subscription model instead, which is cheaper overall.  That's a death knell to a company's immediate profits.

Paradox's greed has hit rank S and is even greater than EA's.  It's sad to see a company fall so far.

[h1] Incest Simulator 2.0 [/h1]

Crusader Kings II is yet another grand strategy game made by Paradox Interactive. It's set in medieval Europe, with parts of Africa, the Middle East, and India as well. You play as a ruler and attempt to make your way to the top and stay in power through intrigue, brute force, and diplomatically useful marriages. Your main goal is to keep your dynasty going, managing your families almost like chess pieces as you strategically marry people off or even give them their own provinces. You rise through the ranks the more counties you conquer, eventually going from a lowly count to an emperor with an empire spanning all of Europe. However, you can select to play as really anyone, already starting as an emperor, so long as your DLC permits it (we'll get to this later). This game is very RPG-like with a mix of strategy as you experience many scenarios ranging from being invaded to having the Black Plague at your door step. You'll find yourself assassinating rebellious dukes, being assassinated yourself, declaring holy wars, preparing invasions, and killing off entire dynasties to ensure your heir will make it to the throne of a nearby kingdom. 

You'll gain and lose traits as your rule goes onward, juggling between how much power you want to grant your vassals, and how you want to expand your kingdom. Unlike some of Paradoxes' other games, this one is very automated. You can have your vassals fight your wars for you without even controlling any units, or take over entire kingdoms through careful marriage planning alone. This isn't to say that the game is easy to understand (the tutorials are almost always useless), but once you get the hang of it you'll find yourself having a grand time. The DLCs allow you to expand your options immensely, being able to eventually play as everyone and unlock many brand new mechanics. That is the inherent problem with the game though. There are so many DLCs that many do not want to fork over the hundreds of dollars required to gain access to all the content. And it is abundantly clear that Paradox cuts off content that makes it harder for you to enjoy the game as new DLCs are released. However, the mods can make up for a lot of this, and you might be able to catch it on sale. Overall, I love this game so much that even the predatory DLC policy Paradox has can't prevent me from recommending it.

[h1] Pros: [/h1]
[list]
[*]Completely engaging gameplay that really makes you feel like a medieval ruler
[*]Fun RPG mechanics to prevent the game from getting dry
[*]Massive world for you to conquer
[*]You'll find yourself making your own stories and messing around to create interesting scenarios
[*]Every game feels different
[*]It's a lot of fun to build up your dynasty
[*]Workshop content is superb
[/list]
[h1] Cons: [/h1]
[list]
[*]Predatory and disgusting DLC policies of Paradox Interactive
[*]Hard for beginners 
[*]So much content is locked off or even taken away from you as a result of DLCs
[*]AI can act extremely strange 
[*]There does come a time where you become so powerful the game becomes monotonous
[*]No water DLC
[/list]

[b] Update 2/18/21: Paradox has recently added a subscription element to this game. I am appalled but not surprised. Instead of adjusting their DLC policies (like not making you pay 5 dollars to cut your character's hair in game), they are now setting a dangerous precedent in order to gain a "passive income". They even acknowledge they went too far with how much DLC they put in here, but are instead making you pay for it and are going to take it away if you don't constantly renew the subscription instead of adjusting prices. I can no longer in good faith recommend this game, even if it's free. [/b]

This is the most odd thing i've ever played in my life, hence the 1,000 hours. At first i was checking this out, then started to get dlc and some magic happened. I was enjoying a game about a map where you click buttons, not only enjoying but having the time of my life. I missed parties to play this, i missed graduation, damn almost sad but it baffles me how hooked i was into this apparently weird and strange game. 

I have the entire dlc collection. But i did not bought it all, i think i started when The Republic came out, and every dlc i would purchase. Most i like with the exception of Conclave and Sunset Invasion. About the game: 10/10. You won't regret this. But we must talk dlc because the barebones game is.....imagine the difference between a desert and a beach hotel. So let's get into it. 

From personal experience, this is the most addictive game you'll ever find in the world, no questions asked. But a word about dlc: Yes it is essential. And i'm sad that you are just picking it up now. I grew along with this game so it was not a thorn in my wallet. It may be in yours. In any case, if you have the money, everything is worth it, but not the songs nor Conclave. Conclave essentially makes the game harder without making it better. This is the one thing that main ruin your experience and take this game from 10/10 to a big fat 0/10. 

So what do you do in it? You roleplay as a person  (ANY PERSON IN THE MAP) and your goal? make your dynasty survive tru the middle ages. Whatever you want to do you can, it's insane the amount of stuff you can do. The amount of ppl you can be, the amount of roles you can play. If you have any semblance of imagination, you'll see your character in the flesh doing his things while only clicking buttons. Game relies heavily on your imagination and it somehow works. It like a D & D party but everything is set up. But a word: this game, like any, has rules, A BUNCH OF RULES. You will only learn by doing it, so do it. 

I recommend to anyone that has free time. Simply a masterpiece, and altho CK 3 did refine the UI, it has no content compared to CK 2. A toddler vs The Rock. I hate nostalgia dudes that say older are better but in this case, yes, older is better. 

To end this: Get most essential dlc and dive in. If you don't get 300 hours at minimum i swallow my words. This is THE GAME. 

10/10.

So I've played and enjoyed Crusader Kings II for a few years now and have invested a lot of money into this game. Unfortunately, I'm a Mac user and apparently Paradox does not care much about Mac users in general. The new Mac OS update was released in JULY (!!!) and CK2 has been incompatible with this OS and does not work AT ALL. It's mind boggling that an OS as widely used as Mac is not compatible with the game especially since this game is advertised as being compatible with the Mac OS. So the hundreds of euros I've invested into this game are now worthless because the game does not start at all. Paradox looks like is content with keeping this game broken for Mac users as it has been that way for MONTHS. It's massively disappointing but actually not surprising as we all know Paradox treats their customers like shite. I love CK2 and many Paradox games but I can no longer trust them to provide the products they advertise as shown by this debacle. If you're a Mac user I suggest you stay away before throwing your money down the drain.

Crusader Kings is hard to describe. Its a good game with a bad company in charge of it in my opinion. Now let me be clear, the developers should be applauded for this masterpiece of a game. All the people who have slaved hours and hours of their life away on this deserve so much credit. I think that it is the publishers, Paradox Interactive who is at fault since they have split up this game into multiple DLC's. That being said, I would still recommend this game. There are very few games I have played like ck2, and I think that the best way I would recommend playing this game is to focus on your characters story. Feel free to take over a country, poison your brother, take Jerusalem as a christian and then convert to the Muslim faith. Have fun in the game, since it offers a surprising amount of freedom for a game that can at times feel restrictive. For example, I joined a satanic cult (seemed like a cool thing to do at the time) and after murdering the head of the cult, I became the new leader. However I was discovered by someone in my court, and for the rest of my life, I had to bribe the pope so he wouldn't attack me. While I did this, I was constantly attacked by assassins, but luckily I had a ample supply of children to sacrifice in my place... moving away from that, have fun with the game. Now if you will excuse me, this is the fourth time I caught my wife cheating on me, and I need to have a long talk with her in the dungeon.

Crusaders Kings II is the type of game where you can commit (very) late-term abortions as well as having an homosexual affair with the pope, marry your own sibling, and put a horse as your chancellor. The randomisation makes the game a different experience every time you decide to start again. It is truly hilarious and entertaining.

The gameplay time speaks for itself. Initially got into it (many years ago) for the idea of having dynasty mechanics. Stayed for all the stories you can tell yourselves (as random events keep firing ingame) and ruthless (and sometimes gamey) diplomacy. This game filled a niche for players like me, that liked the ideas behind Total War, but wanted to focus more on the strategy layer rather than the tactics of each battle. Also, many (and some crazy) mods that take advantage of the medieval setting.
Expensive as f*** because, why not partition all the cool stuff they could have implemented at release (or at most in up to 2 major expansions) into a dozen mini-DLCs??!!

PROS:
- Too many to list. I'll just remind everyone of the amazing modding community out there. Game of Thrones, Elder Scrolls, Warcraft, Tolkien's Middle-earth, The Witcher, Warhammer and even Forgotten Realms have mods. Numerous mods that change the map, too, such as NMIH (Japan), Romance of the Three Kingdoms (China) and the wacky After the End (North America)

CONS:
- Too many DLCs (don't get the unit/song packs, edit music/songs.txt and use your own files, I know I did! Also, Sunset Invasion is just for the lolz), but you'll probably want all the rest (maybe not Rajas of India, but they always get you with the added gameplay extras for existing content)
- There should have been more deterministic mechanics and less RNG-based ones (while incompetent rulers/nobles were a real thing, you will always be plagued by the sheer percentage of useless characters generated by esentially dice-rolls. By comparison, the fixed stats physicians that were later introduced were superior in almost every aspect - hence they usually were elected as successors when there was no heir. There are other aspects: you can get lucky and convert a county to your religion in 1-2 years. Other times you can wait for decades and nothing will happen. All because you rolled dice!)
- No naval battles. It simplifies a lot of stuff, but it is ahistorical (I'm looking at you, vikings, merchant republics and the Mediterranean! Also, who the hell decided to tie river navigation to religion? Yeah, that stuff was added retroactively, alright)
- Court intrigue is minimal and there is little power dynamics inside a kingdom if you know what to do (you can literally give entire duchies to nobodies, while claimants to titles need to get lucky to be sponsored by a more powerful liege if they ever want to get something back. Also the JUST DO IT! meme for assassination plots is hilarious - intrigue is more of 1-2 time thing rather than something to focus your entire playthrough on)
- Strong dynasties never really die off in-game (the Carolingians/Karlings being a most egregious example)
- Too many things grounded in the de-jure setup (hence events to shoe-horn in interesting stuff happening. Yeah, the Mongol's success in East Europe had nothing to do with a cummulation of political, military, technological and sometimes personal factors. No, it was because God spawned them at the edge of the map with hundreds of thousands of non-reinforcing troops which they will always run out of by the time they reach Hungary! On that note, don't even get me started on how artificially the Magyars settling in Pannonia is handled... or the entire tribal to feudal transition, for that matter)
- India never really does anything interesting and is more of a memory hog if you are not looking to play/expand there (hence Rajas of India may be viewed as optional DLC)
- Rather simplistic view of medieval history of Europe (and it shows in the lacking historical research for some places) so don't expect to have an accurate representation of your particular country's history. It is a decent effort, but the fact that the CK3 map is already more detailed than the CK2 map is kind of telling.
- Even after all these DLCs, there is no fully fledged random map generator (the things you can randomize with the generator of the Holy Fury DLC is the de-jure setup. You'll still be playing in the geography of Europe, with the same cultures - though who wants to play with Italians in Tibet and West Africans in Pomerania? Thank goodness you can keep the historical culture setup)
- No real mechanics for the evolution of cultures of one into the other. The genesis of the English culture was rather logical if you look at the succession of historical events, but it is not that frequent in-game. Nor is there an alternative provided (which is why you'll get Anglo-Saxon culture a lot when converting to EU4). There is no need for an event that checks for specific conditions here, there should have been actual code here that handles these mechanics seamlessly!

Some things to note: CK2 is extremely incomplete without its DLCs and the real price you're paying for a decent medieval psychopath sim is much higher than the sticker price of the base game. The learning curve is also rather steep - 10 hours into the game and you'll likely still be scratching your head a lil trying to understand the mechanics. This game does not force progression on you, so if you have trouble staying interested in games that don't give you goals, this likely isn't for you. There's also a LOT of micro as the game progresses, although you're able to control this to some extent by just ignoring members of your court whose line you don't want to propagate. Keeping these things in mind, CK2 is a highly replayable and surprisingly deep game once you get into things. You get to screw over the Karlings, become the antichrist, restore Rome, unite India, revive dying Iranian religions... whatever you can think of, really. 

And if you're bored of all that, you can just turn the whole thing into Game of Thrones.

I discovered this game on accident after being the biggest fan of Europa Universalis III way back in the day, and at first this game threw me off a little bit. It felt odd investing so much time, money, prestige, etc. investing in counties, duchies, and even developing entire regions...just to see it all vanish from my grasp from an election that didnt go my way, or through a formerly strategic marriage producing an heir that wasnt mine, or from my chosen heirs simply dying and leaving me with no one from my dynasty left qualified to rule!

HOWEVER, after giving this game a few more tries, and no longer thinking simply in terms of "What is best for my Nation-State?" as one would in EUIII or EUIV, I began to understand that I needed to think how a true patriarch of the middle ages would think..."What is best for me, my family, and my dynasty?"...and thats where the real fun began. Years later, while still a major fan of the Europa Universalis series (as my combined many thousands of online and off-line sessions would attest to) I have realized that the Crusader Kings series is much more my style, and leaves me feeling more appreciative of the experience.

If you cannot afford to buy, or your system just cannot play CKIII, then please download CKII. Its free, its fun, and if you find the funds to get some of the expansions it just makes it so much more worth nearly any other gaming experience. Dont bother wasting money getting expansions that come and go like Destiny, which wont be around in the next 5-10 years. Instead, invest your time and effort into a real experience that will keep rewarding you time and again for as long as you would like...much like CKII did for me for nearly a solid decade after I finally purchased it.

I will never be able to recommend this game enough, but if you have the ability to do so then I highly recommend browsing all of the various Paradox studios games. They cover history, sci-fi, fantasy, etc. Games like Europa Universalis, Imperator: Rome, Hearts of Iron, Stellaris, A Game of Dwarfs, and so much more, including the newest up and comer Empire of Sin which focuses on the American Gangsters of the early 20th century! Even if Crusader Kings isnt your cup of tea, Im sure that if you enjoy strategy games of any kind, Paradox has something in mind to interest you.

Honestly, Crusader Kings 2 is one of my all-time favourite games, with over 1,200 hours played. It's got very deep gameplay, and the fact that you play as a series of characters, rather than a kingdom makes it very different from a lot of other grand strategy games, where you play as a kingdom or empire - here, you can loose your throne and become a smaller player in the kingdom you use to rule, or usurp the throne of your liege, all of which makes for interesting and unique gameplay. 

Fair warning though - it does start with a very steep learning curve, and the tutorial is not great, and can often break if an unexpected in-game event happens - honestly, I found the best way to learn was to start as a minor power in Ireland in 1066, and just try to learn by playing. 

Especially now that the base game is free, I would very strongly recommend giving it a try. The number of DLC's is a bit steep, and it may be worth going for CK3 unless you can get them in a humble bundle or similar.

CK2 is one of the most in-depth grand strategy games available, and I can testify that the gameplay handles this depth of strategy, detail, and historical "realistic-ness well." As my first Paradox grand strategy game was EU4, I found this to be much more difficult, so it is definitely for people who want a challenge and a change: you are not playing as a nation when you play this game, you are playing as a dynasty. Now with Holy Fury DLC, the publishers continue to take care of their products and the people who play them, by extension.

Edit: I still play this game now that CK3 is out, and I am glad that it is still getting attention and is not being phased out altogether. CK3 definitely progresses the series, but CK2 still has some mechanics that the newer one does not, and the religion aspect of CK2 is more balanced in my opinion.

Is Crusader Kings II worth your attention and money?

I like to think so, even though the dlc is getting a little out of hand. But if you like grand strategy it should be a must buy, regardless of the abundance of dlc. I've gotten all of them apart from Sons of Abraham and I must say they were worth every penny, though if you are just starting out with the series, I'd just recommend getting the standard version (or just try the demo). My reasoning for this is that the dlc adds to the learning curve of the game and if your new it could be a little overwhelming.

The Base Game:

So you start the game by picking a nation and family of your choice or creating one with the creator, which tends to sometimes make the game more difficult because you have no existing relations and family when you begin. Once you've chosen your nation you're thrown into the game's main screen, the map. From there almost everything will happen, so don't expect any fancy battles like in the total war series. Though CKII makes it up by putting so much thought into the strategic mode, like for instance diplomacy. It's one of the only games where I've seen diplomacy count as a valid strategy for actually winning the game.  The reason why is because your family will be the most important thing to manage in the game and one diplomatic mistake could even cost you the game and your lineage, be it to a civil war or a marriage.

I remember one multiplayer game where I was playing Lombardy and a friend of mine was trying out the vikings. He just kept harassing me which drove me to the point where I would start a plot. Plots are “diplomatic” ways of achieving something, like killing someone. (you can see where this is going). So after the millionth raid on my lands (and stealing my daughter and only heir) I started the plot to kill of their leader and I succeeded rather rapidly. My friend was left wondering who could have killed him. Now his nation was ruled by a nine year old and a douchebag uncle as his regent who wanted to kill the boy as well. I effectively knocked him out of the game with the use of “diplomacy” and greasing some palms as he tried to regain stability inside his own country.

So, is the game just a diplomatic simulator? Heck no. If you want to crush your enemies with the power of your armies, be my guest, but be wary of the unrest. Your military consists of different brigades of units who are raised in their home province. So for instance, I raise the London army and I'd get all units from the London province in a stack. You can do this for every province you own, thus raising your army. But beware of raising them to long because your vassals could get upset at you or you could go bankrupt.

And lastly, let's not forgot this one: Religion. In the base game it's pretty dull if you compare it with the dlc but it's still better then most other games. Ever wanted to set up an anti-pope, dethrone the existing pope and be the papal controller? Now you can. Or you could just ignore the church overall but beware their dangerous sting in the form of excommunication. Each religion also has their own bonuses and modifiers attached to them as well as a special something like for instance the ability to ask the pope for a crusade on your preferred target or to reform the Orthodox Christian faith.

And last but not least: The decisions! The base game has quite a few events that tend to pop up every now and again, which can make you life sweeter or a living hell. You can also, for instance, pass a no-alcohol law to boost the productivity of your people but at the same time you make them less happy. Almost every choice has a good and bad thing that'll happen. And lastly you've got the mayor decisions which are highlighted in the decisions menu, like form Great Britain with england, once you've conquered the isles.

The expansions:

Sword of Islam:
For starters it makes the Islam factions playable. Once you start a game with them you'll notice a few new things, like the decadence meter. This meter is quite important to manage unless you want a civil war to tear apart your empire. As a Muslim you'll have to manage your family very carefully since you can take up to four wives, which produces a whole lot of offspring and managing a large family is quite hard in CKII. And lastly they also added combat traits for your generals, like an extra bonus to hill defense or he might be a good infantry leader, which opens up a whole new level of military strategy in the game.

Legacy of Rome:
A must buy if you love roman/byzantine history. This expansion has a mayor focus on the Byzantine empire but changes a few base things as well. You can now have factions within your nation, like the court faction or the religious faction. These factions represent different aspects of your civilization and they all like and hate different things, so I usually end up trying to balance favor between the factions as to anger none. Secondly you've got the addition of standing armies, which are armies that don't need to be disbanded in times of peace. This is quite handy if you get surprise attacked, but I find them less useful then just your normal army, because eventually the standing armies will get too small and insignificant to matter, even though they grow throughout the game. But my most liked feature of this expansion is the possibility to re-create the roman empire in all it's glory. Imagine the glory...

Sunset Invasion:
Not much to say about this one... If you like alternate history it's a must-buy. The expansions is centered around the Aztec empire invading Europe, instead of the other way around, which usually provides some interesting and hilarious scenarios. Like for instance The Isles being taken by the Aztecs and them building a giant temple on the banks of the Thames after sacrificing most of it's people. It's also quite challenging to try and beat them back because they have gargantuan armies, so if you like a challenge, you should get this dlc as well.

The Republic:
Ah the republic... I had some great times with this one. The republic adds the trading civilizations as playable nations, like Venice, Genoa and The Hansa. Your task here is to accumulate the most money possible by building trading posts all around Europe and trying to stay the dominant family within your nation. There will be elections, feuds and wars between the traders to be able to establish the greatest trade empire there ever was and ofcourse don't forget the counts, dukes and kings around you trying to snatch your gold away. 

The Old Gods:
This expansion is centered around the viking raiders but it also makes every pagan playable (including the Mongols and Aztecs) and the Zoroastrians. In this expansions they also added a new date to start from to the game: 867 AD, which is a whole lot earlier then the base game. As a viking you'll be able to plunder cities without any mayor reprimand from the nation you're pillaging, since it counts as a temporary war or you could call for an invasion against a nation which, over time, bolsters the amount of troops you can muster. But if that wasn't enough and you'd like a challenge, try playing the Zoroastrian faction and rebuilding the old faith.

So this was my review and thoughts on CKII and it's dlc, I hope you enjoyed it!

This game sat in my library for about two years because I couldn't figure out how to play it. I thought that because I was good at Empire: Total War (a game I completely despise now) I could play CKII. However, I found myself unable to comprehend that I needed a justification to go to war and that my treasurey wasn't infinite. It stayed with forty minutes of playtime until I wanted to play it again after constantly seeing its rave reviews. I watched seven and a half hours of a tutorial series and eagerly started to play. All of a sudden, it seemed so easy to get a justification for war and manage my realm. This is the epitome of a grand strategy game. It is so immersive yet so expansive. As I write, I'm blowing off studying for an economics final to watch tutorials for other Paradox games. You can easily lose yourself in CKII; I racked up these 112 hours in the last two months. For those of you who have no experience with Paradox games, it is a must to watch tutorials, or else you'll be lost. This game requires that you commit to understanding it, but will in turn deliver one of the best grand strategy games of all time. 
10/10 would get a B in Econ again

Slaughter, Maim, Marry, Plot, this game is basically darwinism boiled down into a few buttons. 

You will find moments in this game where your nobles and vassals are absolutely bonkers, and you wonder why you even bother bailing and ransoming them out of prison when they somehow manage to get captured by raiders coming from the east. 

You will spend HOURS on this game, sometimes entire days building up intrigue and a dynasty to span the ages, but keep in mind. Your wallet will build up dust, as you realize you have spent over one hundred to two hundred dollars financing what is really just a glorified torture simulator with extra steps. You will cry, break, or suffer anxiety listening to the thousands of unique death noises as each and every one of your nobles, family, and friends all die horrible deaths.

Come for the strategy,
stay for the story,
quit when the same old shady elusive shadow schemer keeps plotting your death, even after you've awarded him nearly every duchy, county, or special title in your demense.

This is tough... This is a great game, really fantastic. But it's frigging impenetrable. 30 hours put into it, and I still don't [i]really[/i] know what I'm doing. I know, git gud, right? Right. So I've been watching hours long youtube videos, I've been reading articles on train rides, I've been banging on the door, but nothing's letting me in.

I've played this game in two chunks, and I know that, last time I played it, I did get on top of it somewhat and was successfully developing my dynasty.. but whatever I cotton'd on to that time, I've lost it this time. Mumu? Starting isle? I only own one province and my starting levies are a pea compared to the scottish raiders who mount Ireland from the first damn turn. India? Start on present day Sri Lanka trying to capture the sub continent? Too bad, you'll have a warning that you'll lose land on death, your inheritance options are all locked out, and nobody on the interweb has a suggestion for you. They all just say "change your inheritance laws".

I've been debating how to review this game. I love this game. The time I've spent failing at it has been engrossing as hell, and I love the historical orgasm that it is... I've bought DLC with stars in my eyes, I've started new families with complex plans... but for real, it's just too much.

Unless you want to study like a demon and get on top of this game, it's a waste of money, and if possible you'd probably get more fun out of playing Empire: Total War. I know, elitists will tell me to git gud, but I tried as hard as anyone and this game just hasn't shown me anything.

Rating: 7/10. Amazing game, impenetrable gameplay severely hamstrings it.

Although CK3 has come out, I still keep returning to this one. Although CK3 adds a lot more in gameplay, CK2 is the premier for mods at the moment...it's also adds a lot more nuance to the rulers, allowing them to change over time, either for the worse or for the better.

I may just be making excuses for why I've played this so much. Send help.

Crusader Kings 2 has a lot of depth but it is also suffering from a steep learning curve and what used to be a high price of admission.

Paradox Interactive, the swedish company behind crusader kings has a monetization scheme/system that has them release games where a lot of content is created long after launch in DLC's. Some of these DLC's are well worth your money but most are not, the asking price is just too high sometimes.

Crusader Kings 2 is a game about living through a family/bloodline in the early medieval period anywhere in the 'old world' from europe to north africa to india and the steppes. You attempt to lead this family and the nation/area they control through successful generations through the centuries. The attempt will often fail, as random events or history has a way of keeping you from world domination. This game unlike EU4 and HOI4 is less about the attempt to make your country as powerful as possible and more about seeing what happens. 

Its the journey more than the destination kinda game. The interface and many mechanics leaves me to not recommend this to anyone but the sweatiest of people. Also there is a new crusader kings out now, which might be easier to pick up however I have not played it so I can't say for sure.

If you have many many hours to waste and love family drama shows set in the middle ages then this might be the roleplaying game for you. Otherwise it might be one to skip.

Worth every penny.

Crusader Kings II is a complex medieval dynasty sim. You play as the head of a family managing its holdings, vassals, relatives, the expectations of your suzerain, and anyone (else) trying to kill you. The game is like a lot of Paradox Interactive strategy games, in that it's something of a sandbox where you generally set your own goals. Many of the achievements offer goals to shoot for if you need a little more structure in your life.

Crusader Kings III is out now, so you may want to give this a pass and jump straight into that one, but Paradox has made the base Crusader Kings II game free-to-play, and it was good enough to warrant about 7 years worth of regular DLC. So.... maybe try this out before buying the other one? I'm not sure why I bothered writing a review at this point in time.

There were lots of things I turned to google to try and find out and some of those things I couldn't find an answer to.

An example of one such thing is this: I was playing as Rurik Rurikid and was putting raiders on my ship that I started the game with and sending them away to raid. An enemy ship destroyed my viking ship after about 40-50 years of doing this and I was completely unable to make more ships or even find out HOW to make more ships. I had two fully filled boxes in shipbuilding in the tech tree and a port. My fleet levies were greyed out at 0/0. I couldn't for the life of me figure out how to fix this. Google said something along the lines of, "fleet levies fill over time". Well let me tell you, they certainly didn't seem to be filling from where I was sitting!
