ncest (/ˈɪnsɛst/ IN-sest) is human sexual activity between family members or close relatives.[1][2] This typically includes sexual activity between people in consanguinity (blood relations), and sometimes those related by affinity (marriage or stepfamily), adoption, clan, or lineage.

The incest taboo is one of the most widespread of all cultural taboos, both in present and in past societies.[3] Most modern societies have laws regarding incest or social restrictions on closely consanguineous marriages.[3] In societies where it is illegal, consensual adult incest is seen by some as a victimless crime.[4][5] Some cultures extend the incest taboo to relatives with no consanguinity such as milk-siblings, step-siblings, and adoptive siblings, albeit sometimes with less intensity.[6][7] Third-degree relatives (such as half-aunt, half-nephew, first cousin) on average have 12.5% common genetic heritage, and sexual relations between them are viewed differently in various cultures, from being discouraged to being socially acceptable.[8] Children of incestuous relationships have been regarded as illegitimate, and are still so regarded in some societies today. In most cases, the parents did not have the option to marry to remove that status, as incestuous marriages were, and are, normally also prohibited.

A common justification for prohibiting incest is avoiding inbreeding: a collection of genetic disorders suffered by the children of parents with a close genetic relationship.[9] Such children are at greater risk for congenital disorders, death, and developmental and physical disability, and that risk is proportional to their parents' coefficient of relationship—a measure of how closely the parents are related genetically.[9][10] But cultural anthropologists have noted that inbreeding avoidance cannot form the sole basis for the incest taboo because the boundaries of the incest prohibition vary widely between cultures, and not necessarily in ways that maximize the avoidance of inbreeding.[9][11][12][13]

In some societies, such as those of Ancient Egypt, brother–sister, father–daughter, mother–son, cousin–cousin, aunt–nephew, uncle–niece, and other combinations of relations within a royal family were married as a means of perpetuating the royal lineage.[14][15] Some societies, such as the Balinese[16] and some Inuit tribes,[17] have different views about what constitutes illegal or immoral incest. However, sexual relations with a first-degree relative (meaning a parent or child) are almost universally forbidden.[18]

Pros:
- Greatest grand strategy game ever made.
- The politics and personal stories actually manage to stay interesting after absurd amounts of gameplay.
- A massive number of starting points across nations and time, each representing a unique part of history, making it amazingly replayable.
- Massive amount of DLC, much of it high quality, adding even more to the depth of the game.

Cons:
- Hard to avoid micromanaging at larger empire sizes, making the late game slow at times.  Power through!
- The bug where defensive pacts break down when you close and restart the game.  I don't want to exploit it, so I rarely close them game (hence the 7597 hours of gameplay).

If you're even remotely considering this game, just go ahead and buy it.  Or CK3- sounds like it's excellent as well (just finishing my current campaign before trying it).

CK2 is a game where you are never safe. You can build up a giant empire ruling the whole known world only for your trusted councillor to murder you while you sleep. Managing your realm brings huge opportunities for role-playing as the game is completely open-ended. Choose your own goals, make your plans, and try not to watch them crumble around you.
Or you could just murder as many people as possible. It's up to you.

The game is surprisingly accessable and has great longevity. I often look up historical empires and try to recreate even if they are way out of the time frame; roleplay a count who has decided to live out an ancient destiny.

This has also taught me more about history (through research) than my actual history lessons at school so 10/10 for that too.

The great 'paradox' here is that a game that is based on a great level of details, is made borderline unplayable due to its lack of attention to...details!

It is, in theory, an amazingly deep game based on a level of historical facts that are rarely seen in any video games. But sadly, as soon as you start playing it, it just becomes a big blurry mess in which you are left guessing what exactly is going on?! And when you do figure out most of it, you just realize how random and boring this game actually is.

A great idea for a deep realistic historical game, but which is completely messed-up by an impressive lack of direction, information, and organization. And it is now more than time that we start giving them some thumbs-down, as trying to reward a good 'intent' does not excuse, nor fixes, such a poor execution.

It feels like mad scientists with very weird, complex, and confused brains created a game filled with spectacular data, but which sadly ends-up to be just a blurry mess without any true guidance or structure. 

Have you ever sat in your Doctor's office listening to him explaining you something with very sophisticated words and going: "Wow! That seems to be based on lots of knowledge...Just sad I have no clue what he is trying to tell me here?!" Well, that's exactly the experience many have while playing a Paradox game!

...At least they've got their name right!

*Original 2013* If you are a fan of the Civ series (as I was) this will forever ruin that series for you.  The game has so much depth that I continue to discover new strategies and new methods with every game I play.  WIth the inclusion of the Ironman mode and Steam achievements (taken from Paradox's other great strategy game, Europa Universalis IV) there is even more to strive for.  Paradox has impressed me so much over the last two years that I consider them the flagship for strategy games in our time.  Cannot highly recommend enough!  **Word of caution** This game has a STEEP learning curve.  It does not hold you hand and just throws you into medieval Europe to fight for your own.  Do not let this turn you off.  Watch videos and read the forums, there is a great community out there waiting to welcome you into the fold.  Also this game is hardly about WINNING than it is SURVIVING.  You will lose.  Its part of what makes the game great.  One wrong decision will ruin you and that is what I crave in a strategy game.
DON'T LISTEN TO THE MOB! PARADOX IS STILL THE BEST GRAND STRATEGY COMPANY OUT THERE!

An absolute gem of a game--but watch the DLC costs!
Ever fancy yourself the benevolent leader of a nation in the Middle Ages? Do you like intrigue & role-playing a multitude of characters over several hundred years while painting maps in your nation's color and working to put your dynasty in charge of the world? Does the ability to randomly slaughter innocents because they might eventually have a claim on some of your land motivate you? Then CK2 is for you!

Seriously, the game is terrific, and has been lovingly cared after by the developers in its 8 1/2 years since release.
Not every decision has been perfect, and the game isn't for everyone (I'd liken it to a strategic Dungeons & Dragons w/o magic), but the product today is pretty good and FREE.

That being said, once you play, you'll be enticed by the DLC, of which there are TONS in 3 categories: Great near-needed expansions, art & music changes, and expansions that are only of interest after you've mastered & bored of the game.
The first type is expensive but regular sales make them worthwhile if you can catch them. The second are ok if you want some extra flavor in the game. The third...well, you'd really best be a diehard CK2 fan before you even consider them.

As a note, I show as 900 hours played, but have played hundreds of hours offline as well; I really love this game and the multitude of playthrough options available.

Crusader Kings 2 might be the most open-ended, immersive gaming experience I've ever had. I'm 350+ hours in and I still do something new every time I play. You have 700 years of history and three continents in which to do whatever you could possibly want--discover that earth orbits the sun centuries before Copernicus, lead epic holy wars and trade expeditions, and scheme your way from a no-name count to an emperor. Or just throw epic parties that are the envy of the realm and sire twelve bastard children. Plus, every time a character dies, you essentially get to start all over again as a child or sibling with completely different personality traits and talents. Each DLC adds a lot, but none are indispensable, so even the free vanilla version is still great fun.

Pros
+ Game is complex, dynamic and every playthrough will be different enough to keep it interesting.
+ Learning the game is fun and rewarding when you know what to do and when.
+ You can have a horse as a council member and rule the largest empire the world has ever seen.
+ RPG mechanics, play the character however you like.
+ Unlike no other game out there on the market.

Cons
- Game is hard to learn at first, costs a lot to buy the base game and all of the dlc.
- The performance can be bad, even with good hardware, be sure to turn off auto messages later in your playthrough.
- RNG mechanics that kill your character from nowhere with a coinflip.
- Forced autosave system when you play ironman, you can't make more saves in one playthrough and load as you wish. Ironman is required to earn steam achievements but disables loading saves. It's a singeplayer game so it's like why?
- Random peasants with no military training and equipment in a local county declare war against an emperor with the best military and units, yes. Random raiders will constantly be in your realm and raid, there is no way to avoid it other than to give them land which doesn't make sense.

Crusader Kings 2 has a steep learning curve. When you first jump into the game, you'll feel lost, and while there is a tutorial, it is so obvious that there is more to the game that at every point for the first few sessions, you will feel a sense of wonder at all of the things the game is capable of.

Don't worry though, the game teaches slowly, and you will rarely feel at a loss for what to do. It's a hybrid RPG/Grand Strategy title, and is a great game with or without the DLC.  If you've ever played a Paradox Grand Strategy game (e.g. HoI/Stellaris/etc), at the time of writing, CK2 is the one I would recommend. It's the deepest, it tells the best stories, and it has the best mods.

Crusader Kings 2 is a game that deserves all the praise it has ever received, even though, as is usually the case with Paradox games, there are some rather noticeable problems with it.


Pros: -An insanely choice of playable characters and nations, including everything from the most insignificant county ruled by one of the last members of a dying dynasty, to the powerful head of a dynasty that rules over multiple kingdoms, to the powerful Emperors of the HRE, Eastern Rome, and the muslim caliphates
-The ability to rewrite history and change the face of Europe for centuries to come in the 1066 start date
-Decision between trying to survive the wars of the large Empires as a smaller realm or playing as one of those Empires to experience the hilarious snowball effect one can have when playing an Empire with any amount of potential troops ranging between 45k and 100k in the 1337 start date
-Multiple other, but less exciting start dates are also available between 1066 and 1337

(All pros mentioned are ones that can be found in the base game without any DLC)

Cons: -Only Christian Rulers are playable in the base game
-Only three base game character portraits are available (which are all hideously ugly to look at), one for all Europeans, one for Africans (which can only be seen in-game if the free african portrait pack is activated), and one for everyone else

I've waited, but now is the time - CK2 is dead, long live CK2. Don't buy CK3, wait for a sale and buy the Royal Collection of CK2 instead, with all expansions. That way, you'll have access to a huge (and still growing) library of workshop mods while taking a step away from Paradox's insane DLC whack-a-mole.

My 800+ hours are just hours on Steam, I've played the game thousands more outside of Steam. I would describe this as turtles, all the way down - there is no end (not one you'll live long enough to experience, at least) to the possibilities unlocked by this masterpiece. Whatever limits Paradox have left in the game, the modding community have stretched to well beyond MY wildest imagination. Stellaris, for instance, started as a CK2 "total conversion" mod. One of the better mods out there is the Game of Thrones mod, which lets you "fix" things - no Red Wedding for me, no sirree.

I will not be buying anything for CK3 until CK3 is similarly dead, to avoid being stuck in the DLC rat-race as I have been with CK2. The primary reason I will (probably) buy CK3 is that it's likely to be better able to make the best use of higher resolutions. CK2 doesn't have (at least that I've managed to find) interface scaling, for instance. But as a game, I doubt I will ever see a reason to move away from CK2.

It’s a good game and it´s free. If you haven´t played Crusader King II and is a fan of the grand strategy genre, you should try it now. If you sign up for their newsletter, you get one of the expansions "The Old Gods" for free. 

The base game is a good start in order to get a grasp of the game. If you enjoy yourself, consider getting some expansions for the game. They expand the games in many different ways, but some of them are more essential than others. Do some research for which expansion to get. Grab them on a sale, since it can get really expensive, really fast. Hopefully they release a "complete edition" for a reasonable price, now that Crusader Kings III is coming.  

Overall, it´s a good game that´s worth your time if you are a fan of the grand strategy genre, or a fan of some other games from Paradox. The DLC can get expensive, and some of it really should have been free updates instead of DLC, but they are mostly good and will expand your time in the game. Get the best ones when they’re on sale.

It's hard to get into and learn, but once you do you get hooked on this game like no tomorrow. My favorite parts are the more narrative-driven events and actions and the overall complexities of having to manage both foreign and domestic affairs/political meddling. There's a nice amount of customization if you're like me and want to create a whole new lineage instead of playing off some random guys in history. 
The game can play very differently depending on who you are and how powerful you get. If you first start out as a count/duke, your gameplay revolves mainly around conquering new lands yourself and protecting you and your family from ambitious rivals looking to steal your titles-- not to mention other foreign rulers looking at your lands with a hungry eye. As you work your way up to king, your general gist is the same but this time you get an advisor spot and politics, I feel, are at their highest point with kingdoms. A lot of my Kingdom-title gameplay is bribing, murdering, cajoling, and what have you. 
Empires are where the focus shifts. Once you get a good, sizable empire going with a few or more powerful Kingdoms, you don't have to do much conquering yourself anymore. If you allow external vassal wars only, your powerful king/queen vassals will wage war on foreigners by their own accords for their own kingdom, expanding your empire all the same. 
Politics get easy by this point (If you have started from Count/Duke) because at this point you have a slew of prestige and vassal opinion bonuses from artifacts, Dynasty prestige, titular holdings, and whatever else. You start making enough money to win entire Crusades off of mercenaries. Succession cease to become a worry because your dynasty now holds 4 separate kingdom titles plus an Empire with 60 living members and plenty of heirs. If you choose Imperial Elective, too, you can literally pick and choose your heir. Rigging the elections are not hard once you have gold flowing out your ass and a lot of stacking effects-- and that's just western Europe Christendom playthrough: you can play as a Swede Viking that's way more focused on combat with fuck all to politics, or a nomad that says 'Fuck politics' even harder. Maybe be a merchant prince and deal entirely with politics and money. There's a lot of opportunities for this game, and I have barely scratched starting outside of the British Isles / Ireland, and I'm almost at 600 hours with this game.
 A few things are a bit silly, like empire-tier titles not being able to usurp kingdom/empire tier titles so you end up with a foreign kingdom that's 99% under your control but making you go over vassal limit because you can't give all the dukes/duchess' their de jure ruler, just making the whole thing a fustercluck, or the ungodly RNG system that comes whenever you want to do a duel. 
Besides those and a relatively minor few other things, this game is fantastic and will steal hours from you. Looking forward to CK3.

The game looks like it could be fun but the idea that it might get fun after spending more money that I already regret spending is not an enticing deal. This game is a prime example of how not to make a paid DLC policy and how poorly it ages as time goes on where a loyal fan base might be willing to drop $5 more dollars on the game they already spent $50 on over the past 5 years, but as someone who's first introduction is essentially a demand for $30 more bucks after already spending $12 on a very disappointing game, this is not going to sit well with anyone like me who is not already a fan. 2/10, I am guessing would be good if your willing to drop the cash but otherwise I would recommend you stay away.

Fun once you figure it out. I've played for 44 hours. I've spent as long or even longer trying to learn the game. Arumba's videos on youtube help, but this game requires a lot of patience and trial and error. This game will definitely frustrate you - be warned.

For instance, I played an entire afternoon as the Ottoman Empire, just trying to learn more about the game, etc. As I was probably about 7 hours in and really making progress, a faction finally manages to force "gavelkind sucession" on me by giving me an ultimatum. Immediately after this change, the game tells me my character has died at age 44 from "depression" (ha, a little too on the nose there perhaps), and everything I worked for got split up among my descendants. I was left with a single holding with no power and the new character I would be playing as was a "homosexual," meaning I was probably going to struggle generating offspring (note: no judgment from me there, but it was a nice additional detail to the whole scale destruction of my empire).

If this sounds like 'fun' to you, you will enjoy this game. I doubt there's anything quite like it.

The mods definitely add a lot to this game. If you like playing as a dragon-king in Faerun, a lord of Westeros, a post-apocalyptic feudal bureaucrat in America, or if you think you'll just enjoy life as a midieval lord Europe, this game is definitely worth its dollar value. The mods provide a huge, huge amount of content and I really cannot understate that. (Also you definitely should get the Performance ++ [by Trexeth] mod if you're going to be picking up this game, it makes the late game not bog down and it's VITAL).

Admittedly, the learning curve was STEEP. Steeper than for other paradox titles I play (EUIV, Stellaris), but it isn't unlearnable. I was initially really struggling with the game, and stopped playing for quite some time, but upon picking it up again after coming upon the Faerun mod, I'm hooked. Some tutorials and just messing around in game was enough to build up a skill where now I feel fairly competent against the AI.

My sister and I are 100 years into a multiplayer game that we've only been playing for only 2 days, and I'd say she has a pretty solid grasp on how to play the game now and she's never played any Paradox titles before at all, let alone any strategy games, so it can't be THAT hard, it only took her 2 days of playing to figure it out after all. There are some good tutorials out there on youtube, they helped me a lot. And ultimately, the game isn't really about winning so much as it is about building up a story, living the life of your characters, following a dynasty through the ages and trying to not go extinct as a family line. It's about the journey less than the end, there really isn't any win condition to the game, there are achievements and there are obstacles, yes, but it's a sandbox.

The DLC is a mixed bag, some of it is very good, others are really niche or just plain unnecessary. The only 'vital' one I'd say is the one with the character designer. Don't buy it if you don't think you'll use it, as a general rule.

Absolutely excellent game and extremely replayable. 
No two playthroughs are the same, and as long as you ask for it, each new game you start is full of new events, characters, and locations to spice up the game and keep you addicted for hours. 
Crusader Kings has a unique game mechanic, (that I love) which is that you have to keep your dynasty alive. In other words, your family. Without at least one character in your dynasty alive, you lose the game. This can lead to many bizarre, great, and hilarious events that you look back on in glee majority of the time. Because as easily as growing your family can be boons to your success, it can just as easily lead to your current characters downfall. 
Going through incredibly accurate European medieval history, and then changing it and transforming the borders to your hearts content, is one of this game's selling points and one of its best features. 
You feel like you are a part of history. Like you are making an impact to the very world around you. 
The only downside I found (like many paradox games) is that to fully immerse yourself and enjoy the game to its best abilities, you need to purchase a fair amount of DLC. Less you miss out on playing a wide variety of characters, in unique and interesting starting locations. 
Otherwise, if you a fan of paradox games, not afraid of spending a bit of money, are a history buff, or just enjoy strategy games and potentially growing a continental spanning empire with the added twist of murder plots and supernatural events, I would say Crusader Kings II is for you.

Brought the Pope to my satanic torture dungeon, he enjoyed himself and we became close friends. It was a good time.

In all seriousness, this is a long and engrossing game that has a pretty steep learning curve. The amount of menus and mechanics are very daunting at first, but once you have a solid grasp of them the game really starts to open up. Crusader Kings II is a strategy game that is not solely about your empire and production, but instead your family and the legacy they leave behind. Marrying off children and relatives for political alliances and future claims are all just a part of a game where the test is not just to win, but to survive. This game is what you make it. Whether being a simple count in the heart of England, a fierce chieftain in Scandinavia, or the Exalted Emperor of the world, this game offers incredible replayability. Also, there's a lot of DLCs, like all Paradox games, but I only consider a handful necessary.

CK2 is a mix of strategy, war simulation, and life simulation. As you can probably tell from the high number of hours played by many reviewers, its fans really like it. There are tons of mods. My favorite are probably the total conversion mods, which dramatically change the setting and can allow you to play the game in lots of famous fictional worlds. There are also some great mods that can give you an "enhanced vanilla" experience. Some of my friends have said that they felt intimidated by this game and its learning curve. Honestly, I don't remember how bad it was, but it's pretty straightforward once you get the hang of it. I'd recommend this game for anyone that like strategy and might want to give life-sims a try.

It has taken some time for me to fully formulate my opinion on this incredible game into words. Years, in fact, have my soldiers crusaded into India, bypassing the Middle East and holy land entirely, my disease-riddled children learned to fight with swords before learning how to read, and my doctors castrated me against my will in a successful attempt to cure cancer. 
The wild ride known only as [b]Crusader Kings 2[/b] is not a game, but a spectacle to behold to the common man where every single person has their own agenda, and that agenda usually involves sexual relations with your wife. So what groundbreaking changing features never before seen does the game have?
[list]
    [*] Incest
    [*] Torture
    [*] Genocide
    [*] Cuckoldry
    [*] Manure-driven assassinations
    [*] Pope seduction

    [*] Chess games with death that always go very well. (lmao xd) 
[/list]

This game made me question my sanity. While fervently recommending it to every single person I know, I was laughed at, scorned for daring to suggest a game that isn't Dota. When friends did play with me, I was assassinated by assassins, mobs, manure explosions;  cuckolded without a single giggle, asked how to levy armies for the 50th time, and had player-led independence factions led by them tear my realm asunder. Friends is a strong word, as in the medieval world, the only friend you have is whatever god you choose to worship. Your spouse and children may as well be enemy soldiers, having the hostility of a one-eyed feral cat and the life expectancy of a lemming parkouring a volcano. 

Don't let that stop you from enjoying the key features of the game, such as starting construction of a massive statue. Of yourself. Then getting killed immediately after decreeing its construction, but still continuing to build a monument to a deceased 8 year old for the next 50 years. How about an Aztec invasion that makes western countries completely unplayable? Or the Black Death in the 10th century, only surviving because your 3 homosexual wives took the brunt of the plague for you? Or playing as a 0 year old baby, your predecessor's best friend and lover starting a faction to oust you from power? The choice is [b]not[/b] yours.

 Creating a powerful kingdom is easy, but maintaining it for generations to come is always the challenge. Balancing prickly vassals, international disputes, piety, and autistic wonder construction are all constantly on your mind, but that doesn't stop a portal to hell from suddenly appearing outside your gates, or your peasants from hanging Jews whenever they get STDs (likely from sleeping with your wife). Mongols exist, and god fkin dammit, can they nerf the Khazars? Really nice when they conquer all of Russia at the start of every game lmao.

But works cannot do the game justice, God's gift to man in the simple yet incredible, splendid, ascended game, can only be played to be experienced. Random events and unbalanced nonsense will only make every day that passes that more intense, and there's no excuse not to play it. Everyone can experience the game right now.  Even if it is free, (and all of the DLC can be played for free if you just let me host, for god's sake guys, seriously.... ) that won't stop everyone from refusing to play it.  CK2 is still one of the best games currently on the steam store and earns my highest recommendation. Please play Crusader Kings 2 with me guys. I will continue to mention it until CK3 comes out, and you cannot stop me.

The game can be very addicting for those who like medieval strategy games such as myself.

Overall i have a mixed view on this game. It is extremely unique due to the fact that you manage a noble family not the nation or civilization like in so many other games. So keep in mind that you might start as a king, but then "fall from grace" to a lowly count with in a year into the game or a few generations down the line (sandles to sandles in three generations so to speak). Of course the reverse can happen and you can go from a count and claw your way to being a King or even Emporer.

Keep in mind it is more about strategy. you don't directly command armies as a player (your character can lead them but you will NOT be able to command the army like in a TotalWar game). So war is still mostly having the most numbers of men with some degree of tactics like terrain bonuses and unit types( controlled by culture and the type of holdings that sent troops)  Technology and building up your holdings (castles, cities, and temples that provide taxes and armies) and gold tend to come in very slowly.

it all takes time...and like the civilizations games you can suddenly see 5:04 a.m. when you honestly believed it was probably only midnight.

A lot of the events make the game fun. I can tell the writers had fun with some of the event chains which is a major plus for me. Playing the marriage game is a bit frustrating but can be very rewarding(you have to find suitors for...everyone and anyone you want to be married. thoogh the ai will make offers if it is their interests). however it feels like you just do not have much control. and though that is more realistic, it is very frustrating when the ai seems to know what i am trying to do and throw wars. disease, a cheating wife, rebellious nobles, or power mad king ordering i give up titles to land to him.

So CGP Grey's "rules for rulers" on youtube is like the cliffnotes version of what this game is kind of like. Most of the time the most dangerous people were the ones inside the kingdom, within the council, or in the bedroom....be careful who you trust...m'lord. and you will have to basically bribe and smooze or sometimes kill people and vassals under you in order to secure things on the homefront before your plans of conquest can begin(usually only 1 county at a time with a few exceptions)

If you have a lot of time and like to learn and watch hours of tutorials on youtube and love medieval politics then go for it. 

Overall i rate the game for what it is as a 8/10.

I love this game. Perfect split of war and politics. Best possible for those who wish to roleplay the life of Nobility.

EDIT

So my first review was done at 30 hours of gameplay... Well here I am now with almost 3000 hours of gameplay. 

This game is one of the best games out there. You control individual characters with a dynasty through a couple hundred year period and the goal is to progress your dynasty as far as possible. 

You can murder in secret (Or not so secret) your enemies
Reform old religions to meet your needs
War with other characters for lands and other things
Marry off members of your family to gain alliances
Control the laws within your realm
and so much more!

This game is an absolute MUST for anyone who enjoy kingdom management and roleplaying.

Play as the Duke of Northumbria and York and marry Aines of Aquitaine. Watch as your wife wage wars and amass land in Southern France and Eastern Iberia. You, on the other hand, use your considerable diplomacy to become the Chancellor of England under William the Conqueror. Convince him to grant you lands in the north and receive the Duchy of Cumbria. You and your extensive become the ultimate power couple and most powerful landowners in both England and France and, dare I say, Europe. Marry off your 6 female children to the heirs and future kings of England, Denmark, Hungary, Poland, Croatia, and Sicily. Arrange a marriage between the daughter and heir of the King of Scots and your heir.
Fast forward to several years, you have become the father of six queens, one king consort, and grandfather to heirs to the thrones of 7 kingdoms. Your wife has successfully plotted to gain independence from France and has crowned herself the Queen of Aquitaine, making you a king. You die at 76, leaving your vast holdings to your son, the King of Scots. Your wife dies almost a decade later, again expanding your son’s lands and titles to include the Kingdoms of Aquitaine and Navarre, the Duchies of Gascogne and Auvergne, and control over the Duchies of Poitou, Bourbon, Aragon, Paris, and Upper Brittany. Years later, you made as a saint, making your dynasty even more renowned than ever. Your son, the current King of Aquitaine, lord over your dominions, and King Consort of Scotland dies of cancer. Your grandson ascends to the throne.
Meanwhile, your daughter-in-law, the Queen of Scots, is devastated by the untimely death of her husband, so she takes her own life. Your twenty-year-old grandson is now King of Aquitaine, Navarre, and Scotland, and lord over the lands that you and your wife have amassed over your lifetime. After gaining enough prestige, your grandson names himself Emperor and is the most feared and respected ruler in all of Europe. This is only the beginning of your dynasty’s story. What will happen throughout the next hundreds of years? Will your family stay in power, or will it crumble to the ground like others in history?

Crusader Kings II is honestly my favourite game, its gameplay and mechanics are unparalleled and super fun to play. But there is one glaring problem and it's the game's DLCs, without them the game is uncomplete and lacking a lot of features, if you'd want to get all of them it'd cost upwards of $200. The paradox interactive DLC system is honestly terrible, they hold hostage all the interesting game features behind a paywall and leave the normal game barren.

Despite the steep learning curve, once you've got a handle on the mechanics, you can get lost in this game. I have kept coming back for more time and time again. I've been stressed, depressed and crusade obsessed more than I can count, and I might have murdered more relatives than was necessary to keep my throne safe but hey! The number of hours that I have on this game say it all. I consider it to be a work of art that any student of history or person interested in historical games that you can mold and bend to your own twisted or angelic whims will deeply enjoy. It has been my go to game for over five years now and each hour spent on CK2 has been filled with fun challenges, intrigue, and plenty of cultist activities on my way towards dominating Europe. It may take a while to get used to the game mechanics but once you do there is nothing stopping you from reforming Rome and placing your Croatian Jewish brother on the throne of Imperial China. 

The only downside is that for the game to truly be 100% as entertaining as it can be you need most of the main DLCs. While costly, waiting for a sale (which happen quite often) will usually get you all of them - save for the two or three most recent ones - for low and affordable prices. Other than that the game is simply amazing and hard to get bored of - though if you do get bored just start a new campaign and things tend to get interesting again rather quickly. So go and make Julius Caesar proud!

Easily the best Paradox Game to date, and has much more content than the others.

That said this is an 8+ year old game now and has a fair share of bugs and issues that range from slight annoyances to downright game breaking. Most of these issues seem to appear in multiplayer and despite being a fun experience can exacerbate the issue of the game not explaining itself very well (in true paradox fashion).

If you are new to this game or have yet to play a campaign, be prepared to have the Ck2 Wikipedia open or you may end up with the opposite results to what you are expecting (ie. Casus Belli, Succession, Laws etc.etc.) as there is plenty of hidden factors and nuances that downright make the game frustrating for a new player.

That said I think its fun, nice setting, memes to be had

Overall, an amazingly fun medieval sandbox. 

The Pros: LOTS to do. I'd suggest setting a very long term goal for each campaign to keep it interesting since starting without any goal in mind can lessen the fun. 

The Cons: You need all the DLC (or most of them at the least) to truly have a blast playing this game. Some simply offer fun additional content (monks and mystics for example), while others are virtually required to truly enjoy the game (conclave, way of life, Sons of Abraham, etc.). 

TL;DR: Get the game and the DLC during a 50%+ off sale. The DLCs make the game, but once you have them, it's truly a great game. Mods for this game are also great (highly suggest After the End Fan Fork).

While truly there are lots of things to enjoy about CK2, and everyone finds his own most favourite part in this game, I personally find the stories it creates the most exciting part about it. For example, this story happened just yesterday.

One day my character was chilling in a carriage in his old family lands in Hungary when suddenly he was ambushed and taken prisoner by some weirdo in Brittany. The freak tortured my character with rats. What is worse, I had no money to buy my way out of the prison. At the same time, my lovely new wife became pregnant, and, for obvious reasons, this could not be my character's child. After the first daughter came the second and only then my unwitty spymaster uncovered that the weird guy and my unfaithful wife had an affair! Sadly, due to my liege's incompetency in managing the realm, my lands were constantly pillaged by vicious pagan tribes, leaving me with almost no income. Moreover, the regent that was installed to rule in my character's place was a nice and a charitable guy. He shared all of my petty income with the starving and underprivileged. He did not like my character either and never agreed to anything I asked him to do. 

My poor character ended up in a dark and cold oubliette after his friend tried to rescue him and failed. He soon passed away, betrayed by everyone. He only needed 20 more gold coins to buy his way out...

Soon after the news reached Hungary, king's brother was selected as the new king. Being an envious, lustful and ambitious fellow, he always found his brother's wife to be prettier and more attractive than his own. He immediately divorced and married the unfaithful widow. A few months later, the new king decided to relieve his stress by embarking on a carriage trip to his old family's lands, when suddenly they were stopped on a road by a group of french-speaking hoodlums...
Nice

The AI will actively cheat in this game.

I've observed on three occassions the AI will:

1) Muster a larger army than it's maximum levies
2) Will break truces to declare war without invoking any relationship pentalties with its vassals and courtiers.

My decision to uninstall the game came during an ironman playthrough where I was lucky enough to successfully complete the Immortality quest chain. Shortly after becoming immortal and getting the bloodline I felt very fortunate and was excited to continue the run.

After this all happened I fought a war to install a new king on the throne of west francia and, despite being a free duchy, pledged myself to his kingdom and achieved +88 relationship with the king of france.

A few years later we are in the middle of a crusade and the king of france demands that I cede my duchy to him, i decline and defeat him.

He then demands i cede a county to him, i decline and he breaks a truce to declare war on me but i defeat him again. I am not no longer in a position to continue fighting as my manpower is depleted.

He then demands each and every individual country from my Duchy, I cede to him before realising he will just leave me with one county and decline with one third of my duchy left and surrender. he imprisons me.

While I am imprisoned he forces my regent to cede all of my counties to him, leaving me with the least valuable one and then executes me.

No diplomatic penalties were incurred by the french king for using his army to disassemble an entire loyal duchy and execute its leader in the middle of a crusade.

As you can imagine I made the decision to play a different RTS.
It's okay I guess

This is one of the most frustrating games I've ever played. I've seen several prominent YouTuber's feature CK2 on their channels, and it looked fun. Playing the game though is just a lot of arbitrary heckling and outright boredom. 

You play as a dynasty, or a series of related characters. Your characters interactions with the game world are affected by their innate attributes and their traits. These can be affected by extremely arbitrary events that can add or (mostly) subtract from your A's and T's. Amongst the stupid things that can happen to you is loosing your bravery because you imagine being scared one day, loosing you gregariousness because you suddenly decide that you want to be alone, or becoming FAT which leads to the Hard Diet modifier, an extreme disad that last for a ridiculous amount of time. You as the player have no control over any of these, or dozens more equally ridiculous events, that will re-occur frequently throughout the game.

Fighting war is another frustrating aspect of the game. Supposedly, your Marshall attribute, or that of your general's is supposed is supposed to effect the outcome of battles. Numbers of troops involved are also supposed to be a factor, but in my experience general's and numbers rarely factor in, unless it's the AI's general's and numbers. There's also the fact that sometime's the AI can spawn additional troop's for no apparent reason.

Paradox Interactive's grand strategy game returns with "Crusader Kings II", a HUGE step in the strategy game genre. The games take splace in medieval Europe, and your goal, is anything you want it to be.

Here's the thing about Paradox games, you can do almost ANYTHING in them! In "Crusader Kings II", you could be anything you feel. YOu coul dbe a lowly count, vying for control of his leige's realm, you could be a powerfule emporer, seeking domination of all of Europe, you oculdeven be a kind king, only seeking to hold his fragile kingdom together. The posibilities are endless!

There aren't many flaws I can point out, the gameplay is great, the graphics look fantastic, and the music is STUNNING. The only flaw I can personally point out, is the load times. It can take a minute or two for the game to boot up from Steam, but once those load screens are gone, be prepared for maximum awesomness.

With barely anything negative to say about this one, I highly recomend this game to anyone interested, plus, at the time of this review, it's only $10! How can you say no to such an amazing game for such a cheap price!? What are you waiting for? Go out and but it!

This might be the game I've played the most, and like all things played too long, all I see are the flaws. It's a great game, but there are way too many game-breaking bugs to play reliably long-term. I've had 100+ hours games ruined by corrupt save files, bugs with justified imprisonment, bugs with war claims, bugs with troop stacks, bugs with pathfinding and more. The war score, vassal wars, and others are literally game-breaking. I've had wars that never end, vassals that are stuck fighting each other with warscores of 99% for hundreds of years. It's too big and complex at the high-end ironman mode to actually enjoy, not because of gameplay, but because of fear of game-breaking bugs.
Paradox is slowly consuming my life. 10/10

CK2 is hands down the most replayable game ever made. Once you get past the rather clunky UI, this game offers an incredibly rich role play experience with nearly limitless paths. No 2 playthroughs are ever the same, and as you traverse this incredibly rich medieval world, seeking to further your dynasty's prestige, you will create endless stories with rulers you will rule your kingdom wisely or lunatics who bring your empire to ruin. Its a very entertaining game, however beware the full experience requires a number of the dlc. If you are interested, look up the recommended dlc and purchase them on sale or from a cheaper source than steam. I have spent a little bit of *my life* playing this game. So I am somewhat confident in the words I have written below.

Simply put: It's really good. It's not about graphics, or loading screens, or cinematic cutscenes. It's a small game (even with all the DLC), but what it lacks in size, it more than makes up for in balance and structure. This game is like playing a board game with your friends (even if they don't exist), think DnD or Risk but with less restriction. You create the story in your head, and live it out via pop-up story actions, and meticulous planning. It's the kind of fun and entertainment that only a book can give you, except the story is written by you on a day to day basis. As the times change, and your rulers change, the game is always fresh on each playthrough. And the challenge is never the same.

It's not easy to get into and understand, but if you have a particular interest in games where there is something more at stake than 1 thing/1 place/1 objective this is probably the game for you. There is a new CK3 coming out soon, so this is probably going to be the least helpful review ever as people might gravitate toward that first. But know that this game is already the finished product that consistently delivers.

For a long time I didn't "get" Crusader Kings II. Like a lot of Paradox games, it's almost infuriatingly complex and daunting if you go into it blind. Looking at wikis or even tutorial videos was a bit tricky: What's a Casus Belli? Why are my peasants revolting? How do I get more money? Why am I losing every battle? You have to dig a little online to find simple answers rather than long essays about every possible cause of any given action. This is mainly because there [b]are[/b] multiple causes to any given action.

So one weekend, I fired up CK2 as if it was the mid-90s again and I was playing a game before the internet was a thing. I played through the tutorial (which is barebones at best), then started a game on a relatively easy difficulty (by playing Petar of Belgium in 936 AD), and just screwed around for twelve hours while making judicious use of quick-saves and save scumming. I'd save before taking a risky action and, if it went badly, I'd examine what exactly went wrong before loading up again.

And man, my eyes were opened in those twelve hours. CK2's biggest problem is its insanely cluttered and confusing interface. But let me be clear: it's cluttered and confusing [i]to the uninitiated[/i]. While some games may suffer general issues with UI (which is always my biggest gripe of any game), CK2 gives you [i]all[/i] the information you need at any given moment. It's just, when you're getting started, you don't know which screens display which piles of information you need for your specific, at-that-moment need. With each risky action I took -- regardless of outcome -- I slowly learned where on the interface I needed to go to plan my moves ahead.

It is your actions, ironically, that should be the end result of your thinking within the gameplay. The overall premise of the game is to increase your family's place in history by expanding your power. So... what do you need to do, [i]right now[/i], to expand your power? Capture a territory? Kill a rival? Convert an advisor to a different religion? Once you decide on an immediate goal, you can then look into which actions can help you achieve that goal. Soon, you'll be able to start thinking multiple moves ahead, and that's when the full impact of grand strategy will hit you, and you too will see how damn brilliant CK2 is.

This assumes you are wired for such a game. Not everyone has the patience for inane nonsense or paragraphs upon paragraphs of flavor text. Not everyone is willing to save-scum relentlessly during the learning process. Not everyone wants to wade through menus with mixtures of numbers and proper nouns to weigh in-game calculations in quick mental cost-benefit analyses. And of course, not everyone wants to deal with European and North African history. If any of those apply to you though, if your personality or preference is among that type of gamer, you will seriously enjoy CK2.

CK2 reflects its age though. It's not pretty, its music is fine but nothing better, and its myriad DLC can feel oppressive if you're wading into the franchise in 2020 or later. However, as I write this (June 21, 2020), there are frequent free weekends as CK3 prepares for release, as Paradox wants you to taste the CK franchise before tempting you with the latest formula in the batch. It's certainly smart from a marketing standpoint, and you'll likely have a chance to try CK2 for free or at least extremely cheap by the time you read this review.

And no matter how CK3 turns out, CK2's gameplay is good to last for a long while. CK2's take on grand strategy is excellent and will survive just as much as the Civilizations or the StarCrafts have in their respective genres. Just watch the clock when you play: it'll be all too easy to "five more minutes" yourself into another twelve hours of alternate history.

Crusader Kings II is a truly unique experience. I went into this game knowing absolutely nothing about it, and boy was I surprised by the story the unfolded before me. I was apart of a viking tribe son of a warlord and made it my mission to be the greatest warrior who ever lived. I lost my first fight which left me scarred, soon after the man who had defeated me invited me to go hunting for tigers. After that we became best friends. I married his sister and we began traveling the world dueling anyone. I was ruthless to my opponents, when they'd yield I'd give them no quarter and completely murder them. After a few fights I was invited to a warriors guild, and the price of entry was a duel with 3 different men. I defeated the first two with ease, but the third man gave me a hard time we both fought as hard as we could. I ended up killing the man, but he fought hard enough to gravely wound me. 

After my victory I was welcomed by the guild. And slowly I'd rise through the ranks by completing extraordinary tasks. One of which was fighting a bear with my bare hands. After a few years I had a son, but didn't settle down. I began to gather the tribes and go to war, conquering territories as I went. By the time my son was of age I had taken over half of England, a year later an assassin had taken my characters life and my son had become ruler. Not long after it was revealed that his mother had an affair with a tribe leader who had been conquered by my character. Soon after my son was poisoned by his own mother and the game was over.

I can't in good faith recommend this game to anyone for two big reasons. Firstly, and most importantly, is the extortionate price of the DLC which either prevents users from accessing features that feel as though they should be in the base game. This includes epidemics, societies, being able to play a Muslim ruler, basic features as a Jewish ruler, being able to do anything to influence childhood education, and any real interaction with the pope and clergy. I understand that its important for the developers to be able to make a profit from this game but it is frankly disgusting how many basic features are locked behind a paywall; the base game is nigh unplayable with how few options it gives you.

Secondly, even if you are willing to sink the money into this game to unlock the features that should be in the base game, you have to learn how to play it. I'd recommend watching a lets play on youtube before you buy this game at the very least, so you can begin to understand some of the core mechanics behind the game. This isn't necessarily a fault of the game itself, because it being a complicated game is because of exactly what its trying to emulate, but this complexity still means I would never tell someone who wasn't already set on buying this game to get it.

I've got about 2600 hours in EU4 and think I'm reasonably skilled. I can do a lot in that game. Compared to that when in comes to CK2 I'm still a beginner, despite my hundreds of hours of play-time. I've started several campaigns and taken them to varying lengths, but I've only actually completed one (though quite successfully) and I've never dared try ironman or frankly played much outside of Western Europe.

That aside this game is magnificent and I am in awe of it, and frankly while EU4 might be more my cup of tea and I love it I actually consider this to be the better game. When it comes to fidelity of design and of concept it is unmatched. You play a character. You do shenanigens of varying levels of bastardry (including killing bastards). That's about all you need to know. Sure, there's conquest through the sword and the bedchamber, but the meat of the game is the interaction between your character and his or her subjects and the other characters around them. EU4 is a game about conquest, but CK2 is a game about survival. And while EU4's DLC has been mostly good, it's been fairly schizophrenic in terms of focus due to the nature of the game, but this game has always focused on fleshing out those core aspects; it lets you get to play new kinds of people, and you get to interact with people in different ways and have your character do new things. It just keeps getting better while never deviating from its core thesis.

All in all, this game is one of the most personal and personable games on Steam, and, as weird as it may sound, is also probably the platform's premier game about family. In EU4, I will be happy to see a 6/4/5 ruler because it is advantageous, but in this game I can have a great time with a Shy Arbitrary Cruel guy who owns a backwater county in Scotland because as much as he may frustrate me his journey will still be engrossing, thrilling, terrifying, and hilarious. And that's what makes this game so wonderful.

It also has one of the best game soundtracks I know of.

I can safely encourage anyone who has even a passing interest in the strategy genre, or in history in general, or frankly who just likes enthralling, character-driven stories, to buy this game. It really does have something for nearly everyone.

Crusader Kings 2 is a masterpiece as far as I am concerned. If you are interested in history, this title is for you, and if you are interested in alternate history, then this will probably be one of your favorite games of all time. It is infinite. And I mean that. The possibilities for CK2 practically never end. But I have to start somewhere with this review, and so I will start with the world. CK2 puts you in the midst of the middle ages, spanning Spain to India, and Iceland to Egypt, even China has a role to play off-screen. This world is compellingly alive, with hundreds of characters populating it, all with their own agendas on their own journeys for wealth and power, and in order to succeed you must contend with them. The random and scripted events also lend a sense of breathing history to the world of the game. It is a world where you are certainly set for one hell of an adventure. When it comes to the art, it is very well done. The atmosphere is spot-on, and everything has been aesthetically thought of, even down to the UI changing depending on culture group, government, or a myriad of other factors. Of course, heraldry has been thought of, and features heavily as well in its own role. The sound design is fantastic for this kind of game- the music is grand and just varied enough to keep monotony at bay, the UI sounds are staisfying with their clicks and paper shuffling, even the sounds of battle or minor events imbue CK2 with a vibrancy not found in other games, especially not other grand strategy titles. The gameplay, while itself featuring a pretty steep learning curve to those new to the genre, itself provides the perfect vector through which to influence the world and the events therein. Once you take the time and get the hang of things, the controls and functions of the game will feel like a mere extension of your will. Fantastic, and I think the relative complexity makes getting good at the game that much more rewarding in and of itself. As an addendum, mods can make this good game great. The community is active every day, and things like HIP, GoT mod, and a thousand other things can transform it into a true magnum opus. Overall, 10/10, one of the best games I have ever played, and by far the highest replayability value of any title in my steam library.

I can't believe I haven't written a review for this yet. So lets start.

I started playing this game a couple of years after its launch, and boy has it changed. It would be WAY too much for me to catalog and explain all the changes, so I'll try to keep a short and sweet message about what this game is, and why I recommend it 100%

Crusader Kings 2, to me, is basically a role playing game, using grand strategy as the medium. Pick any noble from a lowly count to a powerful emperor, and basically try to keep your dynasty alive. Learn to manage your realm, deal with scheming nobles, aggressive neighbors who want your land for themselves, war, rampant disease, rebellions, murder, cults, etc. Basically, roleplay as a lord in an alternative timeline of the medieval world. It's especially great for history buffs or anyone with a passing interest in history, as the start of a game is as historical as it can be. A lot of things can happen that shape your dynasty and probably the realm you look over, and overall its a really fun experience. I honestly can't express in writing how much I love this game. I've tried *similar games* such as EU4, Stellaris, and (arguably) Civ, in terms of being a ruler of a nation and leading it to victory. But what stands out to me about Crusader Kings 2 is that there's more of a personal touch to it. Since you control and interact with characters with varying personality traits and skills, its easier (in my opinion) to get invested in your dynastiries naturally unfolding story, and the alternate world around you.

Sadly, the best experience has been locked by DLC, such as being able to play as Pagans, Muslim, more flavor events, and so on(wait for sales if you want it). Still, I can personally say I started the game with no DLC WAY back when the game had more basic features, and still found a way to enjoy myself. 

Its free to play now, give it a shot and from there decide (with your wallet) if you think everything else is worth the investment. For me it was, and I'm glad this game is still alive to date.

Having sunk hundreds of hours into this game. This without a doubt is the best game you'll ever play if you're into roleplaying, simulation, and most importantly the freedom to do whatever you wanted in the confines of the game. The DLCs although many and considered to be a little expensive for few, are definitely worth purchasing once you get bored of the base game. They add that little bit of flavour and provide an overall better experience to CK2.

You add the many DLCs with a very active and dedicated Steam workshop community and you'll find yourself modding your own game to further enhance/improve upon the gameplay. This alone offers endless hours of even more material and more hours of playing time. You'll never get bored of this game because there is always something new to do, a new conquest, a new approach, or a new play style to test out. 

I suggest getting into CK2 first before CK3 launches, so that way you can hit the ground running and the learning curb we'll all experience once CK3 drops won't be as massive or as steep to climb in comparison to an individual jumping straight into CK3.

This game is not for everybody, some of its aspects may discourage even the most curious gamers, like the kind of ugly graphics, the unhelpful tutorials and tips and the unfriendly user interface of the game just to mention a few. But if you, as a new player, really want to play this game, you should find helpful tools, the community of this game is super friendly and each gamer has very different ways to play it, I would recommend you to look for some short tutorials on youtube, the youtuber btrekkie has a couple of videos that are short and very easy to understand, all of this so you know what it is the game about. Do not play the game's tutorial, you should try to play on Irland first, since it is basically the non official noobie island of the game.

If you are still interested in the game you will find your own enjoyment during your playthroughs, that is the jewel of this game, once you understand the basics and enjoy the game, you will experience these incredible stories based on the medieval politics, you can do anything, there are no specific goals in the game, except to have an heir of your own dynasty to keep playing, but you could try anything, to be the king of France and win the 100 years war, unite all the kingdoms in the british isles, found a norse pagan empire and submit the christian kingdoms, just to mention a few ideas.

I still recommend the game even with all the cons that it may have because it becomes so immersive once you know how to use all the tools the game offers you, and if that is not enough you could try some mods, some are unbelievable good.

And finally, check what dlcs interest you since there are a lot and they are not cheap, but first try the game, it is free now and you will lose nothing playing it... except yourself...

Where to even begin?

This game is a gigantic feudal dynasty simulator, allowing you to pick historical figures from interesting periods to play as, minor nobles or even custom characters. Simply put, it's an alternate history generator as you play through your chosen dynasty and time period, and can lead to many interesting stories or moments. One of the coolest features is that each character that is based on a real historical figure will have wikipedia links on their character sheet so you can learn about the actual person they are representing.

This is grand strategy at its best, forcing you to take into account an absolutely mind-boggling amount of variables in order to achieve your goals. There is no "win" state - you play however you like, trying to get done whatever you want to get done. For example, on many playthroughs I started as a count in Ireland and attempted to unify all of the UK under an Irish banner. I've even taken over Africa and parts of Western Europe as Aztecs, invading from overseas in the "Sunset Invasion" DLC.

You can play as a wide variety of cultures, religions, or government types, each with options to customize your realms particular traditions for completely unique experiences each time you play. There is just... a lot. There's a lot to this game, and you'll likely never run out of content to try out.

That being said, it's very hard to learn and not for the impatient. If you aren't a fan of grand strategy, turn away now and find something else to play. But if you have a taste for crushing enemy armies underfoot and the raw nerves of steel necessary to do so, then give this game a shot. You won't be disappointed.

I paid money for this game, let it sit in my steam library, and finally decided to play it right as it became free... 

But anyway. Crusader Kings is a grand strategy game where you take on the role of a medieval Dynasty, one ruler at a time. You basically take on the role of a count/duke/king whatever and make decisions about who you and your children marry, when to go to war, who to make friends with, who to appoint to various offices and the like. It is a very non-traditional strategy game. You could literally conquer and forge a kingdom and then lose it all because you messed up your inheritance laws or bad event happens. You are not a country, you are a person/family in that country so do NOT get caught up in "map painting" as that isn't really what this game is about.

This game is complex, there is a LOT going on and the game is terrible at telling you what is important and what isn't. Watch a tutorial it will help, and when you get it you will realize it isn't that complicated after all. You basically make a few decisions (and most of them are non-decisions like "appoint the guy with highest diplomacy as my chancellor because I have no reason to pick anyone else") and then wait for an oppertunity to open up or an event to happen. Pause, make decisions, play. 

You can guide your family in a direction, but the fun is really in the events and happenings rather than conquest or goal achieving. I can't tell you how many times I would browse through some relations or plots only to go "wait, that's my wife!". Like "looks like someone is plotting to kill me... wait, that's my wife!"

Now that this game is free, so long as you have the patience to make it through learning the game (which does take a good hour or so) there is no reason not to try it.

It has a high barrier to entry compared to other strategy games which can make it seem either unwieldy or even boring at first. Nothing will happen if you don't know how to get through the game interface or do politics, besides dying of course. However, once you learn the UI, game mechanics, and how to use claims it becomes quite addicting!

But if none of that is your cup of tea you can always become a renowned warrior who worships Satan, then go insane and marry a horse.  Your name will be known and feared as you and your proud family of horse people plunge Europe into a tide of murder and incest.  
Until your spymaster kills you over a minor land issue or your court physician accidentally kills you because he thought chopping your limbs off would cure your pneumonia.  

If you have the heart of a warrior and the mind of a Windows Excel programmer, this is the game for you.

First of all, this is one of the best game I've ever played. Just like other grand strategy games you wage war in your quest for power. But this game put emphasis in plot, meaning most of the times you scheme your way up the ladder by any other means, In this game I've assassinated my own liege to take his throne, sacrificed my own child to Satan, and commit other atrocious  crimes. Sounds like fun right?

But unfortunately just like other grand strategy games , Crusader Kings 2 suffers from mid-/late- game lag. In other games it usually happens ONLY in late game, but in Crusader Kings 2 it starts quite early. The reason is the game have to tracked so many characters either dead or alive so after 300 years or so it starts to lag. The expansion packs make it worse by introducing new mechanics, hence new data to be processed. If you think your computer is strong enough to never have any lag, you'll be wrong. Crusader Kings 2 is a 32 bit games and it's RAM usage is capped to 4 GB, so it WILL lag.

So my verdict is YES this game is great, but lower your expectation because it is unlikely you'll have your fantasy of your own long running dynasty fulfilled due to lag.

Like most other Paradox titles this is a very large and very complex strategy game, however unlike other Paradox games the Crusader Kings series focuses on families and individuals as opposed to nations and states. This is a pretty unique take on strategy gameplay that injects tons of roleplaying and emergent storytelling that I cant really compare to any other game. While it is hard to learn at first, this game has more personality and replayability than any other game Ive ever played. If you are a fan of both strategy and roleplaying games you owe it to yourself to at least try this game on one of the many free to play weekends. It gets a glowing recommendation from me as far as actual gameplay is concerned. 

The biggest drawback of this game for a newcomer is the same one that effects every Paradox game: DLC. The DLC list for this game is expansive, and while some are definitely lower on the list of necessity than others a good percentage of them are pretty much required to get the best gameplay experience. This can drive up the buy-in price of the game considerably, and is one of the main things that lead other reviewers to rate this game negatively. Luckily these days, especially with the incoming CK3, this game and all its DLC is routinly on sale with deep price cuts. I managed to get the game and all of the highest rated DLC for still cheaper that a new game and eventually picked up the rest at a later date.

So, as long as you follow the advice to buy on sale, this game and its DLC get a purchase recommendation from me.

I feel this game is seperated from other strategy games because it isn't as flat as games like Total war or Hoi4. The game isn't necessarily about the nation you rule but more the dynasty you create. It's set in the middle ages so your family and succession is the main focus and about how your family survives in this historical feudal world. This game is about making your own story and you truly feel like the master of your own world in this. The complexity of court politics makes the game really interesting once you get the hang of it. Of course the downsides to this game is the long time it takes to fully understand all aspects of this game and the rediculous amount of dlc but if you can get through those two you will be in for an enjoyable experience.

This doddering, old, beauty of a game is still fun and immersive, though its bones creak and it shows its age with every interface. It has potentially the deepest gameplay of any game I know of (with the possible exception of EVE Online), but you don't necessarily have to know about all of that depth. Quite a few of my friends find the RNG of events in CKII to be infuriating; I find the realism rewarding. Playing conservatively is essentially mandatory--CKII punishes the typical greedy expansion of strategy games mercilessly. You can easily build an empire quickly, but if you do you will lose it within a few generations unless you have both luck and excruciating patience and attention to detail on your side. There are endless things to manage and to do--NPCs to keep happy, to manipulate, to assassinate, to sway or seduce or bribe. Your own dynasty is both crucial to your survival and one of your greatest threats. Diseases are the great opportunist; better be prepared with a long line of potential heirs! If you are prepared, you can often get some of your enemies' lands on the cheap, as their realm passes to an imbecilic six year old twice removed. CKII's RNG is brutal and that is what makes a tall, conservative playstyle viable--though still no guarantee for success. And while it can be frustrating, at least the majority of the RNG-based events are based on real-world events we have little control over: spread of disease, outcome of battles, pregnancy and childbirth.

Overall, CKII remains one of my two favorite titles. Its recently-announced successor, CKIII, will hopefully keep the gameplay mechanics and fix the convalescence of this eight-year-old game with some updated UI and fixes for multiplayer stability.

BUT!

You uncover a conspiracy. A conspiracy to assassinate your wife, with the ring-leader being your Vice-Roy!  You're Vice-Roy is still a horse.  The queen?  Still a bear.

All this while, your father's killer is still out there, lurking.  Ready to pounce.

After a couple of thousand hours playing crusader kings 2 I think I can recommend the game to anyone that is interested in grand strategy.
This is a a typical paradox game and has the usual steep learning curve trying to understand the depth  and breadth of the game play.  The first thing I would say to new players is - don't expect to win. There is no real way to win the game, its really about the journey. 
Before the game had achievements  I used to spend my time trying to build a game from being the count of a little province to becoming a duke, then a king, and so on - fighting, intriguing and marrying your way across the politics of the high middle ages - doing everything from re-founding the Roman Empire to founding a Shia caliphate. 
If you can get through the first few games you will find that CK2 becomes infinitely re-playable. Every play through is different, history changes every time.
The one piece of advice I would give new players - be patient. This is one of those games where you can lose a bit of land or a  title, and then 50 years later you end up a king somewhere else.
This is a fun rewarding game if you can give it some time to learn (there are quite a few youtube tutorials that are helpful).

I Love this game, I wish there were more like it.

First of all -  it is pleasant to the eyes and ears. It is very immersive in its style. 
Second - it is pretty easy to start playing and enjoying. 100 hours latter you will still be discovering new mechanics, but basics are simple and are enough to have fun with it.
And the best part - you don't really need DLC's to play.
My first 80 hours or so were without a single DLC, never had troubles, nor did I feel restricted in any way. Nor did I feel that I exhausted the base game capabilities. But hey, don't take my word for it - base game is free, so just try it.
Yes, it is only "middle" Middle Ages and only christian rulers. Guess what - game is called Crusader Kings, what did you expect? Between wars, securing your succession, forging alliances, plotting murder of your enemies and competing for influence over Pope, there's a lot of fun to be had.

Regarding DLC's - they add a lot to the game. None of the are essential, and each can be played without the rest. As for me - each one is worth getting. 

But try the base game at first. I would recommend to give it somewhere around 5 hours before deciding wether you like it or no

While there is a bit of a learning curve, as seen in all PDX games, once you overcome that you have a game that should provide countless hours of entertainment.
It is hard to get into but once your in, you're in for life.

Hugely addictive dynasty simulator. Plays like Rome Total War with autoresolved battles and a far more in-depth campaign. History buffs rejoice.

Like most massive strategy games, it suffers from poor AI. You will find yourself cursing the names of your allies as they are leading their forces to certain doom, or abandoning your troops in your time of need, or failing to declare rebellion when the time is ripe. There are also a number of miscellaneous but crippling bugs such as inexplicably losing your vote in the imperial election. The next class of annoyances is from some of the strange mechanics in the way that wars are declared and won; you may find yourself abdicating to your son because the rebellious noble you seek to imprison is besieged by foreign armies waging holy war rather than by you, or controlling a completely different son and heir than the one you've been preening for succession because his brother suddenly inherited a distant county.

The game's engine most realistically works for 10-13th century Catholic feudal kingdoms: brothers are invariably enemies rather than allies, Catholics and Greek Christians consider each other infidels, crusades can be waged against heretics as well as foreign faiths, and sieges are more effective than open combat.

All in all: it's a fantastic game that splits the difference between RPG and RTS, and a must-play for history buffs.

Crusader Kings 2 is one of if not the best game from Paradox if you have the money for all the DLCs.

I prefer ck2 to EU4 or HOI4 because in Ck2 there is roleplaying and a story that you write, and that is something that is not in EU4 or any other Paradox games.

Also CK2 has always changing difficulty, not like in EU4 where its always France and the Ottomans who will become the huge blob, here its different.

The only 2 downside for this game is that very late game it runs like shit, the Black Death would help your performance by killing off a lot of people, but if you play a long game most of the world has built good hospitals.

And the main issue is the DLC, there are too much, but luckily they go on a sale pretty often and if you play multiplayer only the host needs to have them all.
