While Crusader Kings 2's reputation as a horse incest simulator is mostly deserved, it's so much more than that. It shows you the power of setting ambitious long term goals and persisting through the inevitable setbacks along the way. It teaches you that if you work hard, you can get what you want, if you can come up with enough bullshit justifications to convince other people to go along with you. It shows the importance of being a good parent, but also to be kind and not blame yourself if you give birth to the Antichrist.

I initially bounced off the game back in 2013 due to the tutorial being nowhere near complete. I eventually figured it out by watching Arumba and quill18 on YouTube. On my first successful game, I started as a small count in Western Europe and ended up conquering most of the continent in my pursuit of ridding it of the Karolinger dynasty. I also managed to inherit the Byzantine Empire after many years of planning. Then the Horse Lords patch came out and corrupted my ironman save. I keep backups now.

Recently I've been playing as a Ghanan ruler with the 769 start date. In previous attempts I was conquered by the much stronger caliphates I had for neighbours, but this time I managed to get a hold of a few coastal provinces and Canarias and began funding myself through raiding. I reformed my faith to be Unyielding (high defensive bonuses) and Sea-Bound (cheap ship maintenance, for easier raiding). The Totem-Guardians doctrine specific to African faiths contains the Religious Tax doctrine, which allowed me to ironically tax Muslims for being infidels. Together this gave me enough funds to defend myself, but once I had defeated all the smaller rulers, I was still too weak to deal with either the Umayyad or Abbasid caliphates which were my only remaining neighbours. Then the Abbasids declared a holy war for Canarias. I initially managed to beat them back, but then they dropped a huge army on the island and I had nowhere near the ships to deal with it. I didn't want to give up. Decades of skirmishing followed. I assassinated multiple caliphs, sent councillors to cause chaos and slowly started to encroach on their territory. One of the caliph's vassals hated him so much he sent me money to aid in my war against his liege. The AI kept asking for a white peace, and I kept declining. If they had to surrender, they would have to pay me most of the money they had left. Because so many of their armies were tied up dealing with me, it also made them weaker against revolts and other attackers. Eventually after 35ish years of continuous war, the holy war ended due to the casus belli becoming invalid. This initially felt anticlimatic, but then I noticed the reason was that the entire caliphate had fallen apart. The vassals had become independent and much easier to deal with. Crusader Kings 2 is great for allowing these kinds of stories to emerge at a large scale, but it's equally capable of telling a more personal tale like becoming the homosexual son of Satan and conquering most of Eastern Europe with your friends Circe, Jezebel and Morgana.

If I had to offer criticism, it would be that human players are maybe a bit too advantaged versus the AI. If you know what you're doing you become difficult to stop. Teleporting commanders all over the map feels a bit like an exploit. Way of Life micromanagement when you have a lot of offspring can get a bit tedious. I actually like the DLC system because it has allowed funding continuous development on the game for 7 years after it was released, and it's not necessary to get all of it.

Crusader Kings II is Paradox's best game, and one of the best strategy games of all time. Its greatest appeal comes from its historical accuracy. You can play one of any number of leaders of Europe during the dark ages. Actually, you play as a dynasty of leaders, and it is important that you have a successor, which leads to some crazy antics, which you may have seen in other reviews. You are trying to maintain your rule and if possible to grow it. There are a lot of tools to help you get there.

That leads to what might be seen as the biggest downside to the game. This game has the biggest learning curve of any I have played. There is a lot of effort needed to master all the tiny details. I would recommend playing with a friend who has played before if possible. 

Overall, a great game. 10/10 would recommend.

Constantly needing to replace advisers, people inviting you to plots that go against your interest, kids being born at 5x the rate during wars who you have to assign skills/tutors for, constantly replacing commanders who randomly leave and your army which easily could've won the battle, loses.  


This game is very anti-snowball. Saved up a lifetime of 2000 gold? We'll just generate a barbarian invasion event with 20k extra event troops to make you spend all of it on mercs. Took a plot of land away from your heretic brother? No problem you will now die and play as the heir with the heritic religion, absolutely ridiculous, makes the game not even hard but seriously slow to play. 

TLDR: The game punishes players too hard for making good plays ramping up the difficulty everytime the player takes a step forward, requiring very slow gameplay to think through everything or lots of save scuming.

ONE BIG CON
The sheer amount of DLC you'd have to get to have the same experience as me is outright stupid, I admit it.
However we need to remember that these DLC's where added after the games full completion.
India was never intended to be on the map when they released it, however they added it.
China was never suppose to be interacted with but they did that too in a later DLC.
While having all these dlcs might look bad for a person who gets the game today, and want to enjoy the same experience as me, these DLCs have been added throught the years of the games life.

Its a YES from me, get the game and its DLCs if you can! Its 100% worth it!

CKII is the *only* game that really even attempts historical simulation. i’m in awe of it. And it has nothing to do with the care Paradox took to represent succession laws, cultural groups, overlapping political jurisdictions (though all that is extremely impressive too). Rather, the brilliance of this game lies in this: it lets you inhabit a single person, and only a single person at a time, and through that person forces you to interact with a world populated by hundreds (thousands?) of individuals, each with his/her own interests and opinion of you. It’s this deeply personal (or interpersonal) mechanic that is missing from other nominally "historical games", all of which boil down to mere the glorified chess games (Civ et al.) or laughably thin economic simulators (Total War et al.). CKII is a masterpiece in historical simulation. That sense you have when playing CKII of interacting with personalities, of swimming in an ocean of competing and incommensurate interests, and of small decisions leading (often unpredictably) to significant changes in politics and power dynamics -- it’s the only game I’m aware of that actually comes close to simulating what it’s like to be a person living in history.

This game is the perfect marriage of role playing and grand strategy. Want to become a viking lord, reform Paganism, and become the religious head for all of Scandinavia? Want to unite the British Isles centuries early? Want to form the Holy Roman Empire on your terms? You can do all of that and so much more in this great medieval sandbox.

The strategy aspect is ever-present in everything you do, but it's never so deep that it's bogged down by large amounts of management. There's no board game feeling that other strategy genres might have as you set your own goals and achieve them in multiple ways as they suit you. There's no hard competition with other players, and I've never felt like I had to get into a multiplayer match for a real experience.

I am looking forward to CK3, but if you can get this game and it's expansions for cheap, please do so if you're willing to learn the systems at play.

It's hard to say whether I recommend this game or not. On one end, the complete experiance is one of the best grand strategy games I ever played, maybe THE best. on the other hand, it's also one of the most expansive. See the base game while fine felt really quite barebones and not so intresting to me, the DLCs are there CK2s strength lies, and they can be quite expansive. I will say however, once you get several DLCs and you get what the game is about (a chaotic medival choice simulator, leaning more into RPG territory rather than strategy) it's really fun with TONS of replay value.

Despite all the various criticism about expansions, pricing and what-not, this is still my favourite medieval sandbox game. Over 1200hrs played. The Workshop community only serve to make this game even more fun than the developers have.

TL;DR:Hands down the best game I have ever played! The base game is good but the DLC really make it shine. The dynasty system is a great idea and really helps with immersion and roleplay, no other game like this.

Side note: there's a really good fanbase for this game so if you have any doubts or queries just ask on the facebook let's play group and people will be more than happy to help.

Pros:
-User interface: this is a bit overwhelming at first, but you'll find everything is a click or two away when you get the hang of it
-Multiplayer: you can start of grand strategy campaigns with Friends or strangers that can last days or weeks if you so wish. Should someone quit, you're still able to pick up where you left off in the singleplayer mode
-Leveling system: This is one of the best I've come across, although you can't level your character per se, The countless ways you can upgrade various parts of your holdings/realm/laws/etc, all have a large impact.

Neutral:
-Graphics: Nothing to write home about, but this is not the reason you buy the game
-Features: Although the base game is already able to suck away hundreds of hours of your life, certain gameplay styles and features aren't available untill you get the countless DLC

Cons: 
I will never get back the 1000+ hours of my life that I have lovingly committed to this game and my various characters.

P.S. If you're thinking of getting the game/DLC, or have any questions, feel free to ask me anything.

For me this, is a re-review. I first reviewed this game about 8 years ago when it was first released. The game has changed A LOT since then. So here's what I think of the game now:

What it is: a grand strategy game mixed with RPG elements. In CK 2, you will be commanding armies, engaging in diplomacy, and managing the economy on behalf of a medieval polity (be that a western european kingdom, islamic sultanate, pagan tribe, etc.), but you don't just play as the polity itself. You play as a dynasty, with one character at a time through the line of inheritance as each one of them eventually perishes. Each of your characters has a wealth of traits, making them feel unique, and the "country" that you control changes based on what your new character inherits (or what they don't).

Gameplay: Will feel familiar to all people familiar with Paradox, the developer/publisher. You play on a world map divided into provinces (think Risk). You control a certain number of provinces, and your goal, such as you have one, is to keep the provinces you have an obtain more. Each province in the game world (Europe, north Africa, the Middle East, India, and Central Asia) has a ruler. Playable characters in CK2 are divided into tiers: from lowly counts to regal Emperors. A ruler of a higher tier can have lower tier ruler as a vassal. You can play as the top ruler in a realm, or as a vassal with another character as your liege lord. 

The game is a sandbox, with no set goals. Victory is determined by the dynasty that has the most "prestige" (a measure of how famous and respected you are based on your achievements and your ancestors') at the end of the game, but "winning" isn't really important. In wartime, you raise armies from your provinces (at the beginning of the game, you have no standing army and need to raise levies of peasants to fight for you in wartime, though that changes with time) and attempt to defeat enemy armies in the field and capture enemy provinces in sieges. Battles are AI-determined based on troop numbers, traits of commanders, and RNG. Sieges are basically parking on an enemy province and waiting for a timer to run out. Most provinces have multiple settlements, all of which can be sieged and captured.

At peace, you're tasked with managing your realm and conducting diplomacy. You can ally with foreign rulers by marrying your family members to theirs. You can develop your realm by spending money constructing buildings in your provinces. You can manage unruly vassals by bribing them with money and titles or inviting them round for a beer. You can go on a pilgrimage to a faraway holy site. You can plot to kidnap or murder your rivals and they can do the same to you. There's way too much that you can do to describe everything here, but for the most part it boils down to reading flavor texts in popup windows and making choices, with an RNG determining the outcome.

I find this game absolutely engrossing, but I understand some people will find it boring. It's thrills come more from seeing a plan decades (in game years) in the making finally come to fruition or successfully seizing territory in a war, not from heart-pumping action or visuals. This type of game is often called a map-staring simulator for a reason. However, this is a particularly good map staring simulator. The RPG elements of representing a particular person add immensely to the immersion. Some of the best moments in this came come from making the decisions your character would make, not necessarily the ones YOU think are best. There are very few other Grand Strategy titles out there that nail this at all, and none as well as CK2.

Recommended for: Any grand strategy fans that want a personal touch to the gameplay, and who don't require real time battles to have fun.

The young prince was born only two weeks before his father was killed in battle with a neighboring kingdom. He grew up, learning the ways of war, until when he was 14 years old, his regent, the spymaster of England, had him imprisoned on false charges so he could rule in the young king's stead. The king languished in prison until he was 21, when he broke out, exacted revenge on his spymaster, and took control of the kingdom that was rightfully his.

That's just one story from my many hours of playing Crusader Kings, a game that let's you control the military planning and court intrigue of a medieval noble, from lowly count to majestic emperor. It gives you the chance to live out the lives of royals, making choices that might just affect your character, or could have ramifications for your entire realm. You can forge alliances through marriage, or forge a new bloodline to rival that of the Karlings or Alexander the Great. You can peacefully spread your religion by sending missionaries, or spread it by the tip of the sword. The choice is yours.

I only have two major complaints: The user interface and controls can be very complicated, especially for beginners, and to get the full experience, you'll need to fork over a lot of money on DLC. When you start playing your first Paradox game, it wouldn't be surprising if you took a moment to soak in everything on screen, unsure of what is important and what is just quality of life. The tutorial does a little to help with the basics, but the only way to learn is to play, and try new things, and to make mistakes. And the game will give you plenty of chances to make mistakes. And losing your kingdom to have to build it back up again is just part of the experience.

But back to the other main issue with this game: the DLC. The only good time to get the DLC is when it's cheap and on sale, and if you're not a nerdy medieval fanboy like me, don't bother with the cosmetic packs. While many of the components from the DLC are in the base game, they can only be utilized fully with the DLC. Most of the DLC is worth it though, and if you can get a good deal on it, I recommend them all.

All in all, if you like the sounds of playing as a medieval king raising a family while doing their best to take over the entirety of Europe, while also being maybe a bit of a lunatic, then this game is probably for you. It takes persistence to learn, and doesn't fit everyone's style. Watch some videos of the game and decide if you like it. If you do, well, get ready to build your kingdom, outsmart your rivals, and take your place in history!

(As a note, they've also announced Crusader Kings 3, which will come out soonish. If you'd prefer to wait and get that, be my guest. I personally feel like Paradox games aren't complete until they start making DLC, so I'll be waiting a bit to get it, but that decision is up to you. Have fun and rule on!)

CK2 is a fun medieval LARP game where you can play as a Count, Duke, King, or Emperor of a nation. There is tons of depth in terms of family relations, managing your realm, appeasing (or killing off) your discontent and parasitic council, and pursuing various forms of foreign policy. I would highly recommend this game to anyone who seeks out a medieval experience akin to that of Mount and Blade or Kingdom Come: Deliverance, as it delivers a fantastically immersive experience set between the era of Charlemagne up until the 1400s. The only downside is the excessive amounts of DLC content which is required to obtain the full experience. On this front, I would highly recommend waiting for a Steam sale (or Paradox store sale), as you'll end up saving loads of money. All in all, I'd rate this a solid 8/10 in its current state (DLC included) and 5/10 (DLC excluded).

It is a game that does indeed have a solid learning curve in terms of beyond-basic mechanics and techniques of gameplay. When playing it takes a lot of time to feel like you're really personalizing your domain to being your own. Those are my only real complaints, the rest simulates (at least to a relatively understandable degree) the constant back and forth of the times represented. The game is fun without mods, with them, with or without cheats, and especially with friends in multiplayer where you try to compete in ludicrous ways. Just remember that it will take many many hours to even complete a game. You may get bored and try a new realm, and I've only made it to the end fully a few times without ironman though for most so I have little to no achievements to show for it. Eitehr way, take your time and remember that it's a relaxed game.

-Creating the crusader state of Jerusalem and wrecking the Saracens

Initially, this game is extremely fun, and will captivate many hours of your time.  However, once you have mastered the game mechanics, and understand how all the game mechanics are suppose to work, this game will make you so annoyed and plainly just pissed off.

The game is simple enough to get into, but complex enough to make you feel like it is complex and challenging.  However, start delving into that complex game play and what you really find is an AI that acts like a spiteful, obstinate, 5-year-old.  It's not challenging you with a thought-out (or well-programmed) strategy in mind.  No, the AI just does not want to do what you want to do.  If you want to do "x," the AI will allow everything else but "x" to happen, even at the detriment of the character(s) that AI is controlling.  This behavior is so persistent in the game that it will do some simply unbelievable things to make sure you can not attain "x."

When you require the AI to do something else besides being a stubborn brat, it falls on its face.  I struggle to find reasons to allow AI armies to fight on my side.  They usually either run off and do not contribute to the war in any significant manner, run headlong into the enemy in a suicide attempt that helps the enemy win the war, or they wander about aimlessly and again, not contribute to the war effort.

Worst part about all of this is, the developers have known about the AI behaving horribly for years.  However, instead addressing it in any relevant and useful manner, the devs decide to keep adding on new pieces to this Frankenstein.  This reference is to the movie Young Frankenstein, however.  In that movie, the assistant uses an abnormal brain, ruining the body of work just like the AI ruins the body of work here.

Unfortunately, a DLC that reworks the AI is not considered flashy, and is not something they could charge the player base $15 - $30 for.  Players would expect a fix to the AI to be free and, well, the devs just cant be arsed to do that much work for free....so polishing this turd with flashy new things that do not address the base problems of the game will continue.

I just can't put another hour of time into this game.  The problems are glaring and because of how the game works, they only snowball into bigger and bigger problems until you can not ignore them any further.  Until they do a SERIOUS rework of this AI, do not put any money into this game.

TL;DR: The AI does not make the game difficult, but it's behavior is obnoxious, and it makes the game so tedious and UNFUN to play.

This game is brutally complex, inaccessible to many audiences, unbalanced by design, and a vast amount of the outcomes of this game are dependent on RNG.
It's also one of my favourite games.
Crusader Kings 2 is not for everyone. It is built for a specific subset of weirdos like me, and I don't know how many people are gonna be able to get into it beyond that. But it is brilliant for what it is. Crusader Kings 2 allows you to play as a ruler in the Medieval world, and presents you with a challenge: attain power, outwit your foes, and ensure your dynasty lasts. To make this happen, a dizzying array of mechanics are given to you, turning this game into a fusion of a 4X strategy game and an RPG.
Yes, the game is deliberately unbalanced, but this is part of the fun, and can be understood as a difficulty setting; certain rulers are gonna have an easier time than others. Yes, the game is reliant on randomness, but that makes it interesting, and forces you to change strategies (or allows you to exploit openings) to survive. Rarely does this game just become checking items off of a list; you need to adapt to what the world is throwing at you, and one big mistake can send it all tumbling down.
I will confess: this is not an elegant or accessible game. The learning curve is steep, which is a shame, because I want to bring as many people in on this as possible. But if you're willing to push through the complexity, you'll find the delicious caramel centre at the heart of this game: the ability to make absolutely bonkers historical narratives come to life between deeply flawed people trying to guide the ship of state.
If that sounds the least bit interesting to you: please. Play this game. You'll thank yourself for it.

I've dedicated many years of my life now to this game, having played this game since perhaps 2013. Primarily, I got it out an already established interest in historical grand strategy games, but my love of this game was intensified once coming across the fan-made A Game of Thrones mod. As a result, I became a fully fledged addict of this game, and have actually deleted this game completely from my library once, only to buy it once more again... #firstworldproblems

After establishing a somewhat healthier relationship with playing this game compulsively, I am now able to give my opinions on the game, hopefully as unbiased as possible.

This game is incredibly detailed on its historical accuracy, to an impressive amount. Figures both important and incredibly minor all appear and often with extensive personal histories themselves. It's very possible to trace a lot of historical information from characters and it be more or less accurate to the real historical situation (this is true of vanilla as well as the AGOT mod).

Mechanically, the game has ironed out a lot of the kinks over the years, having tweaked old mechanics and continued to introduce new ones that keep people excited (the most recent example would be 'Great Works', and independent system for building and managing buildings of major importance in the world) and it now provides a very fluid experience with a lot of content to play with.

And that is where this game truly shines; its content. There is so much here that players can sink their teeth in to; seemingly endless story arcs for every character, who will be uniquely built every time you play as them, and constant challenges and threats from those who covet what you have or who seek to thwart your own ambitions. It's a constant struggle against your enemies, your friends and yourself when playing this game, and the presentation of all of this makes it extremely easy to roleplay any type of character you may wish. You could be a pious man of God who hopes to keep the peace between his neighbours, or an utterly devious lord of ambition whose only desire is to achieve as much power as possible, or something in between. Or perhaps you could even have a character make such a transformation in the space of their life; all it takes is for a mad Greek emperor to cut your balls off for a little bit of harmless scheming and suddenly you've gone from 'paragon of virtue' to 'Glitterhoof enthusiast'.

The directions in this game are endless, and that gives it an incredible replay value that I've found is very difficult to match in any other game. With the ultimate goal of furthering the interests of your own dynasty at the forefront of your mind at all times, and taking the game gradually generation by generation, it's easy to get lost in this world as you fashion your own stories around what you're doing. Sure, sometimes ridiculous things happen on the map that you'd never expect, but it's all a part of that endlessly unpredictable wave that life itself is a part of too.

Crusader Kings II is absolutely one of the finest strategy games on the market, in that it's... also basically a pretty decent RPG as well. Considering that the base game is free now, it's much better to play the game itself and see exactly what sort of stuff you can get into! The number of completely ad-hoc story generation is amazing, and... frankly, I'd suggest to just play. Also, modding! Extremely moddable, with many amazing settings from existing IPs to completely new things for you to govern and rule and die horribly to plagues.

Negative: Without the DLC, huge portions of the world are unplayable, leaving you with just (at this point) stripped down versions of Catholic and Orthodox Europe, and some of the DLC still have issues with them that were never fixed. Some mechanics are broken forever in some fashion, especially from older DLC, the merchant republics from The Republic are hard-coded messes that only barely function and are even less fun, and the nomads of Horse Lords... well. Absolute messes.

I have played over 2100 hours on this game over the course of 4 years. When I first bought this game I hated it because I did not understand it, I set it down and did not come back until I found the game of thrones mod on youtube and had to play it. This game is difficult to understand but once you get it, you will love it. It takes time but the amount of things you can do in this game are truly insane. It involves a lot of reading but you will really enjoy the experience. It feels like you are reading a book but are also the author and the main character. Warfare, Diplomacy, Theology, Politics, Marriages, lands and titles, duels and adultery, murder and torture, honor and glory, this game has everything you could ever ask for, even if you had know idea what you were looking for. This game is easily one of my favorite games of all times and is the reason I got into playing games on the PC. If CK3 ends up being terrible, I will still play this game for years and years to come. The DLC are all great, the only one I do not have is legacy of Rome and only because I do not like how everyone can have a standing army, I feel like only a Kingdom or a Empire or the highest liege should be able to have a standing Army during the middle ages. If I want to reconquer the Roman Empire then I play as the greeks. I renamed the Byzantine Empire to the Roman Empire anyway. This is my opinion. Great game but do not expect to understand this in a few minutes. This game will take you at least 8 hours of watching youtube documentaries before you can even start with the basics and even then, you will learn new things each time you play. Truly a must but not for the faint of heart. Time truly flies while playing this game.

CK2 is a grand strategy game with plenty of replay value and once you get past the learning curve it's a great game to sink hours into. You can pretty much be anyone you can think of, a count from the Holy Roman Empire, a khan in the eastern steppes, a Viking raider from the north, or just a tribal nobody in the northeast who'll get their ass blasted by the Russians and Mongols constantly. Religion plays a big part and is varied with the big ones such as the Muslims and Christians being there along with obscure ones such as Zunists. The modding community is huge, and the mods themselves can transform the map, religions, and cultures into pretty much anything you'd want from Tamriel to Azeroth. The only downside is how greedy the publishers are. If they can monetize even the smallest new feature, they will. Other than that the game is great for those who love player freedom.

The brilliance of CKII is making a dynasty the subject of history, instead of a country. Once you do that, the political squabbling of the middle ages (or today) makes much more sense. A state isn't a machine and you don't drive it like a racecar. In CKII your aristocrats pursue their interests within it, and diplomacy is an extension of internal political squabbling. Sometimes that involves expansion and building nice things ... and sometimes it means tearing countries stuff apart. It also makes the honours and mechanics of courts and feudal family politics real game mechanic material instead of decorative fluff. Its easier to understand Richard the Lionheart if you see him as pursuing dynastic interests on both sides of the English channel for facebook likes from his mates, than as chief executive of the Eternal Albion.

So I have well over 2-3K hours on CK2 as I used to play it on my friend's account and I torrented it to try it (Yes Ik pirating games is sacrilegious, but u can't even play MP so yeah I obviously bought the game). CK2 in my opinion is the best paradox title to date; sure it has a learning curve but tbh it's not as bad as EU4 or Stellaris. The endless amounts of replay ability this game has is endless and playing Multiplayer is a must do. Its free now at least and CK3 i feel won't be much of an improvement. Speaking of mods, this game has some of the best developed mods i seen. Notable ones are Elder Kings(Elder scrolls), AGOT, After the End, WTWSMS and Umbrae Sphera. CK2 In my opinion is a must get game, especially while its still free, only need a friend with the dlc and you're good to go.

180 hrs playtime, and as I gather more DLC's the game keeps getting better and more dynamic. Quite amazing, one of a kind game about medieval folks trying to get by.  

When I see the store page, and see the grand total of 300+ euros for the full package, I understand why people complain. But I must disagree. I have spent about 125 euros total on this game + DLC's (I have almost all functional expansions) and will gladly recommend the (almost) full functional package at that price, no question. There have been plenty of sales and I could have gotten it all even cheaper if so inclined. So price to me is not a con here.

What remains is one of the best games, if not THE BEST game I have!

Some reasons why:

1. My main amazement with CK II is the fact that I have felt friendship in this game, and have felt glad to have a friend. I have felt kinship, and have felt the need to protect my own. I have more or less understood love and hate between characters, and the intrapersonal dynamics of power that fuel it.

All these things have been of great influence on how I perceived the world through my active character, the choices I was presented with, etcetera. I cannot remember playing any game ever that pulled this off.

2. The scope of the game is incredible, as is the way strategic hidden gems are just lying around waiting to be found and taken advantage of. The greater whole of all the systems running in this game create a very vivid environment which is simply fun to interact with and analyze.

3. The King is dead, long live the King! What can I say? Living the lives of your Kings and Queens can be an amazing experience. There will be heroes, there will be failures. Quite often not where you expect them. CK II does a good job at throwing life at your characters. The passing of a heroic warrior King is not something to be taken lightly.

5. Excellent UI and presentation- I thought the game was very accessible if you consider the complexity of it's systems. 


With CK III in the making, I believe this game is a landmark still worth buying. And I believe it will remain so for a while.

This is one of the few games that you actually can have fun with even when you're losing. The game isn't about a grand "You Won!" victory screen, but the journey that brought you there. Want to roleplay as a worthless, imbicile lord who's just been lucked onto a throne? You got it. Want to be a king who installs their trusted horse as a chancellor of the realm? That's cool too. 

When you're tired of playing in Catholic Europe, there are so many possibilities that are fleshed out for the Islamic and Hindi world as well. Unfortunately, those are thrown under the DLC-Bus that Paradox is known very well for. The good news to that, believe it or not, is that Holy Fury is the last DLC for Crusader Kings II, so it is effectively a finished product. 

If I was going to buy CK2 today, right now, I'd HIGHLY recommend at least Way of Life. Conclave and Monks+Mystics are a strong second choice, but every other DLC can be added as needed, if needed. Holy Fury is fun, but if you LOVE playing as medieval India, a lot of the content in that DLC will be worthless to you. 

Especially since this game is Free to Play, consider picking it up and finding a quick tutorial on YouTube to get playing within 30 minutes. I guarantee that you'll get way more worth out of this game than a modern, "Reforged" strategy game.

I spent months trying to learn how to play this game. I would return to it every few weeks. But every time I got half an hour into a game, I would get overwhelmed by the grand complexity of it all and have to stop playing. 

Eventually, my hard work paid off. I began to understand the systems and the mechanics. I have now been able to have so much fun. The game is a real masterpiece of generated storytelling. I've had games with storylines as complicated and as riveting as any Game of Thrones episode. I would highly recommending getting into this game if you have the time and energy to do so. And I would recommend getting some nerdy friends into it as well. It can be a bunch of fun to swap crazy CK2 stories with ur buds

Many people say this is a great strategy game but the bad I see out weighs the good about it.

Graphically there isn't much here which for the price and amount you have to spend on DLC content, I expected better for my money.  Granted strategy games don't have much need for them but compared to others like Civilization V it really is lacking in that department. 

As to game play firstly there isn't a tutorial at all and there is also a lot of menu interfaces that a player will have to navigate. It really does force you to click on each one to figure out how what the menu does. Notifications the game gives also aren't helpful in getting to the correct menus so what was the point.

Another annoying thing about the game play is the unwritten rules each grouping of cultures and people have in place. For instance if you play as a Christian nation like England then you have to come up with a Casus Belli or "Cause for War" to go claim another territory. Something like that should be as simple as bigger army crushes little arm and gains spoils of war is made cumbersome when it shouldn't be. 

Additionally to learn more of this game enjoy reading a sizable wiki just to understand the basics. Sorry but basic content of a game should be made available in game. Not having to do more homework just to figure out basic features. 

I have spent a fair amount of time on this game to truly give it a chance but after the frustrations of having to research just to understand what basic features and mechanics are there was no enjoyment. Also be ready to fall into the Paradox trap of shelling out a lot of cash for DLC content that really doesn't add much more to the game.

In short, there are people who really like this and great for them but I couldn't get behind it nor recommend it to anyone.

Crusader Kings 2 is a historical sandbox/real time strategy game, with a focus on characters. This is not a game for everyone. The joy of this game comes from dominating medieval Europe with your chosen dynasty over centuries of careful planning and manipulation, it is the true Game of Thrones video game. Some of the most interesting play-throughs come from the most epic of failures. Graphics are sub par, sound is solid, and game play is slow; yet the whole package is oddly rewarding and addictive.

As a big fan of all Paradox grand strategies, this is one of my favorites. Contrasts nicely with EU4, while still being similar games. Like the rest, careful choices of DLC can maximize gameplay while minimizing cost; if you buy everything, prepare to be disappointed by overpriced releases.
If you are a fan of role playing games and grand strategy, this game combines the two perfectly.
You will easily spend hours playing before you realize it.

I have over 1,200 hours in this game, but sadly I would not recommend it to anyone buying the game fresh today.  The main reason is when you get to the late-game, if any empire, yours or otherwise, is over a certain limit the game will lag out to the point where about once a month, you will sit for ten minutes or more, just waiting for it to finish calculating things.

Remove that one small thing, and this is one of the greatest strategy games ever.  Unfortunately it's a bit like asking Mrs Lincoln how she enjoyed the play.  If that performance issue is ever resolved, I will gladly update my recommendation, but it's just too big and important to set aside.

The incest simulator. Teaches some good lessons. The biggest lesson here is that a good ruler does not have to act ethically "good" but he needs to do what is best for his realm. You will learn about history, organisation of noble titles and how to raise a child properly. The game offers depth, it has a constant learning curve, even for experienced veterans, but beginners can also enjoy it and you will learn within time how to rule.

This game is not going to be for everyone, I can promise you that, but if you're interested in complicated games that always seem to have something new to discover and master, then this is the game for you.

It's just an insulting business model. Sure the base game is free, but the base game isn't worth playing for free.  

the basic DLC pack will open up just enough of the game that you can click on a lot of new feautures, only to be told its part of another DLC you don't have. Its dissapointing because i've always wanted to get into ck2, EU IV and vic II but I can't justify spending the equivalent of a console on these tittles just to play the game as its meant to. 

I'm not sure how to write this without sounding irrationally bitter, its hard. The DLC is good in that they do add a lot to the game, but only a few of them add something that feels like it shouldnt just be included for free. Sunset invasion? I don't own it, but it makes sense to me. It adds a mayan invasion mechanic that totally forces you to change how you play and plan. Cool, no issues with that.  Reapers due? a 17 dollar DLC to incorporate the plague into a game set in mideivil times? That should have been a no for me dog. To expand on that example,  The reapers due DLC also allows you to build hospitals to prevent diseases in your territory as well as adding some new diseases to deal with. With only the base game you will still have disease out breaks (they just arent called plague) but you won't be able to build hospitals, nor will your neighbours so you will be at the mercy of that mechanic without the DLC.  There is the option to build a great wonder , and use two feauture slots to build something that helps with disease resistance but the most you will get is 5%. for new players, a wonder will cost 10X what the hospital does, will take 11- 20 years to build, and using the feauture slots for the disease resistance is kind of a waste compared to the other perks you could build into it. The base hopsital building gives a better disease resistance and is affordable in the early game and can be upgraded.  This is what makes me tap out on paradox as a dev I do business with.  The way their DLC interacts with the main game makes it seem really obvious that these are feautures that were removed in the development stages, not an innovation to the game. there are numerous other examples like the reapers due. If you dont buy all of the DLC pertaining to islam, the islamic factions will either be crazy overpowered while mainland europe is struggling to make flame consistently, or they'll be a punching bag for crusades. Without that DLC Spain always fell to to islam, then they move into france/ italy and create a large enough muslim force that no crusade being called can stop it. Because usually only the UK will avoid it, but they'll be getting plugged by vikings if you don't have the DLC to balance them out, and even if you do, theyre just really god damn strong like vikings were.  This was cool an dynamic the first 15 times it happened. Then I buy some DLC, the islamc factions get the decadence mechanic and a few others, then they function like a legitmate counter balance to the catholic and unorthodox church. Just another example of  them forcing you to buy DLC that just makes the base game work as it should. Does paradox expect me to believe they didnt run test play throughs and watch the same 5 outcomes happen everytime? Historic Mongol invasion that for sure happened as DLC? Is this a historical sim or not? Want to create a character and plug him into a tittle and have your own version of history? DLC. the list goes on. And when you get curious about EU4 (you will) you'll see that it is not free, with the same DLC model.  Along with all other paradox tittles. Paradox can make a fun to play game, no argument here but I put my Footdown at 100$, and I take the time to write a review at 250$ -300$. There is nothing  game dev can do to make CK2 or EU worth that much, sorry. Were talking about a game that has been around for like a decade, get real. I believe in paying for products I like and supporting dev's who games I enjoy but fuck off. Bundle all of this into a 100$ then sure it'd be worth it. the base game, the DLC that shouldn't be DLC, and the actual innovative DLC for a 100$ would be reasonable to me.

The other thing worth mentioning is there isnt a whiff of a tutorial. they say there is, but there isn't. The tutorial teaches you how to get annexed by islam. the base game is free, so its a minor complaint but you will find the same thing in EU4 and Vic2. I personally dont mind learnring strategy games by loosing at them for a bit, but someone new to strategy games isn't going to figure it out. I swear this is because they don't want to explain to you how little is happening in your DLC free experience. Before you comment that I must have just "not figured it out" I did. I was fabricating claims, creating my tittles. setting up my succession and so on, it just got stale real quick, and I dont think charging me another 20$ to have mayans come and take a big shit on my playthrough was the answer for it getting stale.
I have always really loved this playing this game and can not wait to see the new release.

This game is an open-ended strategic political dynasty simulator where you can rule from any region in Europe, starting as any feudal rank between Emperor and Count.

Fabricate a claim on your neighbor's county, declare war and conquer it, ransom his children back to him, plot to and then later assassinate the Baron who ruled over you both, start a political movement to usurp the kingdom as your own, then personally lead a massive army to conquer the neighboring kingdom and declare yourself Emperor shortly before you die from a burst blood vessel while yelling at your council and the sons you had with your concubines tear the empire apart into their own kingdoms because you forgot to change the inheritance laws to primogeniture.

Do all this while avoiding plagues, assassins, envious courtiers, maladies, and even old age, while the game keeps it light with often humorously-phrased text windows and obscure pop culture references. (Not to say that it's a comedy game, just that it's not overly dramatic.)

Unlike Spore, this achieves what it wants to be, though there's many many DLCs (which do add quality content) that Paradox put out to keep the lights on.

So, when you get the DLCs, you're supporting a GOOD player engagement model, one that encourages continued development for a la carte content.

It's a really great game, but be prepared to pay a lot to get the full experience. You'll want certain DLC in order to experience this game as was intended. It's a bit greedy on their part, but what can you do? I suggest Googling what are the best initial DLCs to get along with this game, and take it from there. 

Maybe it's best to wait until it and its DLC is on special, so put it on your wishlist and see from there.

Overall, 8/10 

Pros
- Unique experience. I don't know any other dynasty building game that also allows you to conquer realms, create kingdoms and duchies.
- Hundreds if not thousands of hours of gameplay. You can play as any count, duke, king or emperor from 1066 to 1337. The game itself plays on until 1453 and with Charlemagne DLC, you can start in 769 AD, leaving you almost 700 years of gameplay.
- Trait systems add interesting flair to each character, as they impact their relationship with their vassals, the amount of troops they can raise and they prowess at commanding armies and fighting duels. Striking a balance between marrying women with strong or genius traits to increase the odds of your own heir being strong and quick, or forging alliances.

Cons
- Rather simplistic combat system. You raise some troops, march them against the enemy. If you have more troops you almost always win, unless the terrain is not in your favour. No real tactics to develop
- Rather simple strategy game. The simplistic combat system makes it such that planing your conquest or survival mostly hinges on checking how many troops you have vs how many the enemy has. Since you almost always win if you have more, the strategy element is mostly missing.
- Supply system makes no sense. Castles just make sieges last longer. They do not protect or shield anything, which is what castles were used for. No matter how big a castle you raise, with enough time the enmy will capture it. There is no logistics mechanism in place. You can walk all over your enemy's land and the only thing you have to fear is their army larger than yours. 
- Map is crooked. Maybe not an issue for some but for someone with mild OCD like me, it drives me nuts that Crete is closer to Egypt than Athens, or that Sicily is south of Tunis. Arabia and North Africa are disfigured in relation to Eurasia. Historical Immersion Project (HIP) corrects this mistake but it seems such an easy thing to fix. This is mostly an OCD thing and doesn't impact gameplay at all but I hate playing in the Mediteranean because of this.
- Vassal system is in general very good. The more a vassal likes you the more troops you can raise from him. However, When raising troops from your vassals, your vassal retains their own troops. To put it another way, You have 4k troops in your demesne, and 4 vassal dukes, with 1.5k troops each. When you raise the 6k vassal troops, your dukes still have 1.5k troops at their disposal. What? Where from? It's like the duke clones his army and lets you use his clones that die when you disband them. 
The other major flaw with the vassal system is best shown in HRE and the Byzantines, and blobs in general. Because the HRE was composed of 7 (I think) core duchies plus other kingdoms/duchies incorporated into it, the game shows the HRE as massive with plenty of vassals. This is true but what happened in real life is these dukes were virtually independent, and the emperor could rarely muster a very large army. In CK2, however, HRE can raise anywhere up to 30k troops, which is kind of absurd. France by comaprison, really seems to struggle mustering more than 10k. This leads to HRE becoming totally OP in the game and the ''ally the HRE'' as a war winning move meme. Byzantines suffer from a similar problem whereby they always survive (1066 start date) and expand. There is no mechanism for unblobbing. Once you get enough vassals you are basically immune.
Difficult game with a lot to learn, but worth it if you put in the time. Lots to do, very different game each time you play, and tons of DLC if you become a fan. Get it on Sale.
If you love grand strategy could not recommend this game more highly.

This is an incredibly deep, complex, at times obscure and frustrating game, and after many years of major updates and DLCs piled in modifying mechanics and adding oodles of new ones, it can't be said that it makes an entirely parsimonious whole. It creaks under the weight of its own systems, some of which are still far clunkier than they ought to be.

And yet, I've played 539 hours of it at the time of this review, and I've barely scratched the surface. I've never come across a game which creates emergent narrative the way this game does. I've never come across a game which provides as huge a sandbox, as infinite a range of objectives to choose from and ways to approach them. It's a flawed masterpiece, but it's a masterpiece, and I'm sure Paradox will use their experience with this game to make CK3 even better, and more accessible.

Crusader Kings 2 is a game where, unlike most in the genre, you play as a dynasty and not a nation. You control a character for the duration of their rule and proceed onto their heirs through the centuries. Note that these characters are not just idle collections of stats but they have personalities that will evolve as you play them and as semi-random events happen to you and give you choices that really get you roleplaying.

In the base game, you can play as any christian ruler between 1066 and 1337 and, due to the nature of feudalism, you are not limited to playing powerful kings or emperors but you can choose a minor count or duke and work your way up within your realm through scheming and strategic marriages. You can expand on your choice of playable characters with DLC but more on that later.

While it is very appealing once started, the game does have a bit of a learning curve to it, especially if you haven't played Paradox games before. My suggestion is to start as a count in Ireland in 1066 and slowly get used to the gameplay by exploring the notifications that pop up and dealing with new mechanics as your realm expands and you will take on further responsibilities. Everyone has a game where they don't know what's going on and that's the best learning experience.

If the setting is not your cup of tea, you can entrust yourself to many wonderful total conversion mods that will have you live many lives in the worlds of: Game of Thrones, Lord of the Rings, the Witcher and further original settings.

You may have noticed that there is a significant amount of DLC for sale. Most people get overwhelmed by both the scale and the price but rest assured that none of these packs are necessary to play. Each of them is themed around a particular aspect of the game so I would suggest that you try and play the base game (it's free so why not) and, if you enjoy it, you can buy DLC that either give you more content or unlock Muslims, Nomads, Pagans or earlier start dates. The price will start to seem like a steal when you play hundreds of hours and you've only had to pay a few cents for each hour of entertainment.

Crusader Kings 2 is a game that keeps on giving even after hundreds of hours. There is such a huge amount of content and possible starts that you will struggle to find boredom in it. If you can get past the entry difficulty you're in for a world of fun!

Gobs of depth and endless replayability. After almost 250 hours of play, I feel like I'm only starting to get a handle on all the nuance and strategy. The learning curve is steep, even for a Paradox game - the impacts of decisions you make can be far reaching and often are hard to understand until you've made a number of errors first. Part of the fun of the game is simply learning the way the game functions. I'd recommend watching a number of tutorials on something like Youtube before you spend too many hours wondering how to accomplish almost anything.

The game is not as easy to learn as even HOI, so be warned, you need to be willing to dedicate a lot of time to the game before it really gets satisfying, but the payoff is high.

The idea behind this game is really something unique. It's a shame that they decided to keep that dumb nation spirit in later games, but Imperator was a step in a right direction. Behind every statewide decision, there should be an influential man or group, not some *spirit*. I really recommend to play this game to get a fresh perspective on global strategies, but unfortunately without dlc this game lacks a lot of cool mechanics (contrary to magic buttons from latest eu4 dlcs, that make me vomit every time I see them at videos or patchnotes). Also, it can be seen as an rpg game (this side greately improved in some fantasy mods like Geheimnisnacht) that shows other role playing games *with dynamic open world* what dynamic open world really is. Due the fact that they position this game as feudal sim they allowed themselves to neglect trade completely and it's sad, because powers of Amalfi, Pisa and other maritime republics were really important at this time. Of course, there are Mount and Blade series games, that are pretty cool too, but they focus too much on combat for my tastes.

My favorite paradox game. Tactics and strategy change as you go through the years and different stages of the middle ages. You face the empire of Charlemange, viking raids, the first crusade, invasion of the mongols, fall of Byzantium, and the different political and social institutions that develop over these 500 years. It is incredibly satisfying to watch your dynasty spread across the world, becoming that world's Hapsburgs, having a relative on every through in Europe. Creating a kingdom, on path to the imperial stage, and forming a strong monarchy that gradually becomes more absolute and centralized as the years span. If you play, play from start to finish, and watch the story of kingdom flourish and your dynasty in every corner of the world.

This has been the most detailed grand strategy ever created. I have played this game since it came out with its first DLC, and it has certainly been a labor of love. Would totally recommend this game, its a rare gem in the gaming market. Its too bad that the industry is so riddled with SJWs there might me more games like it.

I think i've put enough time in this game to finally give it a review. Now that it is free i can't recommend it enough if you enjoy sandbox/role-play style games. People will moan about the DLC's and, tbf, they have a point-you don't need every DLC but if you do it can cost a pretty penny. Saying that, there are tons of free mods which masses of content i.e. LOTH, GOT, WOW, relics, werewolves/vampires/zombies/Santa Claus etc etc so you don't need the DLC's if you get bored of the Vanilla. I, personally, have purchased the majority (most relevant) of the DLC's but that's because I've put in a 1000+ hours into the game. Even then I've only ever purchased them while they are on sale. 

Beware, there is a massive learning curve to this game and I strongly recommend watching a crash course tutorial on youtube before starting as it can be REALLY off putting if you don't know how to use the UI and the in-game tutorial is pretty shitty tbh.

So far my review may come across a little bit negative but other than what has already been mentioned the game itself provides hours of fun and entertainment and the potential to create any kind of environment, style and genre you wish is massive- watch Roll1D2 Games on youtube and you'll understand what I mean.

This game is nowhere near strategic. If you're coming here hoping for a challenging, engaging strategy game, you won't get anything near it. What you will get is a slew of political drama with the most random, outrageous events triggered by the unpredictable NPCs that fill this game. You will be made a cuckold, lose your eye, watch your wife get fat, be attacked by Vikings, and maybe get one extra territory from it all, and just when you've scraped more than 200 gold together, you'll die from stress when your heir is still six years old and watch as your designated regent NPC lets the world burn before you reach 16 and take over the throne. That being said, this is one of the most entertaining games I've ever played and is well worth the download.

My most played game ever by a considerable margin, Crusader Kings II is one of Paradox's crown jewels, and, much like its siblings, is perhaps one of the most replayable games of all time.

Combining the grand-strategy nation-building of Civilization and Europa Universalis with the personable character-driven role-playing experience offered by titles such as New Vegas and Warband, Crusader Kings II offers diverse gameplay experiences which one can easily drain thousands of hours into. The dozens of traits, cultures, and situations the player could potentially finds themselves in spawns thousands of different special events, and hundreds of event chains, which keep the game from ever getting lethargic or stagnant. 

The modding community, much akin to most other Paradox titles, is vibrant and flourishing. The critically acclaimed A Game of Thrones Mod, much like HOI4's Kaiserreich, is widely considered by many players to be one of the greatest modifications ever made, and in addition a complete overall improvement upon the base experience. Considering around 1000 of my hours on CK2 have been on this mod, I'd be hard-pressed to disagree. 

However, I will not blindly give this game a full 100% recommendation, despite my great affection towards it. Crusader Kings II and Paradox both have a myriad of substantial issues, all revolving around DLC policy, which could prove as game-breaking for CK3 as they were for Imperator Rome.

Paradox's DLC policy is infamously miserable. Most of the material added could easily be implemented through updates, but instead are bifurcated and repackaged in the most inconvenient of ways so as to make the most amount of money as possible. This leaves the base-game feeling incomplete, and thus, not nearly as enjoyable as it was in years past. Crusader Kings II is by far my favorite strategy game of all time, but I'd be lying if I said it was worth the hundreds of dollars Paradox expects their customers to sink into their finally finished product. 

Not every DLC is horrible; I consider Holy Fury to be the greatest DLC Paradox has ever released, and a fitting final installment which breathed new life and hundreds of hours of possibilities into the game. The Reaper's Due is definitely worth the purchase, and The Old Gods is too, while being slightly overpriced. However, the vast majority of DLCs are, despite adding enjoyable and worthwhile content, thinly-veiled cash-grabs which I would only recommend accruing in the event of a Steam Sale. These DLCs, constituting the vast majority of CK2's downloadable content, should have either been:

a) included in the base-game (Ruler Designer, Customization Pack, The Republic)

b) included in an update (Jade Dragon, Legacy of Rome, Sunset Invasion, All Content Packs)

c) combined with other DLCs to form one fantastic DLC worthy of a $15 price tag (Sons of Abraham, Monks and Mystics, Way of Life, Conclave) (note: this would regularly cost OVER 50 US DOLLARS)
 
d) reduced in price by 33% (Sword of Islam, Horse Lords) to 50% (Charlemagne, Rajas of India)

The result of this revised DLC policy would still cost the player around $75, which is already profitable and expensive as fuck, and thrice the cost of The Witcher 3's DLCs. Shockingly, this revised $75 DLC price tag is 3-4x cheaper than the current one. Just by looking at these numbers, anyone with a modicum of common sense can easily discern Paradox's blatant greed. 

All in all, I definitely recommend trying out the base-game, the A Game of Thrones mod, as well as some of the better DLCs. CK3's impending launch will definitively show the world Paradox's true merit as a game developer. Whether it will be a phenomenal, innovative, and inspired sequel to CK2, a great game plagued by impending avaricious economic decisions, or an EA/Bethesda-level stripped down clone of its predecessor remains to be seen.
Although the amount of DLC is outrageous, it's still an awesome game. Ideally nab the DLCs while they're one sale.

Decide to play as polish rulers and form a polish empire to rival that of the HRE. Game is going well, have expanded into Pomerania and have taken most of Prussia and Lithuania. THEN the queen of Franconia decides to invade. F*ck me right? She has 17,000 troops while i have a measly 9,000 troops coming fresh from a holy war . She ALSO has the duke of Milan as an ally so that means another 12,000 troops on deck. I manage to get mercs and win two (2) major battles. After the second battle the mercs turn on me and declare an invasion. the battle cost me 2,000 troops im sitting at around 6000-7000 men. I make an alliance with France and they enter the war. meanwhile the franconians have an endless supply of money and hire MORE mercs. another 8000 so they are sitting at about 11000 with some more of her vassals showing up. I know france is my only hope. Two weeks after entering an alliance, A massive french civil war breaks out and they decide not to show up for the war. the pope, before the war began called for a crusade and the crusade started at the beginning of the war. Pope gets pissed because i didnt show up when im in the middle of a bloody war keeping my kingdom together. But then, Lithuania shows back up they want piece of their land back. i wouldn't just give those pagans my land but they had about 13000 men. I managed to forge an alliance with Lothungria, but they enter too late. Even with the Franconians never winning a battle, not one (1). they besiege enough land to win the war. I managed to get enough money for more mercs, dangerous i know but i wouldnt go down to these pagans without a fight.  The Day before my troops were set to arrive in a major clash of two armies...the mercs betrayed me. the moment my bank went negative they betrayed me. i fought for as long as possible but lost the combined forces of Lithuania and the mercs beat me. The two Christian forces (France and the mercs) allowed for unholy pagans to win a war against a christian and allowed for the second most powerful country to fall because of greed and betrayal. I have vowed, Queen Ciri "the Missionary" of Poland, the Rightful Queen of Ruthenia and Chergoniv, Descendant of Boleslaw the Bold, to see my vengeance fulfilled. I will take back my land from the coward Germans and disembowel the queen with mine own hands. Then i will scourge the pagans and make them meet my maker. Then i will make sure the French never know peace and then when my vengeance is complete i will allow my death to occur.

I've played 385 hours with this game and fully intend to play more. This is one of those games that doesn't force you to play the game its way, you play how you want. You play a ruler in medieval europe and can go to war, murder your friends and family, and go crazy. All kinds of combinations. great replayable fun strategy.

+-+-+  Sequel is coming very soon. Free to play? Heck yeah!!

===  I only own the base game, no DLC's unless they were provided free of cost.

+ the game is fun.

+ It is at it's heart a strategy game with very little tactical elements beyond generals' assignments based on their skill and terrain considerations.  It's about strengthening yourself by marrying to strong houses.  And conquering or vassalizing weaker neigherbors.

+ I enjoy this game, but i can definitely understand why some ppl wouldn't like it as much.

============
My suggestions to improve the game:

It would be nice if there were much more event style interactions between characters which show and develop their personality.  (Your vassal invites you to go falconing with him, but you'd already promised your wife a romantic row around the swan lake.  What will you do?)   ...options that allow you to choose between developing relationships between 1 or more persons; or between a relationship and your own skills.  So I can actually shape my ruler into something rather than being pretty static.  This should occur for all characters, not just the one the players is controlling and lead to small, medium, or large changes in relationships.

As it is, you wait 5 years to raise a too-low skill a few points through a mundane interaction you've probably seen before.  Just feels like it needs a lot more spiciness in this area in my opinion.

Maybe there is a setting to change the frequency of random events.  If not, i wish there was, with options being:  weekly, monthly, bi-monthly, bi-annually, annually, every [x] number of years.   With it not being 100% guaranteed, but somewhat random heavily weighted to occur at said interval.

Crusader Kings 2 - or Incest Kings 2 as my friends likes to call it is a excellent game. It's kind of like Europa Universalis 4 more character driven cousin - with its "create your own story" aspect of the game is which makes the game.

You can get all kinds of insane and... "fun" events - like your 17 year nephew trying to shag your 60+ year old ruler. Or like marrying a Duchess that is a widow and killing her male children to gurantee that your sons will inherit the dutchy, or instagate a rebellion against your king. Or start worshipping satan in hope that he will restore your "crown jewles" after castration, just to take a few examples of my own games.

The posibilities are truly endless with this game. The downsides are the complex mechanics you'll need to learn - like how inheritance and de-jure laws works and the extra DLC that you'll need for some parts, but if you enjoy the game I recommend picking up the DLC you find most interesting for the kind of gameplay you enjoy after spending some time with it.

This is not a game about conquering the world as the king of France or the like (though it certainly is possible) like EU4. This is a game about crafting your own story about your dynasty. If you try to play it like EU4 with fabricating claims and such you'll have a much worse time compared to trying to role-play or play the marriage game.

CK2 is at its core equal parts a Grand Strategy game and a Role Playing game.  Though you can play in a total min-max, utalitarian way (which is still fun), the most fun can be when you play the game AS the characters.  Not always choosing the "best" option in favor of one that fits your character would choose can provide a extremely satisfying experience.  This game is 100% about the journey, not the destination.  True, starting as the genius, strong, attractive Holy Roman Emperor would make it easier to "win", but it's much more satisfying to sit back at the end of a 300 year long game as the Roman God-Emperor, seeing that you started as an fat, one legged, Albanian dwarf.

I've been playing this game for a loooooong time, and it is one of my all-time favorites. The level of thinking needed to survive and thrive in this game is a welcome challenge; you can make a decision that 6 hours later can come back to bite you if you aren't careful. A staggering amount of content that lets you do pretty much whatever you want makes this game stand out alongside a multitude of cookie-cutter military and political strategy games. The learning curve is a steep one though. The tutorials are terrible, and I pretty much depended on the CK2 wiki to teach me how to play. You will lose a lot, but you'll feel so much more accomplished once you're ruler of the medieval world. Definitely give this one a look.

edit: WARNING! CK3 has been announced to release for 2020. Do feel free to nab this as a goodie, but do not invest into DLCs or suchlike, you're buying what will likely end up a deprecated game within the coming months!


Over 6 years, and not only is this game still kicking, it's still getting massive content updates, like the recent Holy Fury.

Yes, I probably sank 200 bucks into this game and all it's DLCs by now, but take it like this: How many AAA titles at a 50-60€ price range can keep you truly occupied for a year and a half? Because that's what CKII did.

Paradox Interactive is one of the, in my humble oppinion, best game developement studious out there. They use the Agile Developement Manifesto, they listen to community input, they regularily patch their games and pump out new, free content (which is financed by selling DLCs alongside that).

The only 'negative' about this game is, that it's complex, easily overwhelming, deeply intricate, ruthless and slow. It's a very specific niche of Grand Strategy you may or may not enjoy. And if latter is the case, there's no helping it, this game isn't for you.

However, if you aren't sure, go ahead and check out some Let's Plays, and then grab the base game, which ranges from cheap to FREE (yep, they recently gave it away for free), and give it a try. And if you like it, rest assured that every penny you spent buying the DLC goes to people who actually deserve it.

Bonus point: No micro transactiond :D

Jensen's and Meckling's Agency Theory - The Game. This game is a must play if you love the chaos that is humans doing what humans do best: Looting, pillaging and, of course, calling for a crusade to India despite having no clue where this "India" actually is.

I have over 500 hours played on this game....and I can't say I have had more than two or three satisfying endings. The problem comes down to a single mistake can lose you a battle, which can lose you the war, which can lose you a kingdom. Which is great if the game mechanics weren't counter intuitive at times, and undergo changes over time. Meaning you might think you can do something, only to find out you can't, or you might have been able to do it before an update changed the mechanic, but now you can't.

If you are not playing on Iron Man mode it may not be a big deal so long as you are saving often. Just reload the save and try something else. The thing is, I like Iron Man mode, I feel like reloading saves to bypass tough areas is kind of cheating. The biggest issue though is that the RNG will kill you in completely BS ways every single time. You can play the game perfectly but sooner or later some BS will happen. Like you just won't have any children and all your other heirs will be killed or die of illness. It happens. More common though is your ruler will die randomly, and then everyone will declare war against you at the same time. Many of my games have ended with my ruler dying and than 3 wars starting within a year of his death.

Most recently I have been a victim of even more outrageous BS. I started on an the island of Socotra. After several generations I had the most advanced tech in the world, had successfully become a Sultan, and had just won an offensive war against the Caliph. I could call up over 2000 levies from my single county island alone, having built it up as fast as I researched tech. I had almost 1k gold stockpiled, and even though the game kept killing my family members with murders and illness, I had a heir, and things looked promising....

So what happened? Well, first of all I used the assign titles intrigue option for the 15 new titles I took from the Caliph, which then were assigned extremely poorly and only partly so, as It seems the person assigning titles assigned one to himself which then canceled the process unfinished. Almost immediately thereafter, my capital county becomes heretic, Completely random event which I had no control over and almost immediately after it becomes heretic it rebels....with 9000 men. At this time I can at max raise 6k men, spread all over the place. However, because the heretics emerged on the island, the over 2k men I can raise there are suppressed and I immediately lose if I try to raise them. Here comes one those mechanics that really really pisses me off, and part of the reason is it is counter intuitive, and part of it is because it didn't always work the way it does now. 

I have 9k rebels attacking my capital, I can raise an immediate 2k, and ship in another 4k. I wouldn't win with that, but I have nearly 1k gold and can hire the two companies in range giving me over 10k men, with high level commanders I almost certainly will win....except the game mechanics have been made/changed in such a way that it can't be done. Any mercenaries I hire get hired at my capital, now normally if the capital is being attacked it doesn't place the mercenaries on that county, but because I am on an island...guess what. On top of that, they made it so mercenaries start with 0 morale now. So I could drop in 4.4k mercs but they would instantly lose the battle because they have no morale, but what if I put my fleet off shore, and give them the command to retreat to the ships. Well that doesn't work. Apparently someone decided that you can't retreat to ships unless you are raiding? So I have 1k gold, and can't use mercenaries. Great. So now I lose my capitol because I have nothing to contest it with. That is not the end of it though. While my capital is under siege about a third of the counties declare a war of independence, including those I just gave counties to. 

Wait, it's not over, right after they declared for independence a nearby sheikh declares an invasion. I end up losing the war of independence despite winning every battle, because I don't have enough men for a conclusive engagement, and they just need to hold their counties until the timer runs out, which they barely did as they retook one as I was about to take another, and instantly went from me winning to 100% in their favor and them automatically ending the war in their favor. I easily defeated the sheikh despite that, then tried to reconquer those that declared independence, but I couldnt attack all of them because I didn't have a casus belli to do so....Meanwhile. I lost my capital because I had no way to retake it, but because it is an island the rebels can't leave as thy have no fleet, so they just sit there in a perpetual war that blocks me from ever hiring mercs. I tried playing past that point but, I realized I couldn't hold on to my kingdom with my capital locked out, no mercs, and constant wars erupting.

Essentially my gold was useless, I only had access to an increasingly smaller portion of my troops as the game killed my rulers off one by one, couldn't use mercs, and over all the game wasn't fun anymore. The problem is this is just a different version of the same ending I get every time I play. I can play a perfect game, but it does not matter, because sooner or later events outside of my control kill me. It wouldn't be that bad if game mechanics weren't designed so poorly. Why are mercs being hired into combat with no morale? How come I can't retreat to my fleet? For that matter why are rebels on an island not given ships? If they had just left the island I could have bought my 4.4k mercs, retaken the island, then sailed off to win my other wars, fight a war of attrition against the rebels, and eventually won. Instead I ended up in a position with no ability to win due to no error on my part.

Edit: Almost 2 years later and finally corrected the horrendous amount of typos in my original review. I think spell check died after the first paragraph and I never read through the original draft before posting. Well, it is fixed now.

I changed my review from negative to positive, for the simple reason that I complained on the official forums about the gameplay issues I experienced, and played a few months later to find they had been fixed in a patch/update. You can now safely hire mercs when your island capitol is under siege, as they will spawn in another territory you control. I also believe the automatic assign titles function was fixed, although I don't know if it is still possible for it to stop partway through due to the person assigning titles assigning one to himself and halting the process.

Developers responding to feedback to fix bugs and unintended issues in a timely manner, instead of just ignoring player input, putting it off for years, or using any number of excuses like "it is intended gameplay" is a pleasant surprise in an industry that often only bothers to look at in issue if a vast number of people complain about it or excessively documented it. The game mechanics still change with updates, but as long as problems are addressed and gameplay is intuitive, I will continue playing. The last couple times I have played, I felt the RNG was smoothed out somewhat as well, where incredibly unlikely events didn't happen one after the other.

>Shores raided by norwegian vikings
>Capture one of their mayors in battle
>Imprison him, and forget about him
>A few years later, trying to fill out my commanders for an upcoming crusade

>Release and recruit him
>Becomes top commander

>Refuses, for shits and giggles ask him to tell me about paganism
>He makes some good points
>Oh shit, I'm secretly worshiping Odin now

>Persuade my shy, chaste wife to join my cult
>Struggle to get new members
>It gets me down, so wife suggests we head out to a tavern in disguise to blow off some steam
>Get drunk with my wife, in disguise , openly praise Odin together, get wasted
>Some one calls me a heretic
>Tell him to shut his mouth
>He beats the shit out of me
>So bad I'm visibly wounded
>Wife drags me home
>We fall in love once again
>Have three sons, all join cult
>Bar brawl wound heals into a scar
>Go on a Crusade, die in Anatolia fighting for Christianity while secretly being Pagan
>My cultist, crusader, deceitful King is remembered as 'Brian 'The Wise'
