UPDATE: 9/4/2016
I still play this game at least once a week for a couple of hours. With the advent of each new DLC the game expands to reveal even more depth and gameplay. Its a game I would recommend trying and slowly gaining the dlc over time becuase if you like it you will keep playing it. Each new DLC adds something new that you have to figure out and learn how to deal with and manipulate. This game has a steep learning curve but one of the most unique aspects of this game is that losing is truly fun. You enjoy the story and are always curious as to what might happen next. I would avoid anything that says, CONTENT PACK and only pick up things that add features when buying dlc. Don't be in such a rush to buy all the DLC at once unless they are all on sale because it will take time for you to learn all these new features and I found it was alot easier to learn one system after figuring out how the last one works. This is a true simulation and as such, it will not hold your hand. But if you have the patience and determination to learn from your mistakes then you will enjoy this game for many years.

The game is infuriating. The UI is a nightmare. The RNG will constantly fuck you over. And learning mechanics is still unintuitive and requires a wiki. But I keep getting an itch to come back to this game.

The base game experience from what I've heard is extremely bare compared to the experience with all the content expansions. But the game has kept me playing for 7 years with a steady drip feed of deepening mechanics, an expanding map, and expanded game play for different areas of the map. If you start playing this now and start to slowly purchase content as you learn systems, the game has an almost limitless replayability value. You can even randomize the world for more replayability now.

I'd recommend picking this game up if you like enjoying the journey to a destination as much as the destination itself. I'm not sure if I would recommend it to grand strategy players. The game is more about the characters and their interactions than the grandest of strategies.

Okay, fine, this game is getting close to edging out my previously-most-played game on Steam in hours played, I guess I'll tell you to play it.

It's a beautiful mess.  It is an optimization problem with just the right level of degrees of freedom to be catnip to my brain, with enough RNG to both amuse and piss me off on a regular basis.  

But in the unlikely event you're reading this, here's something actually useful: the "starter"/"tutorial" campaign is garbage.  It is the equivalent of tossing a toddler bodily into the deep end of a pool to "teach" them to swim.  This is not a game you're going to learn via the in-game introductory campaign; it is a game you're going to learn by spending hours reading the wiki, or if you're really patient, watching Let's Plays/tutorial videos on YouTube (though literally every CK2 YouTuber I've watched to date has actually been almost infuriatingly bad at min-maxing the game).  Do "Noob Island," aka Ireland (Petty Kingdom of Mumu) in 1066 first.  That's the best low-pressure intro to the game.  After that, research succession law on the wiki and then go nuts.  

Essential DLC (after you've played the base game and decided you like it enough to spend some money):
- Way of Life: way more control over your ruler's development as an adult
- Monks and Mystics: societies are great

Conclave is kind of polarizing; I've never played with it and don't intend to, YMMV.  In terms of gameplay variety, The Old Gods (pagans! 867 start date!), Holy Fury (even more pagans! and also bloodlines), and Charlemagne (769 start date!) offer, in my opinion, the most bang for your buck.  Sword of Islam (play as Muslim) and Rajas of India (play as Hindu and a few other eastern religions) also, but to a lesser extent overall, in terms of novelty of game mechanics offered (but culturally those two are immense).  Sons of Abraham is small but annoyingly vital for certain precarious starts (as it offers the option to borrow money that you can then either pay off or... not).  The Republic is also pretty important in a lot of cases because of retinues.  (Ruler Designer is very meh to me; other people consider it essential.  I have no experience with The Reaper's Due, Jade Dragon, Horse Lords, or Sunset Invasion.)

ANYWAY, this game is great if you like fiddly grand strategy, which I definitely do.  It will not hold your hand.  Read the wiki.  A lot.

I used to play CK1 for years and years - people called me strange or a nerd for they were playing shooter/racing games instead and could not understand my interest in these 'boring', 'static', 'non bullet dodging 3d' games.
To them games should have more graphics than features. To me its the other way round.

So it should come as no surprise that I'd pick up ck2 as well which has tons of more features around the same core gameplay of ck1.

quick summary of game. I'd say: Think sims in medieval world. you manage marriages between nobles, princes and princesses but for political gain or alliances. there is also wars for land so it has strategy aspects and its real-time, not turn based (no end turn button to click). Game also has mods for instance game of thrones or Witcher kings or lord of the rings if you dont like the vanilla world.

edit: why the downvote now in 2018? Well, read the other reviews, dlc's are becoming a huge problem. Imagine having to 'pay' for each mod on any game and you should see the problem fast. You get sold half a game, and to 'unlock' all the features you need to pay for dlcs. Want to play a certain nation in this game? no problemo, just pay us $$ and we unlock that for you on the game that you 'already' purchased. Want your character to be able to grow a beard? - here, pay for this customization pack..

Only Community mods still keep me around.

Oh my God, I loved this game.  It was so much fun, truly a blast to play.  I gladly paid out for the first few expansion packs, which only added more fun to the game.  I'm exactly the kind of nerd they were designed to go for.

But then there was another expansion pack.  And then another, and then another.  I stopped buying them, I never purchased them for this game's successor, EU4.  Which means that this game, and EU4 are games I'll never truly be able to enjoy, because so many features are locked behind a paywall that is over $100 at this point for either game.  It's obviously a successful business model, and this is still one of my favorite games ever.  But I can't play it or anything from this studio that embarks down this path.  It makes me afraid to try their future games.

This is a subjective opinion about certain things in Crusader Kings 2 rather than a review. My thumb down means that I don't personally like this game. I can see other people like it a lot, but have gripes about DLCs and cost. My beef with the game lies elsewhere.

Over the years, I have bought Paradox games like Hearts of Iron III and the Victoria games. And then this. Paradox games look interesting on the surface, and if they're on sale, I often feel like buying them. And then... what happens then is that I might even install the game. And then I might play it a bit, during one evening. And then it gathers dust and I tell myself that yes, someday I should play it some more since I bought it and all. And maybe after months and months, I play again a bit. And soon years pass, the games untouched.

The Paradox games look appetizing in the store. They look nice in your list, give you a kind of intelligent air of an armchair strategist and a general.

But when it comes to actually playing them, thats another story. Wouldn't it be better to play, well, I don't know... Mine sweeper? Hello Kitty Adventure Island? Anything? Watch a cat video? Grind a piece of gold in some MMO?

It is very difficult to put a finger on the reason for such a feeling. Every time I touch the games they seem rather to turn me off than excite me. 

Lets think of some old great games in the same genre, like Civilization I, Master of Magic and the very first Master of Orion. What these games have in common that you have offensive units. You move these units, you destroy the enemy. Destroyed, the enemy is dead. What belonged to the enemy is now yours. Its the ancient secret of steel. With those games, you can utter a satisfied "Crom!"

Not so in Crusader Kings 2. You don't annex land by wiping the tile clean of resistance. No, you need casus bellis, excuses. A Nietschean will to power is not sufficient. Whatever you do, you don't live forever. You have all sorts of scum hanging around you, trying to get a piece  of your pie. No, I don't mean the other countries. I mean your vassals, your relatives, your children. You have to think of marrying, your offspring, their marrying, you have to manage the whole soap opera of relationships (so its a dating game), the laws of inheritance, how your kingdom will be split into splinters after your passing. And this passing can happen any day when you step on a banana peel! You just get a popup declaring you died. And no, you cannot choose your steps better to avoid the peel. Oh joy, after your death you get assigned some of your offspring as the new you to play, and a pitiful shard of your previous kingdom as your new property.

CK2 serves you a kind of socialism where you as the player pay the inheritance tax for your own death. This death cannot be avoided. But you can try to avoid the taxman as much as possible, and I suppose this is meant to be a part of your kingdom management. Perhaps some people find that interesting.

The three other games I mentioned above are simple, childish power trips, where you become He-Man (or She-Ra if you like), essentially a Master of the Universe, your power growing with a satisfying soundtrack of 'muahahahaa'. Master of Magic pretty much explains your ascendancy to omnipotency in its wonderful end-game monologue. Paradox games, on the other hand, seem to me explorations into generic feeling of impotence, difficulty and having to react to all sorts of random garbage that happens. And in the end, death by old age is the reward for your kingdom building efforts. This death will happen soon, as your medieval life span is quite short to the hundreds of years the game itself can span. Why did you bother to do all that work in the first place, since as a king you got the served the same fate as the lout in the gutter? For a while, more of the map was marked in your color, some number was saying you're doing a good thing. For a while you had bling in your coffer. Then, the worms have their meal.

In the end I feel it is the complexity, the management overhead, the random event crap, and inexorable death,  that makes Crusader Kings 2 an unappealing experience.
